reviewText:
A tale of a broken man in a land of perverts and Joy.


Crude,Rude, and lewd. Lisa stars a man who's been broken for many years, incapable of forgiven himself for the loss of his sister long ago, both beaten and abused by their father. Brad Armstrong grew up protecting his friends and teaching karate in his dojo. Envied by his friends, hated by his father and deeply traumatized by the loss of his sister Lisa Armstrong he soon resorted to painkillers to forget and wipe away his regrets.

The world erased in a white flash, everything changed and everything destroyed. Mankind had its females seemingly removed from existance and the world crumbled into a inhospitable place, mutants, gangs, perverts, murderers and psychopaths rule the world now. In the middle of this is Brad who'd become addicted to Joy a new drug in this destroyed world now using it to kill his past. One day when taking a hit of Joy a baby all of a sudden appears in his arms, not only that but a female one.

Brad taking this child to his friends rejects the idea of giving her up for a better living to the local gang leader Rando, Instead he sees this child, now named Buddy as a secound chance. As his daughter or maybe just a means to put his past to rest. Wether its either is up to the player since not all of the cards are on the table.

The only thing known is that you will suffer and your actions will cause suffering.


All in all Lisa is a strong RPG, the roster is amazing, the story is blank enough to allow speculation.
The soundtrack is unique and amazing. The art style is off the walls and the whole world is a perverted joke and will have you cringing and creeped out by its warpedness. The game is a clear shoutout to Mother and Earthbound and Mad Max so old school gamers and RPG lovers with adore this game.

However due to its limited side scrolling the map can be confusing at times, cliffs can easily be jumped off of to your death, bugs and glitches do occur, enemies can permanantly kill allies and the amount of status effects can be confusing.

Its probably one of my most favorite games on steam right now and in existance, The story made me feel for Brad and Buddy aswell as making me feel the weight of losing an arm or a party member to one bad move or choice on my part. You will feel hurt playing this but in the end the game does what it wanted to, to make you feel.

Honestly whats a good game? One that makes you feel for what its created. Wether you on purposely play as a selfesh person or a selfless one, or something in between you will feel like you made a impact in this broken and beautifull world.

reviewText: I just finished Austin Jorgenson's LISA and can say that, without a doubt, it is among the strongest indie RPGs I have ever played. I was hooked on the world of LISA with the slight taste given by the prequel, LISA: The First, which had me eagerly awaiting this title. The developer cites Mother as a key influence and that shows, but even more than the abstract game OFF, LISA has taken the wacky humor and surreal style of Mother into a dark and very adult place. Dingaling is able to take simple, old school pixels and work them into truly disturbing imagery. Lately, we have been inundated with post-apocalyptic settings that are xeroxed and re-sampled at will: zombies, plague, fallout and bad weather. All of those settings, done to death, are fairly grim, but none of them can even touch the misery suggested by LISA. Here we have a world where women are extinct and the surviving men, seeing no future for humanity, have transformed the society into a sort of prison yard where hopelessness is drowned in drugs and alcohol, and memories seem uniformly sad. The main protagonist, Brad, is driven by a past filled with abuse and grief, and literally sets himself against the will of the entire world. The player will be forced to make tough decisions in this game and to eventually think about and judge the outcome. Even as we laugh at sight gags and endless pro wrestling references, one cannot ignore the uneasy slithering quality of LISA. My greatest hope is that the game does well and Dingaling games develops more titles where the heart of the game is a great story, not the ability to snipe someone in multiplayer. Bravo!

reviewText:
Holy crap.

Powerful.

This game explores some serious life issues: Abuse. The pain of childhood, and of parenthood. Manhood and womanhood. Strength. Loss.

This game had me near crying at several points. The story is freaking powerful. It's also remarkably well written, and downright hilarious at times.

And the gameplay?

It's fun enough that I want to play through it again right after beating it. This turn-based RPG is sometimes brutally difficult, in part because it slaps many old-school conventions in the face (e.g., sleeping can be dangerous). Battles are challenging. Tactical thinking is essential since many enemies are VERY dangerous and you're frequently outnumbered. I really applaud the AI as it keeps you on your toes.

The game doesn't hold your hand. There is no map, compass, or any attempt to make navigation easier. You just have to remember your way around, though there are plenty of memorable environments.

Characters will force you to make decisions with lasting consequences. There are dozens of hard choices to make along the journey, which brings me to another topic the game explores: decision. Will you save your friends, or your stuff? I got very attached to the buddies I picked up, only to have them devoured by a mutant, or bail on me when I least expected it. You just never know what you'll face, nor what to choose. Thinking back to many of those times, I don't know what I should have done. All the options sucked.

But I can't help asking myself, Did I make the right choice?"

Highly recommended."

reviewText:
I'm not going to extensively rate the aspects of this game, it's just--
After playing for almost 10 hours, it's still not over, yet the gameplay or atmosphere don't feel stale. The world of the game is relatively big, but it feels enormous due to the amount of things you can do.

I don't understand. How can a cheap RPGmaker game achieve that? How much time hard work was poured into it? It's mind-boggling.

Almost every joke is placed with surgical precision into the story, providing fresh and morbid experience for the player.
Art is the perfect tie-in, amplifying the tone of this game to suit the narrative.
And, most of all, the gameplay feels smooth. Smooooth.

Without doubt, it draws inspiration from Mother games. I'd call it LISA: "Earthboud" for crude and rude adults."
And I like it.

Ratings are for nerds

reviewText:
Lisa tells the story of Brad, a broken man, forsaken by hope, who relies on self-medication to forget his haunting past. The setting is a post-apocalyptic wasteland, where women no longer exist and porn magazines replace money. Lust has made monsters of the men that have survived. You will encounter characters that will fight relentlessly or kill themselves before your eyes. Soaked with despair, this world varies from being horrid to hilarious.
Death is ever-present and you can lose your companions permanently or sacrifice parts of yourself to spare their lives. Do you deserve your arm anyway?
The story begins when the protagonist Brad finds an infant girl, and is given the chance to right his wrongs and spare her the pain he suffered. Keeping her isolated, although she represents the future for a world that has none.

Lisa tells an eventful, compelling story that will make you laugh, aggravate you, and quite often leave you disturbed. I enjoyed every moment of it and recommend it to everyone that shares a fascination for games that explore the cruel depths of the human mind.

reviewText:
This might literally be the coolest game I've ever played, and possibly the best game that I've played in the last 10 years.

Though, I might be the wrong person to ask though as Earthbound is my favorite game, and this game is obviously heavily Earthbound inspired. Stylistically and comedy wise anyway. The story is much darker than anything in Earthbound, but it's all buried underneath some of the funniest writing I've ever seen in a game. The writing start to finish is amazing, I'm only dissappointed that the game wasn't longer as there's a few questions left unanswered.

I did normal mode, first run, collected all characters and beat the game in 12-13 hours. For 10 dollars, that's pretty alright. The fights are pretty open ended as there are like 20+ characters you can choose from, but I ended up using Rage, Bottles and Mad Dog. I found it wasn't the hardest game I've played, but I also haven't tried pain mode yet.

Anyway, if this game interests you at all, buy it. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
It's rare that I find myself writing Steam reviews, but in this case I find that I really should.

Having finished the game, and only done maybe about 3/4ths of the content that the entire game has to offer, I can easily recommend this to anyone as my Game of the Year for 2014. There is a unique world presented in LISA that's both heartwarming, terrifying, and altogether tragic.

For every single moment of laughter, there's a moment that comes where a decision you make permanently affects the denizens of the world. Whether it's your own character, a character you've come to enjoy, a character you despise, or an entire town of strangers you'll more often find yourself resting your chin in your palm and scratching it until the moment passes and you've made your final decision. Even once I did, I still found myself asking if what I had done was right.

That said, the gameplay will not be for everybody. It's incredibly difficult to get started and quite often you'll reach decisions that seem deliberately designed to royally mess you up, and even then it's possible to keep pressing on. There's also a deliberate pace and VERY unsettling subject matter and atmospheres, however the game never feels like it's forcing you into bad situations for the sake of it, despite a handful of cheap shots that get pulled you quickly learn this world cares nothing for you right until the very end.

If you enjoy Shin Megami Tensei's punishing difficulty, Earthbound's quirky and often heartwarming but sometimes dark humor, and a decent turn-based experience loaded with interesting moves and decent status effects. LISA is just the game for you. However, if the thought of losing characters, making heavily burdened decisions, or extremely mature and unsettling subject matter leaves you shaken, this may not be the title for you.

Overall, I can't recommend this game enough, it truly stands as a paramount to what people can achieve when giving it their all with RPGMaker. Not all games need a happy story, but it doesn't take a happy story to provide an unforgettable experience, and I feel that's something worth exploring in the realm of gaming. LISA can proudly stand next to titles like Mother 3 and NieR for boldly exploring darker themes and handling it all in a mature manner.

reviewText: Once you read the description of LISA and see the whole choice mechanic generally two things set into your mind. On my first run through am I going to be doing the goodie-goodie run or the spawn of Satan run? You will play through it with this idea in your head that you’re going this route, but it won't be that way. Oh no. It doesn’t go that way, ever. Once you get to the end of your first play through you’re going to feel like a mutated pile of congealed sadness spitted up from the bowels of Johnny Cash as he plays his cover of Hurt. Because it will hurt.\n\nOnce you stand up and walk away from LISA, It will still hurt. Then you will think, Hey
date: I can get a better ending. That will make me feel better!". You sit down and play through it again. Now it hurts even more. Then you try again. And again. Still you can't seem to make things better. You try every combination not to have it end up that way. Then as you sit back after your fifth play through
recommended:
it hits you. It hits you like a freight train with a nuclear bomb strapped to it.

Brad isn't a miserable broken man.
You are.


Disclaimer: I played LISA back when it was still only available through Kickstarter. Hence the 5 mins in it."

reviewText:
With all the hype for Undertale, it's a shame that this game passed under the radar last year for many people.

LISA is an RPG that'll make you hate life. No, not by its difficulty, as its pretty basic as far as RPGs go, but by how cruel and sadistic the world it presents to you is. It feels strange how this obscure indie game creates a more believable and interesting post-apocolyptic world than Fallout ever did. It's genuiley threatening and disturbing, despite its silly Earthbound-esque vibe. I never thought an RPG maker game could give me an actual sense of dread.

Tons of party members, satisfying combat, tons of abilities with their own unique animations, funny moments, scary moments, sad moments, and a story that'll leave you satisfied and empty at the same time.

This game is actually the sequel to another game, known as LISA: the First. A Yume-Nikki style game that contains fun topics such as child ♥♥♥♥ and abuse. It's not necessary to play that game to fully understand the story, but it's still worth a look. Be warned, both these games can be pretty graphic.

reviewText:
LISA is a game that's intentionally polarizing by design, and simply playing through it's introduction alone is enough to give you an understanding of why so many people never finish or play it at all. The plot is a pitch black, grim, and hopeless affair filled with only occasional forays into light hearted and humorous territory. But the catch here is that these moments are designed to make the inevitable fall back down into the blackest pits of human cruelty imaginable even more devastating and impactful. You see, while LISA is a deconstruction of many common JRPG tropes, it's main deconstruction is that of a trope found in many forms of media, not just videogames. That trope is the notion of protagonist centered morality. What this trope means is that in a story, when the protagonist causes innumerable amounts of death and destruction in their quest, they'll still be a hero and still be loved and praised by the populace, because although they've caused all this, their goal is noble so they're relieved of consequences or responsibility for their actions. LISA disposes of this folly almost immediately. The main character, Brad, is not only suffering because of the awful events that have happened in his life which he has no control over, but by his own decisions and actions as well. Brad has a noble enough goal right? Save his surrogate daughter Buddy from the people who kidnapped her. Except the things he does to accomplish this start to get increasingly worse as the games plot unfolds. Not only that, but the regular people of this world do not look at Brad as if he's some divine hero that must be showered with praise, most of them look at Brad and see this sad old washed up has been and loser, whose just another nobody and a drifter, and then they proceed to ignore him, harass him, try to rob and kill him, make fun of him, and just treat him like garbage in general. And as his actions grow larger in their notoriety and scale, Brad becomes a sort of an infamous demon to the world. So much so that people either attack him on sight out of pure hatred, or retreat from him out of pure fear. And all the suffering that befalls on his companions and loved ones during the games events are all at least somewhat Brad's fault as well, and at many times Brad will be made to pay for it with mortal injury and failing at all his goals. In the end, this is not a story about someone conquering their demons and becoming a better person, this is a story about how someone is completely consumed by them and not only destroys themselves, but those around them as well.

While I for one never found LISA's gameplay to be outright impossible even on Pain mode (the hardest difficulty) I can see why many are repelled by it as well. Unlike most JRPG's, you have a large pool of party members (30 to be exact) that are not only fragile and expendable, but are actively encouraged by the game to be used up as resources in decisions and situations that are either dangerous and risky, or ask you to give up some of your protagonist Brad's strength or items for the life of a party members. Another feature that is in LISA is one you usually don't see outside of rogue likes, certain strategy games, and CRPG's. And that is permanent death. Whenever you are fighting a particularly powerfull enemy, sleeping at campfires, or being faced with a decision, there's a random chance or a conscious decision on the players part as to whether or not a party member will be killed off forever. There is one thing that makes it all easier on you. There is no grinding required whatsoever in LISA. How is this possible? Simple, you gain enough exp from exploring and fighting pre set enemies you can actually see and walk into. Consequently gameplay is now spent venturing into as many new areas as possible instead of fighting the same enemy in the same caves or same forests for hours. After all, the largest  amounts of exp will only be found by exploring and fighting enemies that are well off the beaten path.

When all these things combine, they form an experience that's both foreign and strange, and yet so human and relatable at the same time. For those of you who are easily offended or disgusted, or for those who subject matter like this brings back unpleasant memories or experiences, you will most likely not enjoy this at all. But if your willing to try something that's truly unique and impactful despite everything mentioned here, you might just have an unforgettable ride ahead of you.

reviewText:
*TLDR: WARNING*  tl;dr: Shut up and buy the game.

LISA. How can I talk about this game in a way that would make any kind of sense..? Well, keep reading to see me try. At it's core, I can describe LISA as Earthbound's side-scrolling creepy uncle. The game at the time of this review of mine has not recieved nearly as much attention as I feel it deserves. It's equal parts touching, funny and heartbreakingly tragic. Gone are the JRPG tropes or teen-young adult pretty boys and loli girls, in are Middle-Aged men, Luchadors and Fishmen (to name only a few replacements).

With a very powerful opening that tackles bullying and an abusive father, we're thrown into the shoes of a middle-aged balding man named Brad Armstrong and his battles with substance abuse, where the game jumped forward an unknown number of years to a post-apocalyptic reverse of the comic Y: The Last Man" where men are the only group of people who have survived whatever incident has occured. That's when our unconventional hero Brad

Is LISA NOT for you..? Do you want to invest some time into a game? Do you just skip through speech to mow through a game? Are you homophobic? Do you not want to play the role of a 40-something bald man and his team of freaks and weirdos? Do you have troubles with games that don't hold your hand?  This game is probably not for you.

reviewText: A story-driven JRPG-ish game about a withdrawn, addicted and kinda tortured middle-aged man trying to save a young girl he had once found abandoned in the barren land and raised with a few friends of his in secret for some years. That secret got out though, and since the world knows no women anymore everyone tries to get his hands on her, either to sate sexual urges or to make sure she'll be used to breed children and thus save humanity from the otherwise inevitable extinction.\n\nLISA's world is kinda post-apocalyptic. Could be America, could be not - not much is said here. Sometimes memories of the past flicker in front of the eyes of some characters showing a world that was once intact. Since there are no women around anymore most men apparently saw no reason to take proper care of what we would regard as civilized: Many people sleep in tents, caves or other derelict make-shift-ishy structures; gangs roam the area, people fight each other over gasoline, dirty magazines" (which is the world's currency) or other stuff; joy is - for example - being found in playing Russian roulette

reviewText: An Earthbound-like RPG for a modern age, LISA is a unique game that juggles a deep story with dark humor. Basically, it takes place in a post-apocalyptic world reminiscent of a Mad Max movie where there are no women left on Earth. THEN BAM YOU'RE A DAD AND CRAZINESS HAPPENS. It's not perfect; the game can be punishing, and it doesn't run perfectly smooth (might just be my laptop). Still, it's one of the most original RPGs available on Steam or anywhere else. The story is engaging, the atmosphere is incredibly weird, and the cast of characters gets stranger and stranger as you roam the world. It's a must-play.\n\nTL;DR: for fans of Earthbound, Fallout, and Barkley, Shut Up and Jam: Gaiden, Chapter 1 of the Hoopz Barkley SaGa.

reviewText:
I have played and beat the pre-release of LISA two times and now again for the third time on steam.
I will try to collect my thoughts, that gathered up during that time with the game, into this review. I will try to avoid spoilers.

LISA without a doubt is a very special game. It is one man's passion project. (scroll to the end for TL:DR version)

THE PRICE:
Special games such as this are rarely made to completion, and when they are, their nature is such that it demands concessions.

This is a technically weak game for what people might expect from a commercial title, options are scarce, controller setup highly counter intuitive, resolution non-adjustable, and full-screen mode hard set. It has all the issues you might expect from a game made on a RPG-maker platform, such as an antiquated battle system and very rigid platforming.

If technical shortcomings of a game turn you off, I would like to suggest that they shouldn't, as a game is not a car or a tool judged upon its specs primarily, however if you are not willing to make some concessions to a game over its technical aspect LISA is not for you.

THE VISION:
The state of nature is such where there is <...> no account of time

reviewText:
LISA: a miserable journey and a fantastic game.

At a glance, you might confuse LISA with some typical modern indie expulsion of cargo-cult nostalgia, or think it's one's of gaming's many cringeworthily immature attempts to 'get dark'.

Don't. This game deserves your attention.

LISA's surreal, insightful 'man's world' takes you to bleak, scary places but keeps you truckin' on with sharp black humour and just enough dangerous hope. Consequences are explored cleverly; consequences of the strange apocalypse, of your own decisions, of plain old rotten luck. The audiovisual design and deft game-mechanical touches elegantly create moods; of alienation, doom and fleeting beauty.

This may sound over-the-top for an RPGmaker side-scroller, but it isn't. LISA is honestly one of the best games I've seen in years. I'm not going to spoil the story for you; just play it, you won't regret it.

~
Uppers: A creative, daring story in a well-realised setting that uses its dreamlike quality brilliantly. A wealth of fun characters to grieve for and misplace. Catchy music. Thought-provoking situations. Surprisingly fun combat. Genuine humour and understanding of the human condition. Replay value that'll bring you right back like a kicked dog. Flashes of virtue and hope that only hurt you more.
~
Downers: Quite laggy in some areas which may necessitate a quick game restart. I think there's one very minor mechanical limitation that won't bother you if you don't notice it, so I won't reveal it. I permanently lost Terry early on and now I can't stop crying.
~
The Bottom Line: LISA grabs your mind and bites down hard. This game puts much more expensive developments to shame in its intelligence, thoughtfulness and sheer fun factor. Do yourself a favour and give it a go.

reviewText:
Pop culture has an obsession with being “edgy,” whether it be through grittiness, hyperviolence, or manipulative melodrama. “Edgy,” as a term for describing somehow-exciting and somehow-different new art, has seemingly been drained of any positive connotations. It has become a word that’s to be used exclusively with a sarcastic tone, mocking the tryhards that would use it unironically to describe their supposedly daring and incisive new thing.

So what is LISA? A game with the unofficial subtitle of “The Painful RPG,” that touts a post-apocalyptic setting defined by amorality and violence, that features amputation and drug addiction as game mechanics—it’s edgy, certainly. But LISA is an effective reminder that “edgy” doesn’t always have to be said with an eyeroll and a scoff. Developer Dingaling has put in the effort to present a game that varies wildly in tone and charms, that does all it can to dodge the fatal one-note nature of so many other games that have tried and failed to claim edginess. LISA is a Venn diagram of “disturbing” and “silly” with a surprising amount of overlap, making its tangents purely into either side all the more effective.

(Read more on Deadshirt[deadshirt.net])

reviewText:
IMPRESSIONS after nearly 14|Fourteen HOURS of LISA:  (Full Playthrough)

BUY IT! -- After having completed it.  All I can say, is that I would have payed full price for this game.

After about 1/3 of the game, I knew it was good (great even), but had told myself that it wasn't quite the masterpiece that I had been hoping it would be.  I take it back:

This is an INDIE-MASTERPIECE!  ALL DAY, EVERY DAY, EVERY TIME...

This is what happens when you take the limitations of a game engine, focus on what works, writing a really compelling, layered and deep story - and just take it to its pinnacle.

My mouth dropped just as many times whilst playing as I did laugh out loud.  This thing is so completely funny, and at times so tense as to make you uneasey.

LISA is unlike anything else.  It is funny, touching (I teared up within the first 5 minutes), the combat is stupendous and the soundtrack is worth owning on vinyl.  EVERY single one of the songs - of which there are plenty - is a winner.

I cannot wait to play it again and attempt to recruit the characters that I missed the first time around.  I'd also like to see where some of the different choices might have led me.

If this game looks like something that would interest you, even on the most basic of levels, I implore you to buy it.  This much game doesn't happen anywhere else for a sub 10$ pricepoint.

LISA and SHOVEL KNIGHT.  Time to face off for GOTY.

reviewText:
There are contorted, monstrous bodies in the wasteland. There are drugs that take away all of your pain. There are gangs that violate and murder whoever they want. But, there are no women, and there is no hope in this world. Until a drug addicted loser finds Buddy, a baby girl. The wasteland is unforgiving.

I think this game is best played with nothing but a brief description in mind, so after reading this paragraph, I recommend you stop reading. Comparisons can easily be drawn to Earthbound: the music and aesthetics of Lisa certainly recall Earthbound, but moreso than that, Lisa is willing to be bold with its gameplay. Where other games will treat death or a dark setting seriously in a cutscene but then have the game just rely on killing and ignore its setting, LIsa does not. There is some humor, mostly dark, but more than that Lisa is warped and sinister. It is easily one of my favorite games. It's a different kind of RPG experience that offers something both refreshing and depressing. Lisa has a rich setting and story, with great aesthetics, and solid gameplay (in the style of JRPGs with agility deciding turns).

There are lots of colorful characters, some nice humor, and fun music. But, above else, Lisa is a miserable game, that is engrossing and moving.

reviewText:
41 hours of my life spent playing a video game. Sure, I have 70+ hours on Warframe, but this was the first time I've been emotionally invested in a game and the first time that a video game has haunted me in every aspect.

Worth it.


Anyways,
LISA: The Painful, or simply just LISA, is a beautifully crafted RPG that resembles Yume Nikki, Earthbound, and OFF. This game may look like it's a piece of trash created by a developer in order to sate his own pathetic, perverted, violent urges, but it really is beautiful.

People can and will compare this game to Undertale, but I wouldn't. Undertale has charm because it gives you a semi-negative, semi-positive story and then gives you some closure at the end, but LISA's charm comes from the fact that there is no catharsis. No escape, no happiness. This game is hell.

The grim and depressing feel this game gives off is incredibly damaging, especially if you're an empath. Good thing I'm not much of one. In LISA, you will kill your friends, kill your acquaintances, kill people blocking your path, kill people because you need porn mags, kill people just to kill people, and kill people because you're terrified of what they'll do if you don't. You will sacrifice everyone and everything you love. You will cry, you will scream and you will damn near break your keyboard because this game will destroy you. Much like the blue-pill shaped drug seen constantly throughout the game, LISA is addicting.


There is little wrong with this game. Some lag here and there that I experienced, but ♥♥♥♥ that, lag doesn't stop you. People will tell you that the story is monotonous and drags the game down, but I found that to be untrue. People will say that the game is repetitive in the sense that you have to walk everywhere and not many things about walking are different, but isn't every game? Many of the negative reviews bash on this game because the people who wrote the review disliked the repetition.

The wind didn't blow in their favor. They walked away from that one.

I highly recommend this game, and everything related to it. Get it all, because at the end of the day, you'll find that the only Joy in your life is LISA.

reviewText:
I highly recommend this unforgiving game. It's unforgiving emotionally and in difficulty. The key to success is definitely saving--A LOT.

I'll start with some negatives(I don't see some as as negatives but others might):
-It's not easy and requires patience(I enjoy this)
-griding isn't an enjoyable experience from a gameplay standpoint--if you can find a spot to do it at all
-plot can be difficult to follow(I enjoy exploring the world to try and piece the clues together--which are difficult to find/realize)
-Permadeath for party members(Just don't be stupid and save a lot)

The Positives:
-Best soundtrack I've heard in a VERY long time
-Best sound design I've heard in a VERY long time
-Incredibly original art style with obvious influences--but not in a derivative way. Truly unique visual presentation.
-incredibly atmospheric
-very deep storyline for the players willing to pay close attention to the little details and explore.
-exploration is very rewarding
-characters in the game have amazing personality and most are incredibly human underneath the humor
-great absurdist humor--that is rarely cheesy
-long play time for the money, with several replays needed to really grab everything.
-developer talks and listens to fans
-game has great pacing in the story
-the universe will continue to expand with new games
-very few spots with random enemy encounters (THANK GOD) -- the encounters are 90% planned and highly detailed
-enough familiar classic jRPG elements to let the player spend more time learning the world dynamics(which is more important) and not the physical game control mechanics

Great job to the developer for A. finishing a kickstarter, B. Producing a complete game, and C. Making a fantastic game that has more depth than most out on the marketplace right now. I hope Dingaling Games keeps going!

reviewText:
I wanted to put a few hours into this game before writing a review.
9 hours should suffice for that now.

LISA is, as compared frequently, reminiscent of the game Earthbound (aka Mother 2), but with a dark, post-apocalyptic setting. You play as Brad, a man who had been a martial arts instructor before whatever incident had befallen the world, causing every woman on the planet to disappear and turn the lands barren. You then find an abandoned baby in the wasteland near your base and, shocker ahead, it's a girl, who you then decide to raise with your friends without letting anyone else know (for obvious reasons). Though obviously not everything goes as one would hope...

+Colourful style with well-made sprites
+Incredible Soundtrack (with around 90 tracks !)
+Alot of dark humour
+Many a party member with different stats, abilities and personalities
+Engaging combat system
+References ! (Praise the sun...)
+Unpredictable events and enemy encounters
+Unforgiving difficulty
+Terry mother♥♥♥♥ing Hintz, the Hint-Meister

-Perma-death for companions that can be caused by fighting certain enemies or following certain events. Then again, having your head bit off will do that to you.

All in all I'll be putting quite a few more hours into this.
Better prepare some sweet lemon tea.

reviewText:
★★★★★ Graphics and AudioThe Artstyle is almost perfect for this game. It's inspired by the cult classic Mother, but still maintains its own sense of style and personality, setting it apart from other games entirely. I instantly fell in love seeing it for the first time. The world itself isn't the only thing that's beautifully crafted, the battle system is still quite charming. When you preform moves and combos, your characters will actually do animated attacks, instead of just effects. Enemies do not, but that's a minor issue, it feels natural. The only issue I had was that the background of the battles feel a little uninspired and not very colorful, just sort of bland.
The music is perfectly crafted to fit to the theme of this game. Often I would find myself leaving the game open just to listen to the slick tunes. The sounds tie together the feeling of this game, neither being boring or intrusive.
This game is both visually and soundly a treat to anyone who enjoys retro rpgs and sidescrollers.

★★★★☆ GameplayMuch like Mother, this game doesn't let you spam attack and win. Every character is unique though, some of them preform moves based off a combo system, some characters work off a resource called Technique Points" which build up by preforming standard attacks and taking damage
date: while other characters keep the standard "Special Points" casting like Magic Points. It keeps fights from feeling mundane and keeps you on your toes. This game isn't a pushover
recommended: either. It's initially a bit scary

reviewText:
Lisa might be the single greatest game in my Steam library.
The sprite art is amazing, the writing is superb, and the experience leaves you with your jaw permanently dropped. I had to play through 3 different times just to see all of the endings and recruit all of the bizarre party members I missed due to poor moral choices. Speaking of choices, there is no such thing as a 'good' choice here. You're faced with some pretty heartbreaking decisions, and they really do affect you. I can't say enough about Lisa. It consumed me, and it will consume you.

10/10 - Would giggle/cry again.
voteText: 26 of 28 people (93%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Human civilization was never perfect, and the same applies to Brad. He had to live with abusive father, he had to get over his sister's death; he had to fight it, so he become a martial artist. Drugs maybe helped him to survive through the hard times, but they actually made everything harder.

But the thing that made living really harder, was the apocalypse. Don't think of demons or a meteor, something weirder happened - women weren't able to survive. Welcome to the Earth where testosterone overflows. But, like a God's gift, there is one little baby girl that survived. Coincidentally, Brad finds the baby and hides her from all dangers of outside. They lived a happy life until she decided that she finally wants to see the world, no matter how bad it is; so she runs away from Brad. And there begins LISA: The Painful RPG.

It's a game made in RPGMaker, but there isn't a classical world grid, there are platforms. Yes, it's a platformer made in RPGMaker with well known JRPG battle style. But there's an exception, besides classic turn action where you select attack, spell or an item, you use a combo system with Brad (and few other characters) to do few attacks and a skill in one turn - that requires you to remember the key combinations for combos, which are not more than 5 keys long.

Level design wants you to get lost in a ostensibly big world. The game itself is splitted into several areas, from which every area has many sublocations accessible from the centre. There's always more crossroads, and even more secrets.

Through your gameplay, you will meet many characters that will want to join your group. And as many people you will meet, even more you will lose. The game features a lot of gags and black humour, but it also plays a lot on you with depressive motives and hard decisions. If you will ever get attached to any of your party members, prepare that you can get really sad, as permanent death is something relatively normal in LISA. There are several special events, like Russian Roulette, but even if you try to ignore those as much as you can, there are enemies that can just kill your characters with a single attack without prior warning (even though they have full health). Stunning, blinding or some similar strategy against your enemy may help, but not always.

The overall atmosphere gets tougher with the fact that you aren't even safe at the campfire where you are restoring health and energy. You can awake in the morning without a friend, or deadly posioned, for example. This is the Dark Souls' player nightmare, right? Don't forget that the Brad is also still addicted to drugs (blue pills), so you will have to give him a hand or he won't be much useful on battles.

The main story itself offers about 7 hours of gameplay, but add many more hours if you are going to play through all optional content and the other endings. You can pick a difficulty for your gameplay, but even the normal one can get pretty hard in the pre-final area - just don't think that you'll slide through just with pushing attack button.

Graphics of the game may look poor, but they are fine and they do its job. All the blood, masculinity, monstrosity and grotesque looks great this way, trust me. You may have also noticed that LISA is tagged with Great Soundtrack" on Steam. That's definitely right
date: the soundtrack is so weird but unique
recommended: it deepens the atmosphere and makes you remember and hum some melodies later. Iconic.\n\nConclusion:Overall
hoursPlayed: if you don't mind the graphics

reviewText:
Sleeper hit of the year. With RPGs like Dragon Age:I, Banner Saga, and Wasteland 2, it's good to go back to a much simpler time to have a few laughs and even shed a tear or two. Taking a large amount of inspiration from the Earthbound/Mother series, LISA is a much more surreal and darker take on the genre.

Set in the post apocalypse with a men only world driven by unwholesome amounts of sex drive, you play as Brad; a broken man on the hunt for his adoptive daughter who is the only known female since the apocalypse. Your journey leads you into generally unwelcome terriorty filled with quirky characters chocked full of bizarre humor at every turn. With combat working like a traditional RPG style with an added combo system which can be controlled through the players input to preform special attacks.

The game is a roller coaster ride of emotion, morals, and choices, both which have a dark side to them. So much that you'll choke up on the many curve balls the game throws your way. These curveballs include sacraficing party members for your own skin or even the other way around;  where you yourself are offering an arm or an eye to save them at the cost of losing your combat prowess.

Overall it's a great game with a lot to offer and plenty of content. If you're a fan of the Earthbound/Mother series, you won't be disapointed! Buy this game!

reviewText:
This is a really good RPG and one of the best I have ever played.

If you like the idea of an adult Earthbound/MOTHER 3 side-scroller RPG with several odd elements and humor then this is for you.

If you like the idea of 30 different companion team members each with their own unique and bizarre movesets and conditions, this is for you.

If you like the idea of being put on the spot to choose between losing an arm or a party member, multiple perma-death situations and adrenaline fuelling Russian Roulette this is for you.

If you like expertly-crafted storytelling this is for you.

Buy this game.

reviewText:
A solid RPG videogame, LISA is packed with 10-20+ hours of good humour, discomfort and uncomfortable humour.
The game plays like EarthBound (albeit with a 2d side scrolling view) and the battle system also resembles it too. But be prepared for a lot of customisation as unlike the Mother series, you get to change party members from a large selection that's essentially the size of a miniture Suikoden cast.
There's 3 major HUB areas in LISA that lead to other areas filled with content. Your decisions and outcomes matter in this videogame so expect some things you wouldn't find in a conventional videogame. For example; at one point you're forced to survive 3 full games of Russian roulette to progress the plot. It can be a very unforgiving experience, but even when it screams screw you" it finds a way to make it hilarious.

The theme and story of LISA is as unsettling as it is funny
date: it's set on a world where everything went to crap akin to the Australia portrayed in the original Mad Max trilogy except without women. The dumb
recommended: crazed and depraved acts of men trying to entertain themselves in a dead world can sometimes turn from funny to depressing when you're reminded of their bleak future or the happier pasts they might have had. There's a lot of scenarios in the game and I heavily enjoyed the fun or depressing character arcs that the game puts you through. I struggle to explain any direct example from the setting
hoursPlayed:
plot or themes as I don't want to spoil the smallest things but I can gurantee LISA is compelling from the very start.

Most of the time the music is intentionally weird but there's a few genuinely great tracks that are very easy listening or funky. The bathhouse's theme may be my favourite out of the lot.

It's one of the better videogames I've played in recent years and I'd like you to consider purchasing it. LISA is likely going to appeal to you if you're a fan of Mother series
voteText: Yume Nikki or Mortis Ghost's OFF as it presses all the weird buttons fans of those games have. Game creator Austin Jorgensen should be proud of this title and I hope he finds time to make another videogame (similar to LISA or not) if he can make a viable career out of this."

reviewText:
LISA was a game I didn't expect much from, I bought it for 4.99 and thought I wouldn't have more than 2 to 3 hours in it.
Boy was I wrong.

LISA is a game filled with dark humor and memorable characters. I've explored every single thing possible in this game and I plan to do a third playthrough not only to 100% this game, but also to extend my time in this amazing world and change up the possiblities as 1 playthrough can vary a lot from another. The game also comes with a 'Painful' difficulty which does a lot more than just give enemies more health. Painful mode gives you a new ending which adds more to the story, new enemies, and tougher bosses. Oh, and the game has a kickass soundtrack. With 30+ different companions all with their own personality, hard decisions which can sometimes result in permanently losing your best abilities, companions, or items, and an engaging storyline, LISA has brought itself up to one of my favorite singleplayer games of all time.

I'd recommend picking up this game now as the next installment is coming this summer.
You won't regret it.


Pros:
- Great Story
- Tons of variety
- Lots of items
- A lot of unique companions
- Vast world to explore
- Lots of secrets and achievements
- Memorable Characters
- A hard mode that actually changes gameplay
- Great Soundtrack
- Fun turn based combat

Cons:
- Controls are a bit unclear at first

reviewText:
It's a damn shame that games like these will forever be overshadowed by games like Undertale, that got oodles of media attention. Hell, after the game was released and people were saying 'If you liked Undertale, you should play LISA! It's even better', people flocked to play this and the positive review percentage dropped like a lead balloon. These games are not similar, and people need to stop comparing the two. But I digress, on with the review.

In comparison to Undertale, which takes inspiration from the themes of Earthbound, LISA follows the source material much closer. LISA is a much more traditional, turn-based RPG where you play as a man called Brad, living in the barren world of Olathe as he finds the last girl left on earth, and swears to protect her with his life.

Story: 11/10. I'm not even joking, I don't think I can pop this thing any higher. When it comes to 'masterpieces' in video game storytelling, some either tell an epic tale with in-depth lore and feel, or some hit your emotions hard, and this is one of those games in which mixes a balance of lore and a deep, underlying meaning on the concept of masculinity.

Just please, don't spoil it for yourself, whatever you do. This is something that has to be played entirely blind.

Gameplay: 8/10 - Where some people say the gameplay behind LISA was repetitive and dull, I found the amount of creativity in the battle system incredibly engaging, and loved the use of story telling through subtle actions and notions done by the characters during certain battles.
Like many RPGs, LISA is your typical four-man party member turn-based game, recruiting party members with different roles to help your team. Where LISA differentiates from the rest, however, is how the combat is executed. There are lots of creative buffs and debuffs that you'd realistically think would occur in a world containing only men, such as depression, being drunk and even smelling pretty bad. Everything feels fresh and new, while keeping to a traditional RPG format, and that's something I can really appreciate with a battle system like this.
LISA's world is another thing that really helps the game stand out, as unlike most games that rely on a 3d perspective, LISA's overworld plays out like a 2d platformer, with certain areas being unreachable without certain items. This is used very well in a few gimmicky segments to help mix up the gameplay progression, but I won't be spoiling those here.
The game also comes bundled with a hard mode, entitled 'PAIN Mode', in which after using a save point, it cannot be used again, as well as the game in general being more difficult and having new encounters. This is really the mode that the game should be default to, in my opinion, as many of the game's features like the expendable party member roulette are seemingly meaningless in emotional value when you can simply savescum your way through it.

Presentation: 9/10 - Although the art style might be outdated, it stands out as being unique and different to other RPGs on the market, while still retaining that feeling of familiarity from its Earthbound inspiration. Every character looks and feels unique, with everyone having their own personality and traits.

Soundtrack: 10/10 - The composition work is truly a treat to behold with this one, with excellent use of leitmotifs and bizarre themes used throughout to further enforce that feeling of being alone in a strange place. It's exactly how I'd see a game like Earthbound's sountrack being made in the current era of games, and it really hits the feelings it needs to well. Not one song in the game is forgettable, and for that, I can praise the soundtrack with everything I have.

Aside from a few technical limitations due to RPG maker being what it is (Some slower load times in areas, which for how intensive the game should be, is abysmal to experience), the game is a must-play. People may complain about the gameplay, but you really only play RPGs for the story, right?

And it's not like you'd want to play it twice for how emotionally devastating the story is, anyway.

10/10 masterpiece, and I look forward to Austin Jorgensen's future endeavours.

reviewText:
There are plenty of good reviews already, so i'm gonna do something different.

This review is going to be comparing Undertale to LISA (this game). Why? They both are great games and share (some)
similarities.


MUSIC: It can't beat Toby Fox's soundtrack for Undertale, but it has some good beats here and there.

Undertale = 9/10
LISA = 6.5/10


GAMEPLAY: LISA has a lot more variety to gameplay. Better puzzles, fighting is more stratigic, not to mention the challenge of just getting around (which can be annoying at times)!

Undertale = 6/10
LISA = 7.5/10


STORY: Undertale has a pretty good story. So does LISA. Although LISA's is more dramatic and dark than Undertale's which for me is a good thing. That doesn't mean neither story is awesome however. Both have their plot holes and other negitives.

Undertale = 7/10
LISA = 8.5/10


HUMOR: Both games have humor that don't really get a huge laugh out of you (or atleast me). It's funny, but not hilarious. Although LISA's humor is much, MUCH more dark.

Undertale = 4.5/10
LISA = 6/10


DIFFICULTY: Undertale is quite easy. It's not really challenging unless you go down a certain path (even then it's mainly just finding out the puzzle of how the enemies attack and then your good to go). LISA can be quite difficult without proper planning, and the Hard Mode is outstanding!
UNDERTALE = 2/10
LISA = 6/10



CONTENT: Undertale will last you about 13-15 hours (depending on how fast you go through the game) to explore all the content. LISA will last you about 25-30 hours including the DLC.
Undertale = 4/10
LISA = 7/10


OVERALL: Both are great, and I strongly reccomend both, although I personally enjoyed LISA more than Undertale. It just hit me harder with emotions, and lasted much longer.
Undertale = 7.9/10
LISA = 8.5/10

reviewText:
Do not let the fact that this game is made in RPG Maker fool you.  LISA is a game worth the money I put into it.

The game's humor and characters are well designed and each of them have their own quirks and those quirks end up being used in battle a lot.  For example, one of the characters talks a whole lot and that quirk is used in battle.

The art style and world design is completely different.  Instead of a top-down view you would see for most RPG Maker games this game uses a side view where you can jump up and down platforms and climb up and down ropes.  Falling damage is also in this game depending on height.

The game's choices are, in a way, a little harder than you would see from other choices.  One such example is the choice from losing your party member or lose all your money and items.  Either of them carry a certain weight that has to be taken to perspective.

All and all I would wholly recommend this game to anyone looking for something weird and entertaining.

reviewText:
Welp, here it is. It's the end of the year and I have to pick out a GOTY for myself. Aaaaand out of nowhere comes this game that I didn't even hear about until it was out for a few days. This game just hits every single note for me in what I want in games. It has the emotion and choices that would be found in a Telltale adventure, the weird world and crazy exploration of Mother/Earthbound, and a kickass combat system with a killer soundtrack to back it up. Now let's get into a pros and cons format now that you know my taste in games.

Pros:
+Great sprite work ranging from disgusting to adorable
+Really wonderful soundtrack
+Hilarious moments and characters
+Incredibly difficult descisions that not only change gameplay, but change story
+Expansive world with tons of stuff to do
+Story that will make you angry, sad, and happy

Cons:
-Settings issues due to the RPGmaker engine
-Controls are wonky with a joystick and you'll find yourself getting game overs by falling off platforms
-Some bugs that need to be worked out(music sometimes not starting in a battle) but nothing major


All in all I NEED this game to be successful. This dev knows what he's doing with this genre and needs to continue to make games. I'd love to see a successor to this. I love this game, and it is without a doubt my GOTY 2014.

reviewText:
Game Details

Published by: Dingaling Productions, LLC
Developed by: Dingaling
Genre: Adventure, Indie, RPG
Release Date: 15 Dec, 2014
Completionist Gameplay: 50+ Hours

DISCLAIMER: I’ll be honest here. This game didn’t really do anything for me at all and I barely put any time at all into it (probably the reason why I didn’t enjoy it as much as others seem to have), but I can certainly see why so many people loved it. I tried my best to review this as objectively as possible and have used that to decide that this game deserves a “recommended” review.

LISA is set in a post-apocalyptic setting about a man called Brad who stumbles upon the last girl on earth. After keeping her safe from the rest of the men on the planet for many years while raising her as his own daughter, the secret is out and leagues of pervy men arrive to kidnap her. While the story is interesting enough, it never really caught my attention. It’s sarcastic humour and meta jokes combined with the depressing, hopeless and sometimes boring background story or characters left a bad taste in my mouth, though I can certainly see how it could be equally as amazing for another person.

This game doesn’t really bring anything new to the table, but it doesn’t do too many things wrong either. It’s an average, 2D-plane, occasional platformer with turn-based combat. While I like the added depth of special combo’s Brad and the other members of his party can use to inflict extra damage on their enemies if the player can remember the right combinations, as the game progresses you don’t get to do anything new. One thing I really dislike about the combat system is that there isn’t an enemy health bar at all. This can cause issues when in a particularly difficult and long fight, leaving you to feel like it might never end.It’s very vanilla and seems to be modelled after the classic model RPG, so if you’re into that, this game is for you! The platforming is mostly there to flesh out the scenery or reveal a little comedic scene. If you’re not careful though, you’ll continue on a cliff to the side of the screen, only to discover that it ended without any warning and you’ve just lost 500 HP.

One thing I really liked about this game are the choices it makes you take as you play. These choices will alter how you play the game, and definitely personalize the whole experience. For example, you could bribe an enemy instead of fighting him, sacrifice party members instead of your own arm, or even partake in optional mini-games (like russian roulette) that could either make or break your gaming experience. These choices really help the player realize exactly how hopeless and desolate this world is.

The art style and music choices of this game were very clever. The scenes and backgrounds are very beautiful, colourful and vibrant, and the music is invigorating and upbeat yet somehow do not clash with the macabre feeling of the story

Overall, I can see why this game is as loved by many as it is. There’s nothing fundamentally wrong with the game, the story is interesting, the game is playable, the art style is both beautiful and yet depressing and it certainly has enough gameplay hours for the price of it. If you’re a fan of RPG’s and hopeless efforts, I would recommend this for you as long as you’re sure that it’s something that you’ll love.

If you'd like to read more reviews from me, join my steam group!

reviewText:
Things you can do in LISA
-Competitively race shopping carts
-Puke on your enemies
-Burn a bunch of orphans (Why was that bucket there anyway)
-Meet a fish who is an attorney
-Kill people who stand in your way, kill people for drugs, kill people for the pornographic magazines that have become the new form of currency, kill people who threaten you, kill people you don't want to kill.

LISA is a game that will make you laugh one moment, then disgust you the next. Somehow, between the gore, sexual abuse, drug addiction and stomach wrenching moments, LISA manages to provide comic relief where due. Needless to say, you will laugh, you will cry. You will be forced to make decisions that you don't want to make. Do you really need that arm? Or that one? This game left me gutted and even after finishing it on pain mode, it is still in my mind. It's not a game you play once and forget about. This is the type of game that sticks with you long after you've completed it. You'll find yourself going back again and again because you didn't want that awful thing to happen. But it won't take many hours of this game to realize that there's nothing you can do to prevent all of the brutality that will be thrown your way.

reviewText:
As many of you might know(or not), this game is heavily compared to Undertale, and makes you ask: just why? I'm here to illuminate you(or not).


First of all, and I want to get this out of the way ASAP, both of the games have amazing character development. By the end of everything, you'll care for them more-so than your mother. You will LOVE THEM!!!, y'hear? However, might I say Lisa and Undertale take different approaches on this, but both work just fine. Now that this is done, moving on to the story.


Have you ever wanted to cry deeply from an emotional train wreck of a sentimental wild ride? Well if you're saying yes, which I know you are saying no right now you ♥♥♥♥ing liar, then Lisa is the game for you standalone. For maximum experience, play the Joyful afterwards, but I warn you, it's got boring gameplay. We'll get to that in a second. B-B-BUT WAIT, I hear you screaming with your Alphys emoticon in place, UNDERTALE HAS A GREAT STORY TOO!!1!1! Did I say anything about that yet? Then hold your horses. reviewText:
< Disclaimer!! I got this game for free for reviewing purposes >

Lisa is without a doubt one of my most favorite Rpg maker games ... I still am so shocked that this was created by that engine, Because its unlike any other Rpg maker game I'v ever played.

Such a brutal experience I had playing this, Its gruesome .. Sick ... Twisted ... and just Hilarious.
This game is not for kids.. thats for sure, I personally think its 18+ not 16+ but what do I know.

So now for the game itself.

The game starts with an interesting story, That slowly progresses into what your character is, Revealing bits and parts every now and then.
An interesting concept is that you can slightly control how it goes with the (Choices matter) Thing.
And the story is really dark and good.

The game-play certainly is something to notice, Because its a good platformer with many platforms to platform on ...lol
The battles are fast, They are unique and fun but being fast is an admirable feature because thats what you usually aim in an Rpg game, To not have to waste so much time watching your character do the attack animation.

The dialogues are so funny, The type of ( HAHA..ha...wait .. thats so EVIL ..HA HAHA .. I feel so wrong for laughing at this )

Everything in the game is so twisted, And the difficulty is something to count for,  Trust me DO NOT start the game with ( Pain mode ) From your first try,.
What pain mode does is , Gives an extra ending/boss/area and when you save at the savepoint it disappears so you cant save there again, So you need to go to the next one, Which is an actual pain because you'd die a lot in the game.
So its recommended to try after finishing the game once.

Characters are all over the game, There are a lot to find and get to join your party. ( And let me just say they are all pretty weird, Don't think I met any sane person )
Some wants money(magz) and others some certain stuff, But know that you'll lose a lot of them I will explain why.

Music is really good, And sound effects are good, Level designs are spectacular and characters looks great, The part I really cant deny is the animations... they're just so great.

So how the game works.
You get choices to choose from that effects how the game goes.
And one of those choices are whether to sacrifice one of your party members to keep your items, Or the opposite.
There are a lot of annoying scenarios where you'd be forced to pick between stuff like that or ( Your arm or this random party member), Later in game you'd be able to afford to lose a few party members because you'd have too much that you wont use anyway.

Resting at tents is really scary in this game, Because there are a lot of things that could happen to you after you wake up, A party member could get kidnapped, You could lose items, You'd all get poisoned or sometimes nothing happens.

I don't exactly know how deep your choices effect the game's story, But I do know you need to do your best to keep your party members alive at first because if you keep losing them, Then battles and bosses are gonna be tougher to vanquish.

Shops, Secrets, Weird events, Bikes to ride And much more content to encounter, Didn't feel bored at all.

Also a good note worthy part is the fact that this game is quite long and has some replay-value, And the achievements are really well-done.

I know you might see the disclaimer and see the review for this game being too positive you'd think I'm biased.
The only thing that could be biased is the fact that I enjoy Rpg maker games, But I dislike those that has no creativity or originality and just abuses the basic RTP library, When this one made its own design, And became a platformer unlike any other.

So the not so good parts.
- At certain parts the game felt extremely frustrating with pain mode, Making a small mistake and falling off a cliff and dying then having to restart from a long distance, So I felt like certain save points are close and others are just too far from each other.
- This is considered a con to some but it contains spoilers !!  So the fact about when you get kidnapped and forced to play Russian roulette with your characters, And it is all by chance, So you could either lose 1-5 members or none at all, And I was forced to lose a strong party member and had to load the game... which set me back a lot
- The platforms in the game are great, But considering this is RPG MAKER made you can feel some slight slow downs while jumping with your character, But when its on the bike its pretty smooth.
- In most parts, The game leads to you to the next area that is basically 5 different places to go to, Which you'd need to do by order to carry on with the story, I had to use a guide a couple of times because I got lost, I mean yeah there are clues on what to do most of the time, But it was designed to be hard and I got lazy after dying so much in pain mode, And used the guide which was a really informative steam guide.
- It crashed once for me, Which did not annoy me because thankfully it was a little bit after I saved, And there is this bug I encountered after saving at a tent ( Like all rpg games, Screen goes black when you sleep ) But then stayed black forever got stuck there, Had to close game and load.

So
Lisa, Is a game every big fan of RPG maker games should own.
Because it has so much originality and creativity in it that makes it standout between all those games.

WELL if you are not into platformers then this game is not for you because it focuses a lot on that, But don't forget it has a lot of rpg elements, And a really good story and the game keeps it fresh with those hilarious dialogues
Rating -> 8/10


This review was written while i was a part of the original traders group OTG, however you can trust that the review was not effected by that fact, I was not forced to lie or anything, you can read it and judge for yourself, all my reviews are honest and I am no longer a part of the group.

reviewText:
This game is my 2014 GOTY.
It's got it's own style to it, and it's so well done. It kept me on the edge of my ♥♥♥♥ing seat the whole ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ time. The cameos were fun, the combat and music was outstanding, the story was great, and at a lot of times, due to the scenario, the humor was hilarious.

There's a ton of companions, which vary from bros to ♥♥♥♥♥, LIKE ♥♥♥♥ING RAGE, ♥♥♥♥ RAGE. The game has a ton of nice little details, like a character named Bo, has a cool touch if you feel like exploring.
Like I said, the music was catchy as ♥♥♥♥, such as Work Harder, and it's incredibly fitting, helping the overall atmosphere.
I don't really want to rant on and on about subjective things, so here's some objective:
-Very well done RPG Maker game
-Variety of music
-Relatively lengthy for a one man show (10+ hours)
-Pro ♥♥♥♥ing Wrestling

Do I recommend this game? Hell yeah. Was this review well written? Probably not.

reviewText:
It would be impossible for me to not write a review about this game.

The game immediately harkens to the 'Mother' series with it's visual/art style, it's gameplay mechanics, unique cast of characters, humor, profound story and tweaking of the jRPG genre. With 'Mother 3' inparticular coming to mind in reguards to all of that. But it also has a air of a Alejandro Jodorowsky movie; with it's surrealistic/psychadelic nightmare worlds, blisteringly dark humor and it's depths of probing the human soul (the pancho doesn't hurt either).

I am impressed and staggered by this game; it forces you to evaluate the difficult decisions your characters are often forced to make, making me more than once pause to consider all the ramifications. It's a hard game, with a sharp learning curve that changes on a dime, and while that can be frustrating, it makes sense in reguard to the story.

There is so much I want to say about this game; it was a strange personal journey I took with these characters that I can't really explain in a short review. But it was depressing, funny, mind boggling, crippling, it was so much to me and I think a lot of other people got their own experiences from it. I don't think anything short of playing the game will help you understand that.

There are tons of strange characters to choose from, and it's often hard to decide on what team you want, but for me, when I made that decisions I stuck with them for pretty much the whole game. If I have any tips beyond making sure to carefully think out your decisions, it's save often, wrestle a lot and cry when you need to.

I can't reccomend this game enough. But, I don't think it will be for everyone and that's a good thing.

10/10 for pretty much everything.

Im a sucker for atmosphere and Lisa is on a whole nother level. Telling you why its good only serves to spoil the best of it. But as caution, it is not easy at first nor is it particularly forgiving.
Awesome gameplay, great story, drowning in atmosphere and creativity, in a word: Fantastic.

9/10

reviewText:
To start: I used to add a longer header to these reviews which explained my reviewing ethos, but since it often made the review too long to submit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery.

Gameplay: This game has been described quite a lot by now as a darker Earthbound, and that's not the worst comparison. I'd call it a sort of hybrid of the classic Shin Megami Tensei style of team setup where there are many people throughout the world which you can recruit into your team (unlike Shin Megami Tensei however, you can't recruit enemies) and the combat formula of Earthbound without some minor things like gradually decreasing health bars. There's over thirty members which you can recruit over the course of the game, and as the description of this game says, there is indeed perma-death, albeit not in as harsh of a manner as you may think.

Running out of health in this game results in you getting KO'd, not dying. Characters can die either through scripted story events or random enemy attacks; the latter of which I don't find particularly good. While it did force me to use other characters than my powerhouse team, it did feel frustrating getting punished just because of RNG. Unless I've completely missed something, there is no way to counter or predict killing moves; a design decision I feel would benefit the game. While it is funny that characters can just get their heads bitten off, it can be rather frustrating when that character is your powerhouse. Since it is RNG-based you can save-scum the game (in fact, you can scum the scripted sequences as well, but I'll let you figure out how to do that). However, if you choose not to scum up everything, you'll find yourself actually facing some pretty challenging decisions. Talk about these decisions, however, will come in the story portion of the game.

The comparison to Shin Megami Tensei earlier wasn't just one made to compare party systems; this game is pretty hard as well. Combat isn't as in-depth or tactical as something like Nocturne or Digital Devil Saga, but as far as the challenge goes, it is on the level of Digital Devil Saga's normal mode, with the aforementioned unavoidable lethal attacks included in that comparison. If you're looking for a relaxing RPG, this game ain't the one for you. It's not gonna blow your face off or anything, but it definitely has some expectations from you as a player.

Overall, I had a pretty good time with Lisa. It's about eight hours long (for me; I also know I missed a fair bit of stuff), so the $10 price fits the bill IMO. It's also the kind of game I could see myself playing sometime down the road, mainly for using different characters and seeing the other endings. This probably won't be for a while, but hey; at least it does have me interested in replaying at all. That's a lot better than other games have done for me. 8/10.

Story: From the trailer, I was expecting this to be a schadenfreude-laden adventure in which we enjoy partaking in the misery of this man named Bradley Armstrong. What I didn't expect was for the game to actually get kinda dark and heavy on me. This game walks a damn fine rope between dark comedy and just plain dark, frequently tilting to one side but never falling off. If you're looking for a happy game, go away. Now. If you're looking for a game in which teenagers go out to save the world from [Evil Entity X], you're in the wrong part of town.  If you're looking for a story that wraps itself up conclusively, well... sorry to disappoint you, but there's a lot of interpretation that you can have for this game. The funny bits in this game are great, the dark bits can be downright upsetting at times, and the ending could get a little too real for some. If you're interested in a dark and macabre tale about a man potentially ruining the future of humanity and in the process stepping on about forty rakes in a row for a cheap knockoff karate scroll, this game is for you. 10/10.

Graphics: Well, it's not gonna tax your system; that's for sure. If you can run Steam, you can run this game. As for the art style, I could see it being a love it or hate it kind of affair. Some of the enemy designs can get downright grisly at times. Other times, you're kicking the crap out of/headbutting an adorable deer. The art does a pretty good job of conveying the mood for the area. There's a lot of silly stuff and a lot of gory stuff. The stage design does leave a bit to be desired IMO. Often, it just comes down to a reskin of a generic mountain, and it all would look exactly the same if it weren't for variants in the palette. I don't know if this game engine has the capability for slopes, but it would help the game world look a lot better. Plus, there are a few unfortunate areas in which vital things like doorways are obscured by foreground elements (namely in the motorcycle race toward the end of the game, ramps and the doorway to exit are hidden by grass). Despite some disappointments which may just be incumbent on the engine, the game does look pretty darn alright. 4/5.

Sound: Man, this game has a trippy soundtrack. If you liked the weirdness of Earthbound's OST, you'll be right at home with  this one. In fact, it almost feels like you could switch the battle themes around and they'd work just as fine on each other's games. It's definitely one of those games where I'd suggest getting the OST if you're into it; you should play the game first just to see if you like it or not, of course. The sound design is pretty good as well; hits feel punchy, meaty stuff sounds juicy, and it's just all-around a good job on that front. Of course, there's no voice acting, so there's no point in going over that. Overall, a once again very good effort. 4/5.

Overall scores are: 8/10/4/4; cumulative score of 8.7/10. It's darker than what you'd expect from the trailer and lighter than what you'd expect from the intro. Definitely worth the purchase if you can stomach a sometimes very brutal game.

reviewText:
I've been wanting to review LISA since the day I got it, but I cannot for the life of me figure out how to describe it.

The story instantly grabbed me, so much so that I became completely obsessed and found the first free game pf the series and played it just to see... more of this world. I wanted to find out more about who Lisa is, or more about the main character, Brad, because this game keeps a lot of things vague.

The world is a strange place. I can't describe it too much without spoiling, but it's a post-apocalyptic setting and you see some serious, sad, depraved, brutal ♥♥♥♥. You have to make some really hard choices.

But I think it's the presentation that ties it all together. The goofy art style and the writing make it absolutely hilarious at times. The characters, the animations, even the music... it's funny as hell.

So you have this dicotomy... an extremely serious overarching story, but moment to moment, it's funny, strange, disturbing, depressing, tragic, it's human. And that's just why I like it.

My fav game of 2014 and more people should play it.

reviewText:
LISA is the biggest breath of fresh air to modern gaming in a long time.
Before I begin, I would like to preface this by saying that I am not biased in any way. Though the developer of the game is on my friends list, I added him after learning of and playing LISA. Do not think that I have any ties to the game beyond having played it.

LISA is a story about Brad Armstrong, a single father of the last child on Earth. Our hero's quest begins when his daughter is kidnapped. During Brad's journey to save his daughter, he will encounter, battle against, and recruit many denizens of post-apocalyptia. There are over twenty unique followers, and party configuration will change depending on the player. The game allows much freedom in moral choice, survival, and friendship, and no two playthroughs are likely to be the same.

The moral choices in LISA are abrupt, intense, and weighty. Each choice forces the player to question himself, and just how far he is willing to go to survive. Would you hack off an arm to save a friend? How about two arms for your precious supplies? Again and again, the player will be forced into difficult ethical dilemmas, and the solution is often subjective.

Party perma-death is also a factor to consider when exploring LISA's vast and open world. Many enemies can instantly kill party members seemingly without warning, and it will take ingenuity and cunning to survive encounters. Scrounging for items and supplies can often be vital, though it isn't wise to stock them up for long periods of time, seeing as they could suddenly be snatched away by an angry biker.

The combat system is original and classic at the same time. Whilst combo moves are available to some characters, and status effects are a force to be reckoned with (unlike many other recent RPGs, I might note), the general feel of combat and the layout of battle is more like a throwback to Earthbound.

In fact, the entire aesthetic of LISA is essentially an unadulterated, mature version of Earthbound's. The humor is similar as well, with many objects and enemies spouting hillarious text that brilliantly juxtaposes against the disturbing, violent art and brutal, intense music.

If this doesn't interest you, than the story will. Whilst its concept is basic (and slightly cliched), the emotions and characters portrayed in the game are relatable and imaginative. When Brad suffers through drug withdrawal and immense pain to save the one he loves and wants to protect most, the player feels with him. This is the only game I have played to date where the player shares in the misery of his/her virtual counterpart.

This may all sound rather harsh, but it is made up for completely with the fun navigation and smooth combat. Finding secrets feels good, and destroying a group of enemies is satisfying. Combining moves to do ludicrous damage, and traversing chasms aboard a speedy bycicle, is enjoyable. LISA's fun is difficult to deconstruct, but it works.

The soundtrack is both unique and progressive, and it completely fits the atmosphere that the game so perfectly creates. The often chilling (and sometimes beautifully melancholy) audio tracks are unlike anything previously created. Tracks in the soundtrack often encorporate metallic clangs, haunting chorus, and retro beeps to create funky, catchy, and unforgettable beats that will stay with you long after the credits have rolled.

If I have one complaint, it's that there are some technical limitations of the RPG maker engine. But honestly, this game pushed the engine to a place that seemed unreachable, so minor technical faults can be forgiven.

LISA will likely make you cry, seethe, and pump your fist in joy (it certainly did that to me). It is an emotional rollercoaster that makes the player beg for more. It is a completely fresh, fun, and intelligent experience. It is an indie masterpiece.

I highly recommend that you pick LISA up right now. Set aside some time to play the game. Support the awesome developer that created this title. Do yourself a favor.

I hope that soon you, too, will have joy down in your heart.

-Mipple
