reviewText:
- LISA -  (Scroll to bottom for tl;dr)

This game is digusting. It is horrid. It is not pleasant, nor fun, or entertaining. but it is addictive. It's a drug.

LISA is my new favorite RPG, let alone one of my favorite games on steam, and it pierces your heart with a painful story, disturbing imagery, and emotionally manipulative sacrifices.

Setting

I wanted to start off with the setting since it is so orignal and so neccesary to the story; I just love how it is hidden from the store page but it is so original and fascinating.  LISA takes place in a world heavily inspired from Mad Max. The world has become an unihabitable wasteland, clans and barabarians roam the plains searching for blood - and worst of all, all female humans have gone extinct.

Story Setup

LISA starts off with a man named Brad Armstrong, who was traumatized by his sister Lisa's death and his abusive, drunk father, Marty Armstrong. Brad has resorted to the drug Joy to ease his emotional pain, but soon he finds something that would change the world forever; a baby. And not just a baby, but a baby girl. Brad raises the child under the name Buddy and keeps her a secret from the world. One day, after meeting Terry Hintz, Brad finds out that Buddy has run away and the whole world is after her.

Gameplay

LISA's gameplay isn't too unique, but it it still pretty fun to play. It's an RPG that is heavily inspired by Earthbound. Some people confuse it for a platformer, but it barely is a platformer. Some of the mechanics are quite unique to gaming, that can be a tassle to deal with. For example, one of my favorite mechanics is Joy Withdrawl in which Brad performs poorly in withdrawl, but if you don't give him Joy his withdrawl goes away and his addiction starts to diminish. On the other hand, if he gets Joy, he would perform significantly better than in withdrawl or stable, but his addiction becomes heavier and harder to handle since Joy isn't found around every corner.

Conclusion

LISA takes the cake for RPGs on Steam. Its emotional hardships and sacrifices make it ruin you, paired up with great humor that is often well-cued. Disturbing creatures, gory imagery, and lands crawling with perverts make this a diamond in the rough that doesn't get enough attention. Its soundtrack can be menacing, upbeat, or eerie. It can pair up perfectly at some point, but not at all points. I believe this is a  Must Buy  for all people who love RPGs, emotional stories, Mad Max fans, or all in between.


TL;DR: It's like Mad Max and Earthbound had a child, But the TWD games took it and raised it themselves.

reviewText:
I've been meaning to review LISA The Painful RPG for a while, but I felt like I couldn't do the game justice. Now that I've completed the game and extracted as much as I'm going to extract without resorting to a replay to watch the additional ending scenes, I feel it's about as good a time as any. (Steam also denied me from posting this review for something like a week, I've went through a handful of versions, so bare with me if it has any errors.)

Let me preface this review saying that I am an experienced JRPG player. Having both played and completed a large amount of them, both in my youth and in recent times, I feel that I can complete any game that decides to follow the format without much difficulty, although LISA does build upon the JRPG genre by adding its own flair to it, which might or might not remind you of Adventure games of old, such as those made by Sierra, as well as a 2D enviroment where you can go left and right, climb up as well as jump down cliffs (although be warned as falling damage does come into play and is even a fairly interesting and rewarding mechanic).

That said, LISA is a hard game. It will not hold your hand, and it won't think twice about killing the characters you've grown to love. It makes you think about your decisions, and every turn can be the difference between having your party wiped or a glorious victory - save-points being far apart enough that it can be a challenge - and if you want to keep your party intact through loading a previous save, you will likely have to replay content (especially if you've decided to play Pain Mode, the game's hard mode which only lets you save once per point, although the game does give you enough of them that it is not an issue.)

I've played Pain Mode the first time around, and I feel it is the way LISA is meant to be played -- it makes a game that is an already very memorable experience even more so. I recommend it if you're up to it, but you should be warned: it can become very annoying, very fast.

LISA's 'Mad Max'-ian post-apocalyptic world is well-written, full of character and color. It lives and breathes, and through it, the storyline conveyed bit by bit, keeping you guessing until the very end, although it can be cryptic at times, and it's a slow build. The gameplay will often take a backseat to storytelling, which can be a problem, but I was hooked by the story before I could care (this is more noticeable at the beginning of the game, where they set a lot of the ground for the story).

Speaking of character and color, LISA has tons of it. The landscapes while very simple, can be beautiful and moody, which is fairly hard to convey in a 2D game -- although most of the time you'll be looking at dusty mountains and cavern systems which can be a bit daunting at first. What shines most in LISA are the characters: There are tons, and so many of them interesting enough for you to want to know more about them and how they and the world came to be. It can almost be a problem, as they'll leave you wanting, and the game can be very lean on dialogue at times. Most characters will have plenty of lines, but some can join your party without as much as saying a word, and that's a shame.

Now, I've gotten pretty much everything I wanted to say out of the way, but I want to just take a moment just to appreciate the soundtrack. Oh, the soundtrack. It is, excuse the french, abso-♥♥♥♥ing-lutely incredible. I don't think I've ever been as moved by a game's soundtrack as I have by LISA's before. It adds so much to the game, and I don't think it'd be half of what it is without it -- it's comforting, creepy, upsetting, wacky, lovely and just straight-up badass. It can be anything the game needs it to be, and that's fantastic. It makes soundtracks the likes of Silent Hill 2 proud.

In the end, LISA knows how to pull your strings. It will annoy you, it will make you laugh, and it'll probably make you cry. It knows how to move you and break you, and knows how to build you back up. It is absolutely worth its asking price, and will leave you wanting for more if you do manage to complete it, and completing it? Now that's a hell of a journey.

reviewText:
It's hard to explain the appeal of LISA because it's something that's become better than the sum of its parts. The combination of tight, simple gameplay, excellent writing and varied encounters have created a deeply engaging world, and difficult choice and realistic consiquence excel the player engagement that much more, while never feeling frustrating or jarring. I like to compare LISA to Fallout 3 because along with the obvious comparisons like being a post-apocalyptic world with a variety of strange and scary inhabitants, all with their own motives and reactions to different scenarios, it's also a game where a large spread out world has been designed first, and a great story has been laid softly on top afterwards, which means players will get a lot more or less from the story and world based on what they put into it, and that works really well.

Highlights
One of the great things about LISA is the fact that the game is so simple that all the design elements are clearly assertainable and you can identify why the developer has chosen to do certain things, and what they've added to gameplay as a result. As well as a great players game it's also a reviewers dream.

There are honestly things that are mediocre here. Combat, for example, is fair, it adds a bit of strategy and works well, but I'd be lying if I said it hadn't been done better elsewhere. Platforming too, has some very well designed intuitive learning and progression moments, but otherwise isn't anything special or better than in stand alone competitors titles. But they all do their job pretty well, and they serve the core design principles which are where the meat of the game lies. The characters throughout the world are all unique, interesting and fun to interact with and the progression system is particularly well made because it doesn't rely on grinding, in fact it's nearly impossible to kill more than a couple of the same enemy types, and even those occurrances are rare. Instead, you progress by exploring and defeating everything in an area, which not only adds to your desire to explore and interact, but even rewards you with new items and party members.

Then there's the story, which has been dusted over the game afterwards, and while no means is easy to ignore, doesn't add as much as it would to any other game. This is because, regardless of what the story was going to be, the world and gameplay would serve it from the start and only the writing and art style would have needed to been changed. But the story fits well and when bolstered by the weight of realistic choice rather than the usual black and white Good/Bad system other games tend to have, brings out the desperate nature of this post-apocalyptic world full of horrible human nature. It forces you to invest emotionally into the game, and then to sacrifice to progress. It's often troubling and downright heartwrenching.

Mistakes
The majority of annoyances with this game come from its use of the RPG Maker engine, which both limit its capabilities and cause a few annoying problems. Cliffs, for example, are often very easy to walk off after entering a new screen area, text boxes can cut off text, etc.

There are also plenty of technical issues, particularly in early releases. Fortunately the developer is still extremely active and proactive, which serves the future of this game. There's also a legacy release which, while it has some issues, helps to reduce the scope of technical problems.

Recommendations
Available for £6.99/9.99€/$9.99 on Steam, and with a good 12 hour play time on the main story, this is a very fairly priced title and should probably be played by almost everyone at least once. Completionists and achievement hunters can expect at least another 6 or 7 hours of gameplay and the personal choices and alternative story approaches give this some great replay value too.

* Lisa The First" has a much more vague story and is still available for free[rpgmaker.net]

A truly amazing and painful RPG. I went into this not expecting so much but I was left very surprised. The game pulls you in from the start, you'll keep on asking yourself What will happen next?"

Story
Very hard to say much about the story without spoiling it. But your name's Brad and your journey is to find your adopted child "Buddy". Along your journey you'll meet interesting and just plain weird characters. The story in the game is very dark and grim. So don't expect to go into the game and see the same kinda story or humor like Undertale. This game does have humor though but it's quite different.

Gameplay
The game follows a turnbased combat
date:
but it works very well. the animations are interesting and the combat's nicely done. Every battle has some sort of soundtrack to it. There's a lot of walking back and forth and it's easy to miss something. So take your time and explore. You'll stumble upon different characters you can recruit as well. Up to 3 companions in your party during a fight. There is no limit on how many you can recruit so you can swap out a party member at bars if you wanna try someone different.

reviewText:
Highly recommended.A perfect example of a good indie game!

-Superb music, I purchased the soundtrack before acquiring the game.

reviewText:
***SPOILERS***
LISA is anti-feminist rhetoric in role-playing format, making the claim that that women are the root of all evil in man's heart and the ruin of brotherly cohesion.
The game takes place in a futuristic utopia where men live in solidarity (shirtless and balding) after a mysterious “flash” removes all females from known existence.  It isn't until the arrival of a female baby that murder, torture, and over-all chaos makes itself known once again for the peaceful tribes of men.  Evidence of this can be seen throughout the game as the main protagonist discovers the countless dead, causalities of a war brought on by the new presence of the “last female” and the hope for future survival she brings.  Additionally, the protagonist is witness to continual acts of betrayal and irrationality spurred by the drug-like effect women apparently have on –
lol, jk.  10/10  would have bought at full price.

reviewText: One of the best games I've played in some time. You start out as an ex-karate instructor with a very troubled past who finds a baby while he's out and about. The baby just so happens to be the last girl known to exist in the world, instead of telling everyone he keeps her a secret. One day the secret gets out and you must travel through a world of pain and perverts to get your adopted daughter back. The gameplay is extremely enjoyable, a lot like the game Earthbound. You have a huge variety of characters to help you throughout the game as well. The world is beautiful yet chaotic and the music goes with it perfectly. A lot of dark, dark humor in this one too that never fails to make me laugh. As time goes on and you figure out what exactly has been going on and who you are and who everyone else is, things get really depressing really fast. You are also given decisions that can involve your body parts, your allies, your daughter.....what will you sacrifice to get her back? This is what it feels lke to be a truly broken man.\n\n10/10  Don't lose too many body parts.

reviewText:
LISA is an RPG about regret, shame, and suffering. It combines tight writing to push painful moments and excellent comic timing to relieve that tension to produce a compelling narrative about failure, trauma, desperation, etc. But all that aside, it's also a very satisfying traditional RPG - the diversity of characters provides enormous flexibility in playstyle, the mechanics are complex enough to reward mastery while simple enough to be mastered. There's also plenty of side-quests, which add depth but aren't necessary to complete the game.

The setting is compelling enough that it'll itch at your mind for a while after you finish the game. I'm very much looking forward to the next game in the series.

Beating LISA took me about 13 hours of play-time, accounting for save-scumming. In terms of entertainment value per dollar, it's not unbeatable, but it's pretty good!

reviewText:
Pain, Sacrifice and loss.

Those are the three words that in my eyes are the theme of this game. If you are considering buying this game, get ready to ride the emotional rollercoaster that mostly goes downwards. When should you buy the game? When the following keywords interest you.

- Pokemon kinda battle system
- You like ♥♥♥♥ed up ♥♥♥♥
- You are not afraid to lose
- You want to experience an amazing but ♥♥♥♥ed up story
- You like getting jumpscares (YES, this game jumpedscared the ♥♥♥♥ out of me)
- You like games with RPG elements (buying weapons, gear, items & leveling up)
- You like games where choices matter
- You can endure the horrible, yet genius OST
- Around 12hours of game time (worth every SECOND)

LISA has been, hands down, one of the most emotional games I ever played. It was hard to get through in the start because of the complex" battle system (mostly because you are not familiar with it)
date: but the moment you understand it its addictive and fun. No grinding ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t
hoursPlayed: pain and tears. Get ready to lose EVERYTHING and only gain one thing: PAIN.\n\nP.S. THIS GAME IS NOT FOR THE FAINT OF HEART. Start the game on normal. Pain Mode is too complex and hard for a new player to get into."

reviewText:
Mad Max + Children of Men + Fist of the North Star + Earthbound = LISA.

This game is the best damng RPGmaker game out there, and  while its not saying much on its own,  dont let the game's 2D game world fool ya - it has tredemdous storytelling with surprisingly touching moments, set in the ♥♥♥♥ed up environments with bizarre and unique characters. The writing is top notch, balancing horror and humour with ease, it has quite engaging, turn-based gameplay, and a lot of secrets to find! Be sure to play it on normal difficulty though, cause the PAIN mode basically adds one quick scene at the end of the game,  and one throw-away location in one area. You're better off just watching it on youtube after you've finished playing the game. and the PAIN mode  is basically not worth playing at all, cause it makes the game too brutal to play.

The music is ♥♥♥♥ing sweet too. It's incredibly varied and unique,  you'll be downloading the soudntrack after beating the game in no time!

There are a couple of things I didnt like though:

1) - It gets a bit grindy, at the end, as the game becomes less focused on the story, and more focused on fighting incredibly tanky opponents.
2) - meaningless choices. you can get basically one ending, with minor variations, based on jusst wether onr not you've taken drugs, thus making your choices meaningless, I mean, I get how its supposed to work in-game world, but like, dont  give me the option to make meaningless choices, giving me the false pretense that I can make a difference, its lame
3) - you can just save abuse a few Random-Number-Generated encounters. Especially the ones where your party is involved...you'll see it for yourself.

Otherwise, it's an 9/10 game for me!

The DLC is another story though...

reviewText:
LISA is by the best game I have played for a long while. It's sad that Undertale had overshadowed this wonderful game because of it's massive popularity. Probably the reason why was because of it's dark story and humor. Not a lot of people can get behind LISA that easilly compared to undertale. Of course a lot of people would talk about how LISA would be misogynistic" (I'm looking at you tumblr) and how it has innapropriate humor.

LISA is only for people who can absorb a deep and dark story.

For starters
date:
this game takes place after it's prequel "LISA The First". Lisa The First shows the struggle with Lisa (Brad's sister) and her Father. Abuse. Abandonment. Neglect. Lisa suffers what Brad had suffered before he ran away. That's what was predicted. The timeline during LISA The First shows that Brad is absent during most of Lisa's childhood.

Follow by the current LISA The Painful.

Now it's not much but my prediction is that Buddy is Lisa's daughter
recommended: which whom Brad adopts.\n\nAfter that the story progresses through Brad's journey to find Buddy and rescue her from Olathe's perverts and freaks. The humor stands to difuse any depressing moments
hoursPlayed:
but maintains the constant beat of what is Brad's purpose throughtout the game.

The companions have there own charming personaility that makes you remember each and everyone one of them.

And the moments and events in the game is all humorous and quirky in their own way. That's the magic touch of the Dingaling.

The combat system is intuitive
voteText:
making you remember patterns of WASD to execute skills and while adding extra damage. It keeps you engaged rather than you sitting back and pressing a few buttons and wait a turn.

The more I play LISA the more I go deeper into it's own story making me want more of it.

Dingaling is the magic man and I'm feeling the magic.

-Terr Bear"

reviewText:
This review is sans-DLC, but I did read up on the meat of the DLC to see what I was missing out on.

**Vague spoilers below read at your own risk**

I think LISA had a ton of promise. With the bizarrely crafted world and well crafted, unsettling imagery the story could have come back around really tackled some serious issues; instead it skirted around the subtexts of abuse/addiction in favor of a juvenile madmax-ish mutant... whatever. Just because everyone feels like this game is the best thing ever isn't important.

So why the positive review? Well, the game captured my interest the entire way before letting me down. The unacceptably large number of characters you amass is not justified given there are 5 parts of he game with so-called grind spots". Each character is fun and unique but only a couple are really solid.

The world is huge and well-crafted. Each area looks great
date:
the character/monster artwork is on another level (even with the rediculous pervy angle they approached the game with).  The music is also charming and unique but highly experimental.  It does fit the game.

Combat is OK. The way the characters land on the enemies with their own flare for each attack was my favorite part. When the main character loses limbs combat aptly changes for him which was a fine detail. Also it was funny watching him ride a bike that way.

This game
hoursPlayed: was crafted to confuse and disorient. Mission accomplished. Each sub-area has a bunch of doors
voteText:
each going to other sub-areas and the player gets to stumble around trying to figure out where to go. It added a lot of time to an already lengthy RPG. The game is supposed to be thematically heavy but it could still be more... fun.  The entire game felt like a ♥♥♥♥ing chore to play.

While the first LISA game was about how abuse (be it sexual or physical) is inescapable and hanting. Even though it was over exaggerated and fantastic that game took place in reality.  I could see how that kind of trauma would scar a psyche.

This game is arguably about guilt
helpfulPercent: abuse
votesHelpful: addiction and trying to project those problems on another person who doesn't want to be helped.  So the fact this game is literally taken play in the apocolyypse is ♥♥♥♥ing rediculous.  Had it come back to the poor kid and possible offered insight as to why he took his mental journey
votesFunny: at least I could buy into that. If this game is really post-apocalyptic it really screws itself over as that is just too dumb to get behind. Too wacky. Too "omg pervert mens is everywhere
commentsCount:
shocking lol".

I did enjoy how the character's pre-apocolypse backgrounds/stories wove together by the end that much seemed deliberate but that was utilized the least of all the elements. The whole mutant angle was just dumb to me and didn't do the game any favors.

So

reviewText: This game is brillianlty written. LISA combines great humor and a good, dark, deep story into a great game. LISA touches on subjects such as: abuse, struggles of woman being used, the struggles of being a parent, drug addiction, and loss. LISA is about a man named Brad who loses his sister, was bullied as a child, and abused by his father. Not being able to grasp the loss of his sister, he resorts to using joy"(a drug thats suppose to make you happy) to try to forget about his sister's death. Brad also has a deep hate for his abusing father and can never forgive him for all the pain and suffering he has caused him. LISA can be a very funny game as it makes many great jokes
date: but at some points it turns serious and can probaby make your heart feel weak.\n\nLISA is a turn base RPG that make you want to play it over and over again after completing. One of the best parts of the game is that there is none to little amounts of having to grind to beat an enemy or boss. There are many varieties of characters you can run into in the game
recommended: my favorites being (DON'T LOOK IF YOU DON'T WANT TO KNOW ANY NAMES) Harvey Alibastor The Fishmen Lawyer
hoursPlayed: Queen Rodgers The Boss of The Prostitution Ring
voteText: and Fardy Hernandez The Sex Slave of the Men's Hair Club. Their are 30 companions (all being great chracters) that can join you on your adventure through the weird world of LISA. There are also choises in the game (pretty tough choices) that can change the gameplay of your character. The only complaint I have about this game is just having to reload your saves if you mess up because some save points can be pretty far from where you were
helpfulPercent: so make sure you save often.\n\nI truly love this game and I highly recommend it."

reviewText:
A guy asked me to get a bucket full of water to put out fire, Turned out it was gasoline and i ended up burning 8 orphans.

In a world where women have dissapeared, you play as Brad Armstrong a retired karate teacher with drug problem on a wasteland. One day, You suddenly met a baby out of nowhere. Turned out that baby is the last human female. You shelter her from the outside world yet she want to know about it, few years later someone kidnapped her and killed your friends. And the adventure begins.

Lisa has a lot of dark story and humor which is exactly my taste. The story is depressing and amazing at the same time, the character is naturally likeable, whether it's the main character or the companion that doesn't have that much dialogue overall. I usually don't like the kind of story that doesn't explain all the mystery, But Lisa's story is presented by subtlety that i don't mind it. It actually creates a lot of interesting theory about the game.

This game is made in rpg maker, where it doesn't have the option to make a side scrolling game, yet Dingaling did. Lisa is basically telling you that engine limitation means nothing. The gameplay itself is old school turn based rpg with unique touch on it. I personally enjoy it with the variety of skills that Brad and the companions have. The best part about it is that you don't need to grind at all. Dingaling is an amazing guy.

In the end, Lisa is an amazing rpg that combines good storytelling and gameplay.

YOU'RE TEARING ME APART LISA.

reviewText:
I smiled. I laughed. I cried.

LISA the painful; Absolutely incredible. An easy 10/10 for me. This game has a perfect amount of everything, moral conflicting choices, humor that doesn't weaken the plot, incredible characters and among the best written games I've ever played.

The game engine is RPG maker(Ace, I believe?), yet you wouldn't be able to tell first glance. The music and art are both absolutely amazing, and express themselves along the story side by side. You couldn't ask for higher emotional quality than this. The only actual negative thing I can say isn't even a bad quality of the game. This game is extremely potential to upset you if dark themes are much. A spoiler-free example is the main menu background, it's a girl hanging from a rope.

My absolute favorite quality in this game is something extremely unique. True consequence. You make your decisions, and you adapt to them as best as you can. They put your true morals at work and help you pave the way for Brad, our incredible yet broken.

LISA the joyful is an excellent follow-up to our ending in Painful. -Spoiler alert-

Playing as Buddy was something I craved for after completing Painful. I wanted her perspective, I wanted to see what she does, who she becomes. That, too, was expressed in the best possible way. If you love LISA like I do, you'll love Joyful.


LISA the first is a free RPG maker title this game branched off of. It's very unlike Painful/Joyful, but it's excellent for some backstory of several characters before LISA.

NOTE: Liking Undertale does not mean you will like this. They are entirely different games, so don't come expecting that.
voteText: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Lisa: The Painful  is a clear spiritual successor to Earthbound. It is built upon the the same foundation - deep rpg elements, quirky graphics, and self-referential humor. Yet Lisa's form is infinitely darker and nihilistic. This game earned my runner up for best games I played in 2015 for its ability to affect my emotions.

Narrative
Lisa: The Painful takes place in a world without women. In this void, men have taken up male prostition, murder and thievery to slake their lusts. You play as a troubled man named Brad. The discovery of a lone swaddled babe marks the beginning of his conflict - Brad has found the last girl in the world. After promising to protect her with his life, he hides her in his house and takes care of her with a few close friends for many years.  Tragedy strikes Brad when one of his friends abducts the girl and takes her away. Suddenly, Brad finds himself against this twisted world in an effort to save the one thing he truly cares about...  From the moment I started the game, until the moment it ended, I felt completely absorbed into the world of Lisa. At points I even felt abused. This is truly a painful game and something I would not recommend to everyone.

Gameplay
Lisa: The Painful is a 2D sidescroller with an rpg focus. Throughout your journey you will need to recruit different party members with varying abilities and powers. The gameplay feels natural, fun and intuitive. The developer has given you plenty of tools to customize your party orientation in whatever way you feel is best. However, where the gameplay truly shines is in the choices you will make.

Sensory
The graphics are simple, but used to effectively to create a powerful canvas of sorrow and despair. Blood is strewn around the world with a liberal hand and the entire visual is one of rampant destruction and anarchy. The style completely engrossed me. In addition, the musical score also complements the game perfectly. One of my favorite moments of the game is when I  was traveling through a decrepit town and entered a lone house. Inside I found a figure dressed with some sort of astronaut helmet dancing to a loud, moody song with disco lights shining frantically. The strange figure would not say anything to me so I left after enjoying the music with him for a moment. Later on, after I had explored more of the zone, I returned to the house to check on him. The music was still blaring but the sad creature was hanging lifeless from a rope attached to the ceiling.

Conclusion
Do not let the initial quirky presentation fool you: this game is entirely mature, entirely twisted, and entirely  hopeless .

reviewText: Lisa is a phenomenal RPG whose elements keep me pulled in to play more and more. Fantastic story, amazing music, exceptionally memorable characters, tons of varied party members, intense story-based choices that do in fact affect the game, and of course leveling up that ISN'T defined by the old fashioned tedium of grinding endlessly against the same random enemy.\n\nIf you want a game with a one-of-a-kind feel that defies expectations and goes against typical rpg cliches, then this is something HIGHLY worth playing.

reviewText:
What can I say? It is a solid turn based RPG that has no filler content/grinding. An amazing story about a father trying to redeem himself and rescue his adopted daughter who happens to be the last female in the world. Full of serious topics about dealing with drug abuse, depression, child abuse, sexual abuse but done in a somewhat comedic way to get people thinking without being preachy. Also while the story is simple and to the point, the world contains hidden bits of lore that helps build the story (similar to Dark Souls). I cant recommend this game enough, more thought has been put into this game than every Bethesda RPG ever and clocks over 8 hours and is so much more memorable. The only crime is there are too many party members so it can be hard to decide whom to use and level up, but there is a fantastic steam guide that solves that problem.

If you are a firm believer that video games are an art form, do yourself a favour and play this game.

Fox

reviewText: Man, the whole time I was playing this game, I wanted to write a review for it just yelling at people that this game demands to be played. Lisa is unlike any game you have ever played. This game has a story that will draw you in whether you want to be or not, it demands your attention. The story of Lisa is a heart wrenching experience that few games have come close to offering. The gameplay is stellar and the graphics although somewhat confusing initially, I had fallen in love with after about an hour of gameplay. This game has many characters and personalities you will come care about as your story through Lisa progresses, and the game is aware of this and will take advantage of such things. When games say you will have to make world changing desicions, I often find myself rolling my eyes, but Lisa has desicions that will really push you to the limit; Many of these you will not want to make at all. This is game is the epitome of what a small developor is capable of, all games should thrive to achieve what a game like Lisa has. this game is simple and straightforward on the surface, but once you start that journey into the world of Olathe, be prepared. Lisa is an outstanding game and I cannot recommend this enough. If you want a game with characters that will draw you in and a world that feels so real yet so surreal at the same time, Lisa is the answer.

reviewText: I really enjoy this game. It's balanced so the challenges are rarely trivial but never require grinding. Unfortunately, it's easy to get lost trying to figure out which way to go at crossroads.\n\nBut the biggest draw isn't the mechanics, it's the loving care and quirky humor in the game. Sometimes I'll admit I wish they focused a bit less on the pervert" subject but it doesn't overshadow the other things. Each charcter is unique and everyone of your many possible companions has their own fighting style. The game also features surprisingly deep and difficult moral choices. Instead of trying to make you weigh things emotionally
date: it makes you decide if losing a companion is worth keeping all your items or similar mechanical choices."

reviewText: Great game. The dark but comical tone is consistant throughout with a very good soundtrack to match. The decisions you're presented with feel significant as they directly impact on gameplay. And it has a good length for the price.\n\nIf you enjoyed Earthbound or enjoy jrpg's in general you can't really go wrong when buying this. Even if you're not a massive fan of the jrpg genre it's worth a go as there isn't much in the way of grinding and it isn't drawn out in any way. The battles are almost entirely hand placed and one time only affairs, and as a result the game feels well paced.

reviewText:
An influential game with a dark and depressing story. This game has made me cry many times and you forget that it is made in RPG Maker.

There is great character development and loads of replay value. Not to mention the community is very nice. The story is very unique and is worth analyzing.

The amount of gameplay you get out of this game is worth the price, unlike most games that cost more than the hours of gameplay you can get out of them.

There are a lot of things to find, so if you like finding secrets and analyzing a game's story, this is for you.

Have fun!

reviewText: The sad thing about LISA is that I really can't explain how great it is without spoiling some of the plot. At first glance LISA looks like another 'oh-so-wacky' indie retro cash-in, but the game goes so much deeper than that. Put together from the ground up by Dingaling, LISA tells the story of an aging Martial Artist, Brad, journeying through a post-apocalyptic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to rescue his adopted daughter who just so happens to be one of the only women left in the world. The gameplay isn't too special, but it's enough to set it apart from the rest of the RPGMaker swill flooding the internet. Reminiscent of Mother 3 and Mario and Luigi: Superstar Saga, you and your stable of buddies can unleash hell on enemies using guns, weapons, special techniques and, of course, martial arts combos chained together with your keyboard. When you aren't fighting to survive you're solving puzzles, getting into trouble, and making game-changing decisions that'll cost you an arm and a leg (and THEN some!).\nThe story, artstyle, and soundtrack (also made by Dingaling) add a metaphorical cherry to the already appealing cake. There's music to pump you up, music to freak you out, and music to feel the moment. Though it frequently juggles comedy and tragedy, LISA's plot tells one hell of a story in a way that hasn't been explored before. Sappy as it sounds, I think Lisa has one of the best stories I've seen in an indie game. I know that doesn't say much, but I guarantee this one will feel special to you.

reviewText:
Life is cruel and unfair and you´re just a loser trying to do what you believe is best, even if you´re terribly wrong or you´re a monster. This is the kind of statement Lisa makes from the start, and it´s a good thing, because less and less games deal with psychology, abuse, and moral dilemas in a smart manner and not corrupted by political correctness or lack of knowledge on this days. And with tons of tongue and cheeck humor on top of it.

The story is intriguing, complex and has several layers. The dialogue is absolutely weird when it has to, emotional when it has to and clever when it has to. The turn based combat system has variation, humor and a learning curve.

Listen, it´s not gonna be a pleasent ride, but is certainly one that leaves a mark. Specially recomended for people that loves Post-Apocaliptic settings and all the themed explotation on the despair and flaws of the humankind that goes hand to hand with the genre.

reviewText:
A comparison of two games about chasing around a kid in a bleak future:
In Fallout 4, you have unlimited choices as a vapid character who does anything they wants in a post-apocalypse where nothing matters and the only resulting tragedy is the death of good writing.
In LISA, you have no choice but to play a battered man on the brink of sanity and follow the dark and twisted passages of your rotting, disheveled mind coming to grips with a disgusting future that leads you to make horrible, unavoidable decisions.

If you want a memorable, uncomfortable experience that will leave you delighted and disturbed at the same time, play this game. It was clearly made with by someone with love and dedication to the player's experience... or maybe an A.I. just got ahold of Earthbound and Videodrome.

reviewText:
I may have only played an hour and a half, but for that short amount of time I felt that I needed to write a little review.

I bought this game when it was on Kickstarter. I didn't really understand what the game was supposed to be but it looked interesting so I backed it. This game has been sitting in my library since that day and I am actually disappointed that I waited this long to play it.

As simple as the game seems it is quite in depth with the story. Also, I am glad to see that there is plenty of violence and swearing in this game instead of the M" rated games today that really aren't that graphic. I honestly am so surprised on how great this game is. It is very enjoyable and gives a good laugh here and there with a great storyline. It pushes some boundaries I give it that. I am glad to see that a modern game has such an original feel to it. This is a game that I feel everyone should give a chance.

If you are butt hurt easily this game is not for you

reviewText:
Look,
It's
Simply
Awesome.

LISA is not going to be for everyone. It's extremely dark, morose and weird for the majority of gamers. It's unlike anything I've ever played, and that's why I like it. There's something compelling about this game that I can't quite put my finger on. Every character you come across is weird and unique, instantly memorable for both the right and wrong reasons. But that's the thing about LISA, there isn't a right or wrong way. You have to be selfless, selfish, heartless, sympathetic and apathetic.

The best game I've played that was created in RPG Maker.

reviewText:
Absolutely full of amazing jokes and gags but besides that it has some amazing decisions that actually impact your gameplay as you can get loads of companions for your party that can actually permanently disappear because of things like dying in battle, dying in russian roulette, being kidnapped or abandoning your party. While mostly being a hilarious game there are many depressing themes and situations that made me feel the same way The Last of Us made me feel at certain points. The combat system is really enjoyable, you press WASD in certain orders to do combos and a lot of moves have hilarious animations too (like Terry Hints falling over and sliding into enemies). There are just too many secrets dotted around the world and so many unique characters to unlock from a man sitting on a stool telling stories and firing a lazer from his finger, to a bra and thong wearing bearded man with beautiful blonde locks who suffers from drug withdrawal. The last moments of the game were really painful to play through as I really felt my heart breaking every time I pushed Brad towards his final goal.
I sit here having finished the game feeling so guilty.
9/10
The only improvement that could be made is including button prompts during combos for controllers (XYAB instead of WASD)

reviewText:
Sweet lemon tea.

So, I figured I would rewrite my review since I've played through the game a few times now and have since bought the game for a few friends of mine. I have to say that Lisa the Painful is one of the few games that have struck a strange cord for me. I haven't enjoyed a game this much in quite awhile to be honest and with the recent release of Lisa the Joyful, only continued the journey for that much longer.

To keep it brief, the whole series itself has a great but exceptionally dark story, granted it has great balance with the simple but loveable characters and side stories you can partake in so it isn't such a sob fest the entire way through. That being said though, Lisa the Painful has a great story, awesome characters and overall decent replay value. You can even get added content in Pain mode I've found which is pretty awesome. I really do hope there will be more content for this game.

Lisa the First was a rough play but Lisa the Painful and Joyful have just the right mixture of elements to make up for it.

Stickin' to my original note: Joyless or bust.

helpfulPercent: honestly. You think you're safe to have a rest in this little tent a stranger so generously offered to you? Think again! A multitude of things might happen - you might get beaten
votesFunny: or a secret admirer might leave you a present. Decided to take a break under the starlit sky
commentsCount: after that one difficult fight? Well
column16: I hope you'll be glad to hear that one of your comrades got kidnapped for ransom. What will you do now? Pay the ransom? Or abandon your battle brother to the tides of destiny? It's all up to you.\n\nThis game
column17: while unforgiving in some aspects
column18: almost always gives you a choice. (Some of these so-called "roadblocks" can be a bit disheartening
column19: but they add to the overall plot quite nicely) Each area is unique and filled with a different cast of characters! Some depressed
column20: some angry and aggresive
column21: some down-right weird and perverted. While some recruitable characters do not have a lot of dialogue tied to them
column22: they're all unique in their own way
column23: with a little backstory behind each of them.\n\nExploration is always rewarded. Of course
column24: it depends on your definition of "reward" - a worthy enemy to test your mettle against
column25: or perhaps a hidden treasure in one of the darkest recesses of a cave? Who knows
column26: you might discover something you'd never have expected to find! It's just so pleasant to see a lot of small
column27: intricate details dotted around the different locations.\n\nThis game also gives off a very nice Earthbound-esque vibe - from the characters and the presentation of the areas
column28: down to the music. While the soundtrack is probably not something you'd listen to on any given regular day
column29: it adds to the game's atmosphere incredibly well.\n\nSo
column31: don't be afraid! Put on your time-worn poncho
column32: gather your most trusted allies and embark on a painful quest of self-discovery

reviewText:
Oh hello there! My name is Nern. I’m considered the greatest historian of our time… I’ve gathered a wealth of knowledge about Olathe and what happened… Many tales… Would you like to hear?
>Yes I totally care
> Booooring.
Hmmm. I wish you were more enthusiastic… Oh well I’ll tell you anyway. Let’s see… Oh right! It all started with what I like to call THE FLASH. I was sitting with my wife, god rest her soul, sipping on sweet lemon tea. I believe it was homemade by my sweet wife, God rest her soul. Or wait… maybe she bought it at the store in a bottle . You know, like a plastic bottle?  Well hold on now, that would be ridiculous to buy a bottle of sweet lemon tea, then transfer the contents into a glass. Why not just drink it from the bottle? I guess maube so she could put ice in the glass? But then again making tea homemade would be just as time consiming if not more! That sneaky ♥♥♥♥♥… anyway I’ll save that story for later! So, I’m sitting on my porch drinking sweet lemon tea. From a glass of course ho ho! When suddenly… A great strangeness fills my body… something was wrong… I’ve lived many years, and I’ve never felt something like this before. Do you know what it was? … Yup! It was my rocking chair! That son of a gun stopped rocking! so I look down and realized a little rock had gotten caught beneath my rocking chair! A rock under my rocking chair! What a day! I decided it was time for bed, I had a little bit too much excitement for one day! Hoho! I slid into my jammies, brushed my teeth, and said my prayers. As I was climbing into bed I noticed my wife, god rest her soul, brushing her hair in the bathroom. As I peered across the hall my body swelled with emotion… “Why can’t I be married to an attractive woman?” “Is it me?” “my money?” I’m a tall guy, I workout forty minutes a week… Is that not enough? Now my neighbor at the time, Tom Forknight, was very short. His wife Karen Forknight-Plateburger. Yeah one of THOSE women. Well, she was more attractive than my wife, i’d say she was a soft six, whereas my wife was a hard four. What’s the deal? I thought women liked tall men? Why was Karen with him? … Anyway my horse of a wife, god rest her soul, crawls into bed next to me. She decided to leave the beside light on so she could read her book. It was one of her romance novels again.. Give me a break… As if I don’t already feel inadequate enough… Not only do I have to compete with Tom, Now I have to deal with these fictional hunks! Aye Yai Yai! At this point I had suppressed the urges of intimacy, I rolled over and tried to sleep. Her bedside light was only of minor annoyance. I was able to drift off.. Then I woke up to a big flash of light. That’s about it.

I can tell by the way you’re walking away that you don’t want to leave… If you really want to hear another story I’ll tell you
.
Once upon a hot summer night. Sometime in July. … Was it July? My local grocery store sell really good eggs in July. I don’t know why. Do chickens operate better in heat? Fireworks maybe? I don’t know I don’t want to get off topic. Point is, the eggs that summer were marvelous! Anyway, My wife and I, god rest her soul, went to a BBQ that night. It was held at Dale Spooner’s house, well his backyard… Conny Spooner doesn’t like people in her home, I think she’s just an uptight ♥♥♥♥♥. So at this BBQ I see none other than… that’s right, Tom Forknight...Now earlier in the day my wife, God rest her soul, had made potato salad for the BBQ. Personally I hate potato salad, I’m more of a mashed kind of fellow. Hoho! So I sat in the TV room avoiding her till the BBQ. Once we were at the party I made sure to distance myself from my dumb potato ♥♥♥♥♥ wife, God rest her soul, I just didnt want anyone to think I would associate myself with someone that would bring a potato salad! Anyway Tom and his above mediocre wife were akready there. And get this, They brought a fruit salad! With Whipped Cream! The nerve of those Forknights! Needless to say I gave my wife, God rest her soul, a couple of choice words! About whipped cream! Versus Potato Salad! Son of a ♥♥♥♥♥! A real Tongue Lashing!

Well Hello again! Funny seeing you here! What are ya following me or something? Hoho! Anyway… I often wonder what all happened here. What was that big flash? Why are we here? Even our day and night cycle is odd… Sometimes days last ages and nights come rarely. And these clouds… so strange… What’s happened to our earth? … Oh well. Enough of that boring stuff. I once had a real kooky day at the doctor’s office! I was in the waiting room reading a teen magazine. Normally I don’t indulge myself in adolescent publications, but I couldn’t resist! I had recently heard the new artist on the radio, Ulysess Utensils! She’s some young woman maybe a boy, I don’t know. Either way that child can really grasp my attention! So I’m reading this magazine because I saw Ulysess on the cover. I still wasn’t able to identify if it was a man or woman. But as I’m reading I notice something on the ceiling… I look up to see that there is some water damage. You’d think a doctor would make enough money to maintain his office… I guess he cares more about his cool jetskis than his patient’s comfort… And assumably big house and hard bodied wife.               I wish my wife was like that…                       Big ol’
Melons…           Just then a droplet of water falls from the ceiling! My eyes trail it all the way down to the ground! I stared at the floor for sometime watching the carpet absorb the water.  Suddenly my attention is caught by a small child. The child was glaring directly at me. I saw the devil beneath his eyes! I got nervouse and quickly stared directly at my feet as not to aggrovate the child. And that’s when I realized something…    I was wearing two different kinds of socks! Golly I’m all revved up after these thrilling exchanges! To be fair you’re a bit of a bore but beggars can’t be choosers! I think I’ll stick around. I’ve got many a tale to tell!
------------------------------- Nern Guan Joined your Party------------------------------------

reviewText:
Already looks like a game worth playing.

1.8 Hours played, I won't give spoilers but feel free to add for tips/advice.

Story is interesting, gameplay isn't like a Zubat cave. It's a good RPG and allows you to leave it from time to time if you're as busy as I am.

Mechanics are interesting, I love to speculate new things Brad and his crew picks up on their journey. Characters can be annoying but I love them and they do have different aspects to offer in fighting, none of them have been the same. I personally would recommend the combat system, it's fun, not too complicated, but not easy and pretty engaging especially when you get a new crew member.

So far I have made a couple decisions in the game playing it how I want to play it and I enjoy it, the game starts out engaging and interactive and I can already tell it'll be that way for the whole road. Updates to be made in the future. Good job Dingaling, I back this 100%.

2+ hours played

Found a secret place :}, map explorations FTW.

reviewText:
This game is a decent length role playing game (If you play it more than once for the sake of making alternate choices or total completion) that I would honestly catagorize under horror. There are plenty of disturbing things to see if that is your sort of thing. The game also seems to love messing with you in every way it possibly can, which may be a turn off for others. People will try to sell you useless crap, assault you, kill you, cut your limbs off, force you to watch your friends kill themselves... Then sometimes it will mess with you simply by having you climb up a long rope, only to very literally find a giant middle finger waiting at the top and nothing else. Or having some random guy fart on your main characters face after sleeping. A lot of this is based on luck and not scripted. Truth be told, it is a bit annoying in this regard. One can find it to be amusing, but others may just sigh as they find themselves being screwed over in a way which forces them to restart from the last save if they want to continue, knowing that they may have to restart again if they are unlucky.

Those are the negatives. If you're willing to put up with that, I can't suggest this game strongly enough if you want an insane, dark, well told story presented in the form of a typical JRPG.

There is also continuity between this game and another called Lisa: The first. It is free to play and can give you some general backstory information and help you solve some of the puzzles that is the story of this game.

In short: This game is definately worth playing if you like grimdark and can tolerate the game being an ♥♥♥ sometimes.

Made revisions after playing the game to 100%
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: LISA is an impressive balancing act, teetering on a razor sharp line between comedy and horror, and yet it works. It never feels like it's trying to make light of the world; that's just how things are. And the way things are is, well, crushing. No matter how light-hearted the game may get, there's always this opressive fog looming over everything; with every element contributing to this depressive atmosphere. From the brutal gameplay and how quickly you can (permanently) lose party members to the many songs and their themes.\n\nIt's a good deal more disturbing than a good many of horror games I've played, and I don't think that I'll forget it any time soon.

reviewText: LISA: The Painful RPG is the kind of game that doesn’t come along often. It’s wonderfully weird and as dark as it is humorous and endearing. Sporting a kickin’ soundtrack as well, LISA is all around a game that a lot of care went into crafting, and despite how unforgiving it can be it’s hard to not recommend this game (especially since it only costs $10 on Steam). Filled to the brim with secrets and easter eggs, there’s some good replay value as well. Just buy it, man.\n

reviewText:
LISA is most definitely my GOTY 2014. And I've played a lot of games this past year. Everything about it is amazing to experience, from the music to the gameplay, to the characters, to the story.

When you first start, the introductory story segment draws you in to the point where, when the gameplay was being introduced, I worried it'd suck, since the story was so good. It didn't. The gameplay's fun as ♥♥♥♥. The battles are challenging, especially so on Pain mode (the hardest difficulty), and the events of the game that can seperate you from your most valued party members are brutal. By the way, those events aren't scripted. Olen can get his head bitten off, or Nern can be kidnapped. Or vice versa. Really, no one is safe. Be ready to lose those you value most.

The battles run a little like the Mother/Earthbound games. The characters in your party lack the typical class of Fighter/Mage/Rogue, and instead have abilities based off their actual character. For instance, Nern, a really chatty fellow, has abilities that involve around talking. Telling Ghost Stories to spook your enemies into not acting-- insulting them to make them go berserk. Discussing health with an ally to recover HP.
These quirks help flesh out these characters, and you'll quickly find yourself favoriting some over others, based off their skillset/character setup.
As for the diversity of these characters-- there are around 35, if I remember correctly, each with skills unique to themselves. There can be some similarities between them, but nothing that makes you think they're a copy of another character. Roles can overlap, though this isn't a problem due to how sparesly that occurs, and how many options you have for your party.
Recruiting these characters can be as simple as buying them a drink, to holding their lover hostage so they join you.

The story. Holy ♥♥♥♥ the story. Depending on the choices you make, you'll either feel awful about yourself, or you'll feel oppressed by everything around you. I won't say how (it'll be obvious when you encounter it), but it's possible to complete the game with no arms-- just kicking, biting, headbutting, and tackling everything in your way. The story is one of the best in any game I've ever played. I'll just leave it at that. The atmosphere while playing reminds me of the tense darkness, and the maddening overlay that Hotline Miami has. That depressed, insane, vibe. The music also is reminiscent of Hotline Miami, and fits the game's style great.

I've already bought this game for two people, and I'll probably buy more copies for others. It's a shame this game isn't more well known, it's amazing. For 10$, it's a steal. I completed the game in 13 hours on the painful mode, and I still didn't do everything I could've. About to start my second run after I finish this review.

Buy it.

reviewText:
Before you read this review a few things must be taken into consideration:
I did not purchase this game. A very kind individual gifted me this game for the sole purpose that I play it, give it an honest review, and spread the word of its existence if I enjoyed it.

I haven't finished the game as of yet. I'm doing my best to experience every nook and cranny this game has to offer. If my opinion of the game changes by the end I will edit this review accordingly.

I don't care for most turn based rpgs so keep in mind this is from that point of view. I think the combat in most of them is downright boring as all hell unless it's got a unique gameplay mechanic or appealing visuals. *wink* if you catch my drift *wink*
GAMEPLAY
Movement in this game is very limited, it can become a pain in the ♥♥♥ to travel between towns or landmarks sometimes. Somehow I can't help but feel that this is intentional and really adds to the feeling of despair, hopelessness, and even the comedic value of the games atmosphere. The only reason I think this, is because later they give you the means for traveling between areas yet not towns. The long trekking really builds up whatever emotion is supposed to be conveyed at the end. Don't get me wrong though, it's still a pain in the ♥♥♥.

Combat in this game is very similar to that of other turn based rpgs. You got your items, skills, hp, mp, exp, etc. The game mixes it up by giving you a combo system that your character can use instead of using skills that take up your power, making it feel very interactive. But what actually makes me enjoy the combat the most in this game as apposed to others is the attack animations of your gang. It never gets old watching your bros ram, shoot, moon, or run over your enemies and making them cry. The dialogue of you posse after battles alone is worth fighting for. You can have 3 other jabronis besides you in a posse at a time. All the other jabronis that you aren't using stay in an inventory that you can access at certain wanted posters. You can heal ya bois by either using items for sleeping at a camp. This game is mostly about making choices and the outcome will mostly be negative in some some way. Even if you feel like you got away unscathed you will have still lost something whether you deemed it valuable or not.

SOUND DESIGN
The soundtrack and SFX in LISA really add to the its atmosphere. I really feel a sense of dread when I get into combat with an abomination and hear music that perfectly matches the absolutely horrifying appearance of the thing in front of me. LISA's music (and sometimes even lack there of) exceedingly contributes to how you will feel while playing it. It really plays up what's happening and is easily one of my favorite parts of the game.

GRAPHICS
The artstyle is like Road Warrior meets Earthbound and it is kept consistently throughout. I personally enjoy the artstyle and color palette of the game but you can determine that for yourself by watching the trailer on the store page.

OVERALL
Everything about this game is so well crafted, from the story and dialogue to the characters and gameplay. I hope some day this hidden indie gem finally gets the attention it deserves. This game will tear your heart out with its tragedy and sew it back together with its wonderfully dark humor. LISA provides players with a suffering that can only be quelled through the joy of playing the game.

10 sweet lemon teabags/10

reviewText:
A terrific, yet extremely depressing game that will make you feel terrible by the time you're done playing it, guaranteed. It's best to play this blindly and not look at any spoilers, since it's a very story-heavy game.

There is an unfortunate stigma attached to the program with which it was used to make this game (RPG Maker). Ignore that stigma, since this is NOT by any means your average, cheap, cut-and-paste RPG Maker game that so many have made (myself included.)

Just be prepared for a ton of feels. You have been warned.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Really good game. Tells a fairly sad and deppressing story with a sad and depressing world in a completely joking and sarcastic tone. The RPG gameplay itself is a bit dull and can seem a little grindy, but I think it's a flaw you can look past hopefully. The world is fun to explore and lets you piece together the story yourself for the most part. You will generally actually feel bad for the character/characters too probably.

It's really just a well written story that doesn't take itself too seriously most of the time. Example being, in one scene you have to choose to either cut off your arm or kill a party member. Then directly after that, you find a guy who is pooping, but a spider scares him and touches his butt.

the DLC is much more linear and not quite as good as the original, but it wraps things up nicely and leaves the story feeling finished at least. Get that one on a sale I'd say

i like it a lot thx ilu

reviewText: what can i say about this game that hasn't already been said before? i've finished both The Painful and The Joyful and all i can say to express myself is WOW. the game is fantastic, it's been said numerous times that the story is fantastic but that feels like an understatement. it's gritty, sad and unique. the gameplay is awesome and the battles are fun, sometimes very challenging so beating a boss or a random encounter of baddies is extremely rewarding. one of the most memorable parts of this game for me is the soundtrack. the songs are fun, very random and oddly catchy. for anybody looking for a fun story driven game then this is for you. the entire experience is one you won't forget 20/10

The only reason I think this, is because later they give you the means for traveling between areas yet not towns. The long trekking really builds up whatever emotion is supposed to be conveyed at the end. Don't get me wrong though, it's still a pain in the ♥♥♥.

Combat in this game is very similar to that of other turn based rpgs. You got your items, skills, hp, mp, exp, etc. The game mixes it up by giving you a combo system that your character can use instead of using skills that take up your power, making it feel very interactive. But what actually makes me enjoy the combat the most in this game as apposed to others is the attack animations of your gang. It never gets old watching your bros ram, shoot, moon, or run over your enemies and making them cry. The dialogue of you posse after battles alone is worth fighting for. You can have 3 other jabronis besides you in a posse at a time. All the other jabronis that you aren't using stay in an inventory that you can access at certain wanted posters. You can heal ya bois by either using items for sleeping at a camp. This game is mostly about making choices and the outcome will mostly be negative in some some way. Even if you feel like you got away unscathed you will have still lost something whether you deemed it valuable or not.

SOUND DESIGN
The soundtrack and SFX in LISA really add to the its atmosphere. I really feel a sense of dread when I get into combat with an abomination and hear music that perfectly matches the absolutely horrifying appearance of the thing in front of me. LISA's music (and sometimes even lack there of) exceedingly contributes to how you will feel while playing it. It really plays up what's happening and is easily one of my favorite parts of the game.

GRAPHICS
The artstyle is like Road Warrior meets Earthbound and it is kept consistently throughout. I personally enjoy the artstyle and color palette of the game but you can determine that for yourself by watching the trailer on the store page.

OVERALL
Everything about this game is so well crafted, from the story and dialogue to the characters and gameplay. I hope some day this hidden indie gem finally gets the attention it deserves. This game will tear your heart out with its tragedy and sew it back together with its wonderfully dark humor. LISA provides players with a suffering that can only be quelled through the joy of playing the game.

10 sweet lemon teabags/10

reviewText:
LISA has...changed me.

I use to be a normal teenage girl before I was sucked into the sticky black tar of Joy that is this game.
I was encased in it.
Molded by it.
Until I emerged a man...

...A very lonely and perverted man who would only wear shirts that ended above my nipples...

But a man never the less!
I don't remember much of my old life but, to some degree, I feel whole.

For those of you who don't think of that as reason enough to also get in the tar, you're the one who is really missing out.

LISA has to be one of the best RPGs on the market. Everything that was put into this works so well together to make an experience that is worth playing at least once (even if there is more than enough reason to play multiple times).

The game's art and soundtrack are amazing and go hand in hand. Both are relatively weird but so enjoyable that you want to keep going just to see what's next.
The World the devs made is awesome and filled with amazingly enjoyable characters, especially the party members. Each of them has their own distinct appeal and abilities that make them all so wonderful and distinct. Some highlights include (SPOILER)  The Lord of the tutorial, a lovably annoying historian, and the most badass drag queen. . These characters, and more, you will meet and find the ones you appreciate the most.
The story is also one of the best I've seen. Without going into too much detail, it is a rollercoaster. It can range from light hearted happy moments to AHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH WTF and everything in-between. There is never a dull moment in the story of The Brad. And as I'm typing this, I'm trying to think of one moment I'd share with someone who was reading this, and debating if they wanted this game, but I can't think of any that wouldn't be better seen through playing the game.

So please, get this game for yourself. It is really worth every cent. If you even have a slight interest in RPGs, great stories, or dark humor, this game is for you.
Do it for Uncle Razu.

reviewText:
An amazing experience but in my opinion, pain mode is detrimental to the experience as a whole.

I love rpgs and I love good stories and Lisa exceeded at both in the first 20 minutes of gameplay. This game brings to the table a plentitude of funny and original characters, amazing soundtrack and very unique bosses, locations and jokes. The game made me laugh, cry, unnerved and scared and the transition between each emotions was executed with extreme precision and skill. I praise the maker of this magnificent game.

I chose Pain mode as I wanted to extra bits of content as well as the extra challenge with the new bosses and luckily, it wasn't impossible for my first playthrough but caused me a lot of distress as I found myself restarting often because of a silly mistake but I didn't mind that as the pain it caused me was well received. It is the painful rpg after all. What bothered me though is the fact that you don't get a lot of room to test characters and build your dream team, especially if they are under-leveled. The 3 first characters that I got in my game were the same three I kept during the whole game as I could not level up the newer and cooler characters as I knew the lack of save points and the potential game over right around the corner could wipe away hours of gameplay.

In my opinion, if you want to truly enjoy your experience and get to choose the team you want, do not choose Pain Mode unless you want to feel true pain in which case, I invite you to do so. But otherwise, you aren't missing that much without Pain mode as the extra bosses, cutscene and dungeon don't bring much to the story and you can easily get the information online.

I highly recommend this awesome and painful game!

reviewText:
Crazy. Insane. Quirky. Super depressing with some black humor.

Preface: If you are going to play LISA, you should look up LISA The First. You do not necessarily have to play it, but just read up the story on it, even if it's creepy.

Now for this LISA: Go buy it. Further, make sure you buy LISA The Joyful as well, meant to be played after you complete the main game.

This game is one which is best played going in blind, so I do not want to say much about what happens. But if you are alright with witnessing some pretty terrible events and having to make some pretty terrible, screwed-up choices, then seriously get this game. Even if you are afraid of having to make bad choices, still try the game out - open yourself up and don't be afraid to give it a shot.

The game has its ups and downs, but the environment and story was just so strange yet organized in a way that it kept me focused and playing it all for a good long while. I never wanted to stop playing LISA despite what bad events kept occurring (exception: there is 1 single point in the game that is bad random number generation and really annoying).

The game is certainly not an easy one, especially because there are difficult RPG battles, which I did not know about when I first started it out. But I have more than enough experience with RPGs so I lived through it all. And if you play it right without wasting some items, you should have enough luck to make it through, or grind if you need to. Just read up on some of the guides.

But really, you should just give the game a shot - go in blind, and just push yourself through it. Make sure you get LISA The Joyful because you really need it to wrap up" some parts of the storyline more. In fact
date: LISA The Joyful turned out to be a great culminating point for everything.\n\nI got so connected to this game way beyond what I imagined. I got extremely angry at the characters
recommended: happy when certain obstacles were passed
hoursPlayed: and well
voteText: really sad when a ton of the bad events occurred.\n\nIt had me hooked from the beginning."

reviewText:
LISA is a great a great game with great humor, tough choices, better combat than in most final fantasy games, awesome music and great pixel graphics.

Combat functions very similiar to JRPG:s, only different things is that you can either use the skills straight out or you can combo them our self using WASD keys for more damage.

When not in combat the game goes on as a sideway scroller, thou you can only use jump if a platform is either slightly above or below you ( you cant jump because you are too dull and could lose a few pounds, according to the game ). Bike chances things as you can actually jump with it. You can also fast travel later on but wont spoil more about that.

Leveling also follows JRPG style you gain new skills as you level up and auto gain stats.
You might find items that you can use on character for them to learn new abilities or gain stats.

Exploration and seaching is the key. There are many hidden things and opportunities to be lost and found some of them are affected by the choices you make along the road.

Items and inventory use is very simple and has similiar inventory to JRPG:s. You use jerkys to heal and diet colas to get more sp. Joy is a drugg in this game it heals a lot and makes you joyfull ( buff ), thou be warned it causes addiction that lasts extremely long or longer. Resting can be done in campfires. Choose wisely wher you sleep as it might have dire consequenses even permanent ones. What happens while resting in a poor spot is determined by location, events and random.

There are many querky characters such as Terry the hint lord or The annoying guy. Some characters have to be hired some found. They all have different fighting styles and weapons along side with other gear.

I wont spoil more things so here are some...

Helpfull tips:

-The game is hard so expect to save often and prepare to lose party members, limbs and items.
Saving is done in points similiar to final fantasy series in this case crows, jus remeber to save in different slots as choises tend to haunt you later on.

-I have read that some had difficulties in what keys function, I think its simple:
Z for almost everything to interaction to picking up, cancel, etc
X for party screen
Up key + Z to jump up or down if platform present slightly above or below
WASD keys in combat combos
F6 for larger screen

-Dont trust anyone they all lie and are full of poo ( nicer word for what I meant  ).

-Many hidden things to discover you should try to search every corner and explore every route.

-Killin everyone is not always in your best interest and if you kill some one you will not see what happens to him later on.

-AGAIN REMEMBER TO SAVE OFTEN! and in different slots...

-Praise The Sun
