reviewText:
Lisa is a 2D RPG set after an apocalyptic event that destroyed all the females. We play as a drug addict named Brad that stumbles across a baby one day and to his surprise it is a girl. Brad, along with two friends decide to raise and protect that baby which they name “Buddy” to keep her safe from the outside world. As you can imagine things eventually go wrong, she is kidnapped and you are off to save her. One of the first things you may notice is that the game is locked in a 4:3 ration annoyingly enough and there is no way to stretch it. This game has a very strange sense of humor and nearly everyone you meet is completely insane, making it so you never know who is going to try to murder or rob you and who is friendly. Along your journey you will meet a ton of potential party members and be able to take up to three with you at any one time.

Combat is a pretty normal ordeal that has you slugging it out in a turn based duel with your foes. You will be able to pick from skills, items or a chance to escape from battle. It is a pretty typical system with one of the few undue things about it being a 5 button input when you select to attack that allows you to pull off special moves. You can pull off these moves by clicking on the skill menu as well so it is pretty pointless. Brad is a junkie addicted to a drug called joy so if you don't take some every once in a while you will have a withdrawal effect in combat that seriously cripples his ability to fight. Winning a battle can grant you a multitude of items like cigarettes to heal poison and magazines which is the currency for the game. If you have ever played an RPG there is nothing really all that different here other than how insanely weird this game is and deciding how much you value yourself over those fighting by your side.

The world of Lisa is as cruel and violent as it is weird making you have to make some pretty difficult decisions such as losing an arm making you lose your sweet hadouken skill as well as making you weaker or sacrificing a friend in your stead. It sounds like a hard decision but the companions in this game are so numerous and outlandishly insane that you'll be missing their ultimately replaceable skill set more than anything. It's never an easy decision to make however and trying to resist your captors can lead to more disastrous results. Losing tons of your party members is nearly unavoidable since even during non-scripted events they can get kidnapped and murdered. If they fall in battle you can simply go rest in an inn or by a campfire to heal them. Resting by random campfires is as very risky gamble with someone possibly getting kidnapped, your party being poisoned by a random spider, your stuff can get stolen and much more I'm sure but at that point I'd sooner walk all the way back to the inn than find out what other nasty surprises lay in wait.

It is no doubt a very dark game that is masked by its weird “humor”. I'm hesitant to call it humor since very rarely is it funny and relies more on insane randomness that will have you wondering what “just happened?” from beginning to end. Nothing seems to make a lick of sense and you start questioning if it is real or if it's a hallucination in Brad's drug filled mind. In that regard Lisa does an excellent job as you will never have enough time to plant your feet on the ground and feel like you understand this world. It's not an easy game either, if you have been robbed of all your belongings don't expect it to pull back any punches, your decisions have consequences and even the snowmen want to kill you. Yes there are snowmen in the desert and that may be one of the least weird things about this title. To save the game you must find a crow and if you pick hard mode in the beginning of the game it will explode once used. Hard mode really should not be attempted your first time playing Lisa since it is difficult and unfair to begin with.

When not in combat you are free to explore the environments which are pretty open ended though you ultimately have to visit most locations nonetheless. There are no maps, the level design is really confusing and there are no reminders to what you are meant to do so it's best to make time for when you play Lisa as playing it a bit one day and a bit another day can easily get confusing. You can jump up small ledges and objects giving it a bit more variety than simply walking left or right. Rather early in the game you will unlock a bike that allows you to move much faster and jump from higher locations without taking damage. Be very careful though as there are endless pits all over the place and you can easily ride right into your doom if you are not paying attention. Riding a small red bike too fast was the lead cause of death for me in a world full of violent psychopaths as sad as that may sound.

This game only features few random battles in certain caves and in tall grass. You can grind for magazines and items though it will take a very long time as well as making it sting much worse when you get robbed again. Scattered around the world are stores, bars and vendors where you can exchange your magazines for their services. A risky thing to purchase is equipment for your party since they die off so rapidly, making them a potentially really bad investments no matter how much it may help you out in combat. Lisa is all about potential risk and rewards. The strange thing is that I've never felt I was having fun playing this game but for some reason felt compelled to keep going. It can be frustrating to be so helpless as you are repeatedly mugged, beaten and humiliated but it is a far more effective method of making you feel like the world is dangerous instead of simply being told it is, grind a bit and becoming the unstoppable king of the world like in most other RPGs these days. Sadly Brad's motivation of rescuing Buddy is something we the player most likely will not care about since she does not say a single thing before being kidnapped and all we had to base her character around is a short cutscene.

There is no voice acting and everything is told via text. Strangely enough the text is slightly cut off in the corners of the speech bubbles and while it's nothing gamebreaking it never stopped being annoying. Graphics are nothing special but it does its job decently to convey all the weird or disturbing things like mutants, someone's head being bashed in and random rave parties. The real star of the show here has got to be the great soundtrack. It is both weird and catchy enough to make you stay in an area for a bit longer just to listen to it. Lisa is not a title I'd recommend for those that like to feel in control or even understand what is going on while playing video games but for those that can enjoy a game that kicks them when they are down and can handle dark humor. As twisted as this game is it always has an almost surreal type of wackiness such as your childhood bully riding around on a small deer and proceeds to murder your friend or a random body building club with people bench pressing refrigerators. While not a fun game it is without a doubt a very strange and brutal experience that you will not likely find anywhere else.

reviewText:
It's not often I write Steam reviews (this is my first), but this game really struck a chord with me.

Story: It's hard to get too detailed without spoiling, but the basic premise is that the characters are in a post-apocalyptic setting in which only men are left alive (it's unknown what happened to the females, at least far as the player sees), yet the main character, Brad, came across a young baby who just so happens to be female, so he takes her in to raise her and protect her from the outside world. As you may expect, a human is a difficult secret to hide; she eventually gets kidnapped, so Brad goes in search for her and the story starts.

The main, overarching story is told a bit slower, really coming more to the forefront at the end of each hub area, but it's very interesting when it does. There exploration in between the story segments is still extremely interesting though, since it's filled with plenty of events and things to see, many are very quirky and humorous (and the humor is excellent, very reminiscent of Earthbound), though some things can be pretty unsettling (the game constantly walks a fine line between these two distinct types of emotion, and pulls it off surprisingly well). There's also the backstory of the game world and main character, which are also hinted at in various ways as you explore many of the areas, so even between the bigger story sections, there's still a lot to hold your attention and get you continually more interested and invested in the game world and characters.

True to the game's tagline of The Painful RPG"

reviewText:
I don't usually buy games (or write reviews whatsoever) right of the bat, but when I took a look at LISA's trailer I knew something good was going on. Back then didn't know I just got myself GOTY 2014 (and a very high standards for 2015 as well).

I just finished LISA and if you like games with great story, great characters, easy mechanics and gameplay yet game itself still being challenging, you definitely should give it at least a try. Halfway playthrough I knew I would love the game and after this review I'm going to lauch a new run. Game appearently has two very different difficulties, and supporting characters and team variations enough for several playthroughs.

So what's bad about this game? There has to be something, right? If I have to bring some bad sides up, I'd say that this game is challenging for your spirit if you usually like to play nice dude like I do. With LISA, you just can't. I also would love a longer story, now that it's once actually VERY GOOD. Other than that, I can't really give you any complaints. The soundtrack is a beast, (I'm personally a big fan of retro-graphics, so) it looks very neat and gameplay is easy enough. Oh, and did I mention that the story is good?

Thank you, Dingaling/Jason, for this piece of soul-crushing art. It deserves lots of attention.

reviewText:
This is an incredible game that reminded me what it was I loved most about video games. It put me in Brad's shoes. I was the man that lived in this world. I made the decisions. I felt the emotions and paid the consequences for my bad choices. There might have been a few moments in the game that I couldn't figure out and maybe once or twice I came across a section of the game that was a big buggy (only about one or two minutes of game play) but other than that, this game was as close to perfect as you can get. The humor of this game made me really laugh. On the other hand, some of the choices in this game really effected me emotionally. I'm very glad that I played this game and would recommend it to anyone who really wants to get lost in a deeply emotional, very funny, very ♥♥♥♥ed up game. This game isn't for the kiddies. It's very dark and very disturbing.

I just finished this game a few minutes ago and I can't get over what just happened.

The people who made this game should be really proud of what they've made. It's art. It's beautiful. It's funny. The music is amazing and plentiful (there's about 90 songs). GG Dingaling and GG Widdly 2 Diddly. ♥♥♥♥ing amazing.

reviewText:
Best game of 2015

No other game this year has left me with the level of anxiety, fear to play on or sheer disappointment in myself than this experience. These are not the usual emotions people seek from a videogame as many use the medium for escapism from these exact things. However few games offer anything like the ruthless, relentless story and gameplay as presented here; making it an unforgettable play for my time spent in its world.

Undertale and Gods will be watching offer similar experiences, but neither left me as shell-shocked as Lisa.

Also the Music... just Brilliant.

reviewText:
The game that shows you not to underestimate RPG maker,
and it's complete with choices that affect the difficulty and story of the game.
Sacrifices will be made, and there are things that are difficult to do, but must be done.

The story follows a character named Brad, who was pushed into a drug addiction by traumatic childhood events. He's a broken man, abused by his father with a sister who had killed herself.
After his failure to protect her, he find his second chance years later, when after an apocalyptic event that wiped out all women, he found a baby girl out in the middle of nowhere.
The world Dingaling has built is complete with its humor, outright disturbing moments, and lore that will leave you winded.
The first scene leaves an impression on you. Maybe it'll take a while, but you'll realize soon that the story's no joke.

The combat is also great, and there are plenty of party members.
Speaking of party members, they're just so expendable to our enemies in the game.
They can be permakilled by certain moves in combat or in Russian Roulette.

It's on sale, so you should buy it.
Do it.
Or watch a playthrough of it, either way...

You may end up in love with this little-known indie title.

reviewText:
General Overview I do not normally write reviews, but after playing (and beating) this wonderful game, I felt I owed it to the steam community to share my thoughts on LISA. First of all, if you're thinking about buying this game, but are easily offended and/or cannot handle very mature (and rather dark) content, I would definitely recommend looking elsewhere for a game to satisfy your personal tastes. However, if you are like me, and enjoy a good dose of dark humor with some very solid RPG elements mixed in, this game is definitely for you. To make this a bit simpler, I'm going to break this review down into sections. Oh, and I must warn you, the story section contains some minor spoilers, though I tried to cover up those that you do not find out within the first few minutes of the game.

TL;DR If you're a fan of dark humor and/or old fashioned RPG style games, I highly recommend giving LISA a try. The story elements come together nicely without being completely overbearing, and the world itself is an incredible (though pretty p*rverted at times) place to explore. If you're on the fence like I was, definitely give it a go. Underneath the humor/grotesque imagery lies a deep and memorable story with very solid RPG style gameplay.

Story I want to start by saying that, despite the copious amount of humor, LISA manages to weave together a tale that both makes you think, and makes you sad. The game stars Brad Armstrong, who finds a second chance in life in a baby girl he finds one day in an apocolyptic wasteland where females have (supposedly) ceased to exist. Brad,  wishing to redeem himself from the suicide of his sister, Lisa,  takes in this baby girl and, with a few of his childhood friends, raises her as his own daughter. But one day, I believe while he was passed out in a drugged up state  having taken Joy, a euphoric painkiller of sorts, attempting to suppress the memories of his abusive father and the death of his sister  Buddy, his adopted daughter, is stolen away by the lonely men of the world (who, having not interacted with a female in many years, are rather hell-bent on real female intimacy, if you know what I mean). The main plot of the game centers around Brad's attempt to rescue his daughter, a daughter who may very well be the only female remaining in the world. Throughout the story you must make many tough decisions and sacrafices, and by the end you're left wondering whether or not your journey is even the right thing to do. The background info is slowly gathered throughout many flashbacks triggered when Brad enters certain areas. All in all, the story is very well done, and by the end, you can't help but feel bad (which, ironically, is what makes the story so good).
Story: 9/10

Gameplay Honestly, this is the part of the game that impressed me the most. With so much emphasis on story (and the world), I was afraid that the gameplay mechanics might suffer. Boy was I wrong. The game turned out to have very solid RPG style mechanics, with the fights done in the classic RPG turn-based style. The character progression is wonderfully done, with almost every single companion having a specific niche to fill. Also, the companions play very well off of each other, with specific companions fighting very well alongside each other with highly complementing move sets. Being a big RPG fan, this was the part of the game that I was most worried about when originally deciding whether or not to purchase LISA. After playing the game though, I am incredibly impressed at how well this game managed to stick to its RPG roots.
Gameplay: 9.5/10

Sound/Music Overall, the sound helps quite a bit in adding to the atmosphere of the game. The music helps quite a bit in getting into the world of the game. That being said, I was a bit disappointed in the lack of variety, as many times the same few tracks seem to be played in numerous areas with just a slight change in tempo. Even so, I never really got sick of it until the very end of the game, and I never got so sick of it that I muted my game (the tracks were enjoyable, just too often repeated).
Sound/Music: 7/10 (though see general atmosphere section for more on the positive aspect of the music)

General Atmosphere This is an area that the previews/store page promised would be excellent, and I believe that the developers delivered quite well on that promise. The mood is set right from the beggining of the game, and the sort of dark and gloomy atmosphere is maintained throughout the entire game without the game trying too hard to achieve it. However, this bleak, gloomy atmosphere is quite often lightened a bit with a touch of humor (usually right as it's needed), as well as numerous references to popular culture that can be picked up on. The humor does tend to be a bit dark and edgy at times, but (at least for me) that's exactly how I like it, and I believe it suited the game very well.
Atmosphere: 9/10

Conclusion If you're a fan of dark humor and/or old fashioned RPG style games, I highly recommend giving LISA a try. The story elements come together nicely without being completely overbearing, and the world itself is an incredible (though pretty p*rverted at times) place to explore. If you're on the fence like I was, definitely give it a go. Underneath the humor/grotesque imagery lies a deep and memorable story with very solid RPG style gameplay. I would recommend LISA to anyone with a dark sense of humor, those who like a story that makes you think, and all generic fans of RPGs (who can handle or enjoy dark humor).

Story: 9/10
Gameplay: 9.5/10
Sound/Music: 7/10
General Atmosphere: 9/10
Enjoyability: 10/10

Overall: 9/10

I highly recommend this game!

P.S. This is one of my first reviews (ever). I hope it was at least a little bit helpful! :)

reviewText: What ultimately impressed me in LISA was not the sublime soundtrack, charming artstyle or its slick combat system that's parodical of the 16 bit RPGs we grew up with and loved, but Dingaling's ability to interlope innocuous moments and quirky humor into a plot that is stricken with depravity and melancholia. We want to cry for Brad as he is tormented and mutilated throughout his journey, but cannot help chuckling at the absurd circumstances that surround his misery.

reviewText:
LISA is ruthlessly gut-wrenching down to its story, setting, characters, and gameplay design. The game thrusts the player into Brad's tormented world as he sets out into a bizzare and hellish wasteland on a rescue mission.

The player is forced to make exceedingly difficult choices throughout the game. The turn-based combat, as well as artistic design, takes heavy inspiration from Earthbound. LISA distinctly carves out its own niche, however. It's difficult to explain the range of emotions the player will experience when playing through this game.

The game suffers from some very minor performance issues at times, though it doesn't detract from the game very much at all. The difficult choices all feel compelling save for one unfortunate event around the middle of the game. To be clear, this one particular event  just feels cheap. You'll know it when you see it. However, I'd argue it's a very much forgivable misstep.

LISA is absolutely unashamed and relentless in its delivery of heavy, mature, and disturbing themes. This only makes it all the more essential to play in my opinion.

reviewText:
It's one of very, very few RPG Maker games that are actually good. LISA sends you into a miserable world populated solely by men who have lost all hope for the future. Life is cheap, those who live long enough suffer horrible mutations, and your character will be made to suffer. Like many Earthbound-inspired games, there is much disturbing imagery within, with music designed to unsettle as well. Although the game isn't all that dialogue heavy compared to other RPGs, it does a great job of telling a story with its wide variety of original, clever and imaginative visuals. The characters are pretty deep, deep enough to warrant multiple playthroughs just to have a full understanding of why the last hour of the game played out as it did.

There's a lot of permanent consequence in this game, so beware. From my perspective I find it to be kind of annoying and save-scum bait, but honestly that aspect of the game just isn't made for me. The Russian Roulette portion did feel like the RNG constantly cheating me, though. I actually had to save scum once I lost 4 characters to the enemy's one...geesh.

Two things worth noting: You'll get a bit more out of the game if you play LISA: The First, which is a <60 minute free RPG Maker game, before playing this game. The other thing is the game can be annoyingly grindy -- but RPG Maker save files are pretty easy to hex edit. (just be aware that values are always the minimum byte width necessary to store said values, i.e. exp will be 1 if under 256, 2 if under 65536, or 3 [not 4!] if >= 65536)

reviewText:
General Overview I do not normally write reviews, but after playing (and beating) this wonderful game, I felt I owed it to the steam community to share my thoughts on LISA. First of all, if you're thinking about buying this game, but are easily offended and/or cannot handle very mature (and rather dark) content, I would definitely recommend looking elsewhere for a game to satisfy your personal tastes. However, if you are like me, and enjoy a good dose of dark humor with some very solid RPG elements mixed in, this game is definitely for you. To make this a bit simpler, I'm going to break this review down into sections. Oh, and I must warn you, the story section contains some minor spoilers, though I tried to cover up those that you do not find out within the first few minutes of the game.

TL;DR If you're a fan of dark humor and/or old fashioned RPG style games, I highly recommend giving LISA a try. The story elements come together nicely without being completely overbearing, and the world itself is an incredible (though pretty p*rverted at times) place to explore. If you're on the fence like I was, definitely give it a go. Underneath the humor/grotesque imagery lies a deep and memorable story with very solid RPG style gameplay.

Story I want to start by saying that, despite the copious amount of humor, LISA manages to weave together a tale that both makes you think, and makes you sad. The game stars Brad Armstrong, who finds a second chance in life in a baby girl he finds one day in an apocolyptic wasteland where females have (supposedly) ceased to exist. Brad,  wishing to redeem himself from the suicide of his sister, Lisa,  takes in this baby girl and, with a few of his childhood friends, raises her as his own daughter. But one day, I believe while he was passed out in a drugged up state  having taken Joy, a euphoric painkiller of sorts, attempting to suppress the memories of his abusive father and the death of his sister  Buddy, his adopted daughter, is stolen away by the lonely men of the world (who, having not interacted with a female in many years, are rather hell-bent on real female intimacy, if you know what I mean). The main plot of the game centers around Brad's attempt to rescue his daughter, a daughter who may very well be the only female remaining in the world. Throughout the story you must make many tough decisions and sacrafices, and by the end you're left wondering whether or not your journey is even the right thing to do. The background info is slowly gathered throughout many flashbacks triggered when Brad enters certain areas. All in all, the story is very well done, and by the end, you can't help but feel bad (which, ironically, is what makes the story so good).
Story: 9/10

Gameplay Honestly, this is the part of the game that impressed me the most. With so much emphasis on story (and the world), I was afraid that the gameplay mechanics might suffer. Boy was I wrong. The game turned out to have very solid RPG style mechanics, with the fights done in the classic RPG turn-based style. The character progression is wonderfully done, with almost every single companion having a specific niche to fill. Also, the companions play very well off of each other, with specific companions fighting very well alongside each other with highly complementing move sets. Being a big RPG fan, this was the part of the game that I was most worried about when originally deciding whether or not to purchase LISA. After playing the game though, I am incredibly impressed at how well this game managed to stick to its RPG roots.
Gameplay: 9.5/10

Sound/Music Overall, the sound helps quite a bit in adding to the atmosphere of the game. The music helps quite a bit in getting into the world of the game. That being said, I was a bit disappointed in the lack of variety, as many times the same few tracks seem to be played in numerous areas with just a slight change in tempo. Even so, I never really got sick of it until the very end of the game, and I never got so sick of it that I muted my game (the tracks were enjoyable, just too often repeated).
Sound/Music: 7/10 (though see general atmosphere section for more on the positive aspect of the music)

General Atmosphere This is an area that the previews/store page promised would be excellent, and I believe that the developers delivered quite well on that promise. The mood is set right from the beggining of the game, and the sort of dark and gloomy atmosphere is maintained throughout the entire game without the game trying too hard to achieve it. However, this bleak, gloomy atmosphere is quite often lightened a bit with a touch of humor (usually right as it's needed), as well as numerous references to popular culture that can be picked up on. The humor does tend to be a bit dark and edgy at times, but (at least for me) that's exactly how I like it, and I believe it suited the game very well.
Atmosphere: 9/10

Conclusion If you're a fan of dark humor and/or old fashioned RPG style games, I highly recommend giving LISA a try. The story elements come together nicely without being completely overbearing, and the world itself is an incredible (though pretty p*rverted at times) place to explore. If you're on the fence like I was, definitely give it a go. Underneath the humor/grotesque imagery lies a deep and memorable story with very solid RPG style gameplay. I would recommend LISA to anyone with a dark sense of humor, those who like a story that makes you think, and all generic fans of RPGs (who can handle or enjoy dark humor).

Story: 9/10
Gameplay: 9.5/10
Sound/Music: 7/10
General Atmosphere: 9/10
Enjoyability: 10/10

Overall: 9/10

I highly recommend this game!

P.S. This is one of my first reviews (ever). I hope it was at least a little bit helpful! :)

reviewText:
I've been trying to come up with a review that can do LISA justice but I find that I am completely stumped. This game plays with your emotions so much that I almost had trouble completing it. At times you feel sorry for the main character, Brad, and other times you hate his guts. You can laugh at the goofy jokes and the occasional breakage of the 4th wall, and you can be disturbed by oddly shaped mutants and mounds of corpses. This game made me laugh, squirm with discomfort, and honestly made me cry. Quite simply it hits you right in the feels.

It is a fairly long game and it has a large world full of interesting and diverse characters, scenery, and events. You are routinely forced to make choices that permanently affect the game and your experience. These choices can get you new party members or cost you your arm. The enemies are diverse and interesting, and you never know what you will be encountering next.

10/10 would cry again

reviewText:
Not just one of the best games I've played in years, but one of the best games I've played period. LISA is a turn-based RPG in the style of Earthbound, set in a post-apocalyptic world in which women, and by extension, humanity, are on the verge of extincition. The story follows Bradley Armstrong, a gruff, bearded man, who, in spite of his appearance, is not some typical action hero, but a deeply troubled and unstable individual. Finding a baby abandoned in the wastes, Brad finds himself faced with deciding between his own desperate need for redemption in caring for her, and the potential salvation of humanity in the hands of others.

No matter what decisions you make, it's a tragic narrative, and as such, moments of humor are often present between major story beats so as to keep it from becoming too depressing. It pulls off this balancing act stunningly, simultaneously poignant, and hilarious. All while immersing you in a deep, rich world, better realized in 2 Dimensions than many other games' are in 3. With a huge cast of memorable characters and a fantastic soundtrack,  LISA stands out among it's peers as a both a bold new IP, and a love letter to a handful of existing ones. I couldn't recommend it more.

10/10

reviewText:
10/10
Would I recommend this game? Hell yes, but not to everyone. LISA is an acquired taste. You've gotta have a taste for the weird, the creepy, and the wrong.. and you definitely can't be feint of heart.

Before I start, I'll just say, 10/10, hands down. Dingaling has created one of my favourite games to date. LISA's story is very refreshing and original, and definitely something not anyone could have thought up. There are secrets o' plenty, and the playstyle is very old-school. Of course, there are plenty of perverts, mutants, and substance-abusers as well, but they make it interesting. LISA hits all emotional buttons; you'll laugh, cry, rage, get the weirdest of boners, and most of all, cringe. It's one of the most original, well-thought-out, and intriguing side-scrollers I've seen in a really long time.

The soundtrack is created by Widdly 2 Diddly, which is actually just the same guy who makes up the one man show that is Dingaling. It's perfect; eerie and cheerie. Some of my favourite tracks include Beehive"

reviewText:
The game that shows you not to underestimate RPG maker,
and it's complete with choices that affect the difficulty and story of the game.
Sacrifices will be made, and there are things that are difficult to do, but must be done.

The story follows a character named Brad, who was pushed into a drug addiction by traumatic childhood events. He's a broken man, abused by his father with a sister who had killed herself.
After his failure to protect her, he find his second chance years later, when after an apocalyptic event that wiped out all women, he found a baby girl out in the middle of nowhere.
The world Dingaling has built is complete with its humor, outright disturbing moments, and lore that will leave you winded.
The first scene leaves an impression on you. Maybe it'll take a while, but you'll realize soon that the story's no joke.

The combat is also great, and there are plenty of party members.
Speaking of party members, they're just so expendable to our enemies in the game.
They can be permakilled by certain moves in combat or in Russian Roulette.

It's on sale, so you should buy it.
Do it.
Or watch a playthrough of it, either way...

You may end up in love with this little-known indie title.

reviewText:
8/10 - TL;DR - Great story, emphasis on choices...but felt a little railroaded.  Excellent gameplay.  Excellent artwork.  Excellent soundtrack.

Story:
(MINOR SPOILERS)
This was a very artfully executed RPG with a masterfully told story.  The opening alone is one of the strongest openings I've seen from a game in a long time.  The main characters had interesting backstories which I felt compelled to figure out.  I've not had a game make me feel as much as this one did in such a short period of time.  All that being said, I felt a bit railroaded in my playthrough.  I was forced to make horrible decisions (which is fine), but I didn't feel that what I chose affected the story very much.  I remained very much an anti-hero though I did my very best to play the white knight."  Not the worst thing in the world
date:
but that's where I think there could've been some improvement.

Gameplay:
The battle system is reminiscent of Earthbound.  It is turn-based and filled to brim with interesting status effects and skills.  The combo system used by the main character (and a spattering of others) was very visceral and felt quite fulfilling.  I was also impressed by the massive roster of pickable characters to choose from.  Finally
recommended: one of the coolest elements of the game is the overworld exploration.  Lots of traditional pixel-based RPGs are viewed top-down
hoursPlayed:
but this one is a sidescroller with platforming elements.  It made for engaging exploration.

Artwork:
The art of this game was what drew me in initially.  Most old-school RPGs go with the traditional JRPG/anime theme
voteText: but Lisa stands apart with its gruff biker-types and washed-up middle-aged drug addicts.  The art isn't beautiful.  It's quite ugly...in the best way possible.  If you're looking for a game that ventures off the beaten path in terms of artwork
helpfulPercent:
I highly recommend Lisa.

Music:
Lisa had one of the most bizarre soundtracks I've ever heard from a game.  That being said
votesHelpful: I loved it.  Widdly 2 Diddly managed to add wonderful atmosphere to a very unusual game.  It even played off of old RPG tropes (success music sounding less than successful) that managed to make me laugh from time to time.  And when the music wasn't making me laugh
votesTotal: it was making me feel more intensely the painful moments of my protagonist.  Excellent soundtrack."

reviewText:
The game that shows you not to underestimate RPG maker,
and it's complete with choices that affect the difficulty and story of the game.
Sacrifices will be made, and there are things that are difficult to do, but must be done.

The story follows a character named Brad, who was pushed into a drug addiction by traumatic childhood events. He's a broken man, abused by his father with a sister who had killed herself.
After his failure to protect her, he find his second chance years later, when after an apocalyptic event that wiped out all women, he found a baby girl out in the middle of nowhere.
The world Dingaling has built is complete with its humor, outright disturbing moments, and lore that will leave you winded.
The first scene leaves an impression on you. Maybe it'll take a while, but you'll realize soon that the story's no joke.

The combat is also great, and there are plenty of party members.
Speaking of party members, they're just so expendable to our enemies in the game.
They can be permakilled by certain moves in combat or in Russian Roulette.

It's on sale, so you should buy it.
Do it.
Or watch a playthrough of it, either way...

You may end up in love with this little-known indie title.

reviewText:
This is an incredible game that reminded me what it was I loved most about video games. It put me in Brad's shoes. I was the man that lived in this world. I made the decisions. I felt the emotions and paid the consequences for my bad choices. There might have been a few moments in the game that I couldn't figure out and maybe once or twice I came across a section of the game that was a big buggy (only about one or two minutes of game play) but other than that, this game was as close to perfect as you can get. The humor of this game made me really laugh. On the other hand, some of the choices in this game really effected me emotionally. I'm very glad that I played this game and would recommend it to anyone who really wants to get lost in a deeply emotional, very funny, very ♥♥♥♥ed up game. This game isn't for the kiddies. It's very dark and very disturbing.

I just finished this game a few minutes ago and I can't get over what just happened.

The people who made this game should be really proud of what they've made. It's art. It's beautiful. It's funny. The music is amazing and plentiful (there's about 90 songs). GG Dingaling and GG Widdly 2 Diddly. ♥♥♥♥ing amazing.

You won't regret playing this game, but you will regret.

reviewText:
With all the hubbub around another great recent sprite-based indie RPG, I keep recommending those that liked that one to try out LISA.

It's a post-apocalyptic tale of a father searching for his daughter in a hellscape full of twisted mutants and the worst of humanity that will play at your emotions and expectations, part absurdist, part horrifyingly real.

The battle system is unique, with a big emphasis on status effects and dialing in combos like a fighting game. While some of these techniques (anything involving tripping, oil+fire attacks) will turn most battles into a cakewalk, it's offset by the ridiculous brutality of many of the bosses.

However, the story and writing is the best part of the game. The creator toes a fine line between absurd, often crude or sardonic humour and extremely serious moments that will have you on the edge of your seat. Many times you will have to choose between two horrible decisions, and the consequences will impact the rest of your game. There are no happy endings in The Painful RPG and the game will always remind you of the awful choices you made.

A twisted and groovy soundtrack tops it all off. I am yet to find another game quite like LISA.

reviewText:
Lisa is a fantastic game. On its own, the spoon-fed plot is enjoyable, but the real joy comes from exploring the world and putting story elements together. The dialogue alone makes Lisa a game worth purchasing. It shifts wildly between the poles of childish light-hearted toilet humor and poignant dark psychology. There is an entire area in the middle of horrific violence that is completely dedicated to professional wrestling memes. It is wonderful. The music is heavily atmospheric and has neat tie-ins with the story (especially whenever you hear a horn). The combat system is one that's been done before (kind of a mix of Xenogears and Earthbound), but battles aren't tedious as they are in other RPGs. More attention is given to exploration and dialogue than combat, so getting into constant fights and grinding is never a worry. There are a few areas (five in total throughout the entire game) that have infinitely-spawning random encounters, but the time spent in them is short enough to not become repetitive. The remaining fights are all either scripted or completely avoidable based on choices.

The character development is somewhat lacking for certain party members in the game. For Brad, Buddy, certain party members, and the main antagonists of the game, character development is strong - especially if information on them is sought out by the player. For other recruitable characters, it isn't as much. While this is to be expected from a game that both relies on its humor for character recruiting and one with a large recruitable roster, there should be a little more backstory for certain party members and enemies. Information on a lot of them is available through the artbook, but it's not in the game itself. In pain mode, there are some added enemies that don't really add anything to the plot, but who one would think would be important.

The rest of the gripes are fairly minor. Navigating menus can be somewhat tedious. If Brad uses a bottle of soup on a character, it exits the menu to display text that the bottle is now empty and it is necessary to navigate back to the item menu again. That could probably be streamlined better.

The combat UI can be buggy at times. There are times when a party member will receive a status ailment and the text on the screen will never disappear. Sometimes enemies will just disappear from view. They are still there, and reappear when they're selected, but their sprites will just vanish momentarily.

The UI to set controls is awful. Thankfully the game defaults to controller settings that are present in most console RPGs, but trying to set up custom controls is very difficult unless the player is very familiar with the game beforehand.

Most of the characters are useful in their own ways save a few. The Joy withdrawal mechanic on Brad can be annoying, but it isn't game-breaking; however, a significant portion of the recruitable party members are also Joy addicts, and withdrawal symptoms happen so often that keeping Joy addicts in your party is a significant liability. Some really interesting recruits rarely see use because their Joy addiction is such an annoyance that other non-addicted party members are much more preferable.

The stengths of Lisa far outweigh the weaknesses. It is a hilarious and emotional journey that encourages exploration and strengthens its storytelling through gameplay. It is wholeheartedly recommended.

reviewText:
This game is going to tear your feelings apart.

LISA surprised me, a lot.

It felt kind of hard to get into at first, as it doesn't really feel welcoming and all that, but once you get the hang of it and continue even though the first few minutes might seem bad, you're going to thank yourself.

There's a serious story about rescuing your daughter with lots of choices to face - whether you like them or not - and then there's also loads of dark humour that's going to make you laugh even during the darkest times in the depressing, grey and unforgiving post-apocalyptic world.

Even though I've found most of this game to be amazing, one thing I did not like was the music. It felt a bit too annoying for my taste, although people tend to praise it and I indeed can fully see that it does its job right at describing the game world.

Conclusion time - whether you're like me and mute the music or like it and leave it blasting into your speakers or headphones, let's just say that you should play this game no matter what. There.

reviewText:
This game goes up there with the MOTHER series in the ranks.  It's beautiful, hilarious, horrifying and satisfying at the same time.  You will feel emotions that you haven't felt for a video game in a long time.  I actually cried a few times over this game because of how emotionally in depth I became while playing it.  And the last time I cried over a video game was MOTHER 3.

The game play resembles the MOTHER series with the battle system, but is more of a side scrolling RPG.  I wouldn't have it any other way.  This game is PERFECT.  Five stars, 10/10, all of the hot peppers, etc.  Big ups to the creators who obviously spent many hours (and I question how many of said hours were sober) on this game.

Not for the faint of heart.

reviewText:
Twisted, Deep, Comical, and Lots of Fun
If you like Earthbound, wrestling, body horror, ambiguous morals, post-apocalypic enivornments, the Power Rangers, or surreal humor then LISA is not for you because it's not for anybody.  But you'll still love it.

LISA is a bizarre game.  You need to know that going in.  This is the kind of game that will make you slap your forehead as the game wrecks you and your player character with little warning while still giving you a fair amount of time to prepare for the hit.  It's also the kind of game where all of the characters are weird, sometimes lovable, oftentimes disgusting, and completely expendable.  Don't get too attached.

The gameplay is an interesting combination of genres.  On one hand, it is a side-scrolling adventure game with similar philosophy (but far different feel) to Flashback or Another World.  On the other hand, the game's combat system is handled as a turn-based RPG that brings to mind Earthbound.  All of which is very balanced, though a small gripe is tht screen transitions in the side-scrolling sections can occasionally cause players to blunder off cliffs resulting in damage or even instant Game Overs.

The graphics also easily bring to mind the Earthbound asthetic, especially the feel of Mother 3.  Don't be fooled though!  This game is not childish at all and will use its cartoony style to create an unsettling dissonance (which is helped greatly by the soundtrack as well) with all of the dark subject matter.

That's the final part of the game that I wish to comment on: this game covers very dark subject matter.  There is betrayal, ♥♥♥♥, extreme violence, needless murder, suicide, sex-crazed wastelanders doing anything to get off, drug abuse... the list goes on and on- and it's not exclusively the villains who partake in this behavior.  It all comes together to make an excellent story with beautifully flawed characters who try to get by in this bizarre, barren, ridiculous, and harsh world.

The reason why I bring this up is that, while I love how the subject matter is handled (oftentimes like a screwed up joke that cracks up the joker but leaves the rest of the room uncomfortable), it isn't for everybody.  If you find yourself easily offended or unable to cope with uncomfortable subjects like the ones I listed in the previous paragraph then this game might make you squirm too much for you to enjoy it.  If you think you can handle it, however, this game is definitely worth your time.

One of the best and most interesting games that I've played in a while.  It continues to amaze me what creative people can manage to do with RPG Maker.

reviewText: Easily my favourite Pixel RPG ever made. It has enough humor to leave you wanting more, and a large amount of sorrow that allows you to take this game seriously. As said, most of this game is depressing and at times very harsh, but is balanced out to the point where your emotions will contrast each other constantly, never staying the same. The story is very intriguing, and its basic art style is still pleasant on the eyes. Every character you meet will shock you, make you cry, or make you cry for a completely different reason. The soundtrack is done perfectly, although at first it seems repetitive and annoying, it slowly builds on you and really sets the tone for the insane world you're forced to survive in. I still listen to it occasionally for its originality. The game's difficulty is challenging in some areas more than others, seemingly without a pattern, but that all depends on your party members, luck, and the items you're carrying. There's another difficulty in the game known as 'Pain Mode', which severely hinders gameplay, making it almost impossible to finish first try. I'd reccomend it to people wanting all acheivements, or people who are ok with getting angry often.                              If this game was a rollercoaster, it'd be one without a seat, and no speed limit. I rate it: 10 Bald Naked Men / 10

One of two sides of the Earthbound coin, but mostly drawing upon the darker, creepier and trippier aspects of it.

It's the story of Brad, a complete nobody, who while living his days in a depraved, post-apocalyptic world where women have ceased to exist, stumbles upon a baby girl, giving him purpose in his useless life. As you travel through the desolate wasteland that used to be the world and interview some of the colorful characters here, you'll be asking yourself wtf could happen to the world to make it like this?"

reviewText: I bought this game to make me laugh, and with that goal achieved within 30 minutes of playing the diverse characters, amazing soundtrack, and heart wrenching story beautifully woven into the game were all a bonus. The game is an emotional rollercoatser from start to finish, with an ending sure to leave a pit in your stomach as deep as the myusterious backstory. For a ten hour game it has a lot going on and makes a smart choice not to shove it in the players face but instead make the player ask questions and give them enough information to piece together something for themselves. I have only a few criticisms for the game: real combat is a bit scarce with many fights meant to be cinamatic or as jokes, and when the game forces you to make decisions that the player may not agree with it can be a little frustrating. That being said the game is easily worth the ten dollars, and with extra content promised on kickstarter may even be worth an arm or a leg. 7.8/10

reviewText:
LISA is a post-apocalyptic RPG. I find it good but not very fun, and I will try to explain why.

I will start with what got me into playing the game: the graphics are simple, but the art style is rich and very evocative (special mention to all the different monstrously mutated humans). It translates into the scenes visited: a lot of variation, twisted stories, but with a simple delivery and charm. This is mostly what kept me going, knowing that each area would reveal new characters and stories with their own personality that bring something new to the experience. While it is impressive that all these scenes can hint at much more depth while being so short, it also disappointed me that there was little follow-through to any of these stories and characters. Especially regarding all the many players that can be recruited to the party of the player. Only a little bit more follow-through for the main quest, but new elements that concern it are so far from each other that it feels disconnected from the experience. At least there are moments with terrible choices to make, and some of those will stick to the player's mind even after the game has been closed!

While I appreciated the variety in locations, I found it very hard to appreciate the core gameplay that would get me from one place to the other. The game looks like a platformer, but there is no way to jump so moving up requires cords. There are many platforms to climb, so exploring is both tedious and dangerous as falling in a pit can lead to a game over. And the framerate can occasionally tank so much that navigating the levels becomes even more painful. I would have stopped the game after a few minutes if there wasn't quickly a bicycle to move faster, but even then navigating these mountains and having a hard time remembering where each door among many goes really put me off. And that is where I could also see that despite its limitations the game was well designed, as backgrounds were hugely different for each place, or sometimes annoying enemies would serve as a way to remind the player which direction had not been explored yet.

Talking about combat, this game is similar to a jRPG as the player chooses the different attacks, and then everyone attacks in turn with no movement involved. There are some moments with surprise encounters, but thankfully very rare or it would have convinced me to stop the game as well. It is not really necessary to grind either, so the usual reasons as to why I hate jRPGs are largely mitigated here. And even if I do not like jRPG combat logic (why can my character heal during a battle but not outside?), the combat system was not a complete bore due to the original attacks and effects (can make someone feel weird, cry, trip and so on). So not especially enjoyable, but not too taxing while having depth and enough variety in the enemies encountered to prevent too much repetition.

Another question is: are the save locations frequent enough to prevent frustration? I would say that it is alright, there are enough save points to not have to walk long distance over and over. However, the rest camps can be quite annoying as there are high chances to treat the player very unfairly by kidnapping a party member, poisoning the group, stealing the in-game currency. I get it, Lisa's world is harsh and it has to be painful for the player as well, but I would just load the save and try over and over until my party has been healed. And waste my time. Because I don't want to waste my time looking around for a kidnapped party member, or having to grind experience to upgrade a new one if the previous one decided to abandon me.

In Lisa, every design decision makes sense and has been well thought. The game could have been so horrible to play if the developer didn't know what he was doing! But as it is, playing is alright. Not fun, but with enough variety to push me to seek the next deviant scene I will encounter and yearn for more. And the music kicks ♥♥♥. I do not know if I can recommend Lisa as I did not enjoy most of my time with it, but I still find it a good and interesting game with a lot of depth under its simple appearance.

reviewText:
Out of all of the games that I've bought over the past 6 months, this one feels the most unique. I've never liked games that play up the hard-for-the-sake-of-hard mechanics, but LISA is hard because the world it's building is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ one.

I'm about 1/3 of the way through the game and didn't plan on writing this review until I'd finished the game, but whatever this game is great. The narrative is cool, the combat animations are satisfying, and it's the only game that I've ever played that actually made me regret a decision that I made through game mechanics rather than sad elf faces.

There's a character who sucks that you can sacrifice your items to save. You think that he's going to get better, but that doesn't happen. There's a point later in the game where you can make that character compete in a game of Russian Roulette. I did that and three rounds later the plucky nutcase walked out unscathed. While he still sucks and I'll never use him in combat, there's something magical about me discovering that a useless party member's secret power is his ability to not get murdered in Russian Roulette.

I have no idea what goes into the game's Russian Roulette simulation. He could have just gotten lucky for all that I know. All of that is just a narrative that happened because the developer lets you make choices that have consequences and feelings attached to them. There is no Jesus/Hitler binary here and it's great.

My only complaint? The game's overworld is a little confusing.

Also, this game's writing is incredibly good. I bought Dragon Age Inquisition and I got Joss Whedon tropes and bulls whom I can Romance, but Lisa gives me funny and heartfelt moments with porno mags as currency.

Proof of an uncaring universe

reviewText:
I am really impressed by the level of overall polish and artistic beauty in Lisa. Don't get it twisted - this is not one of those short little indie titles - this is a full blown RPG with one of the best storylines you will ever experience. It seems simple on the surface, but there are layers of complexity here.

It is absolutely worth full price. And there is a sequal in the works, which is just awesome. Just stay off the forums for fear of spoilers.

Pros:
+Artwork is brilliantly done - its subtle but you will catch on
+Music is absolutely outstanding, and I will certainly pick up the soundtrack
+Choices really do matter (e.g. I made choices that ended up killing off an entire town)
+Character avatars are modified due to different choices
+This game is emotionally charged (some consider it dark), and keeps me coming back

Cons:
-Some of the platforming can become tedious if you are not sure where to go. This is not a huge deal, but I will mention it.

reviewText:
I love this game!
But it wasted a lot of potential... obviously, because it's a one-man-job (even including the soundtrack) and a whole game like that is a little much for one man.

If I was a heartless critic and strictly went after quality, I guess there's a lot about this game I would give a beating. The gameplay has a lot of flaws and some places (+ their fights) can just annoy you (damn Marty spiders!).
Also it's kinda fun to 'collect' playable characters but in the end they don't really mean anything. I would have rather liked fewer of them but with a bit bigger part in the story.

Anyway, its shortcomings couldn't keep me from enjoying the f**k outta this game. I just loved its dirty, cynical perv vibe. There's just not many games out there which are this uncompromising. I was actually surprised I liked it so much, because, to be honest, I'm a little tired of all that Southpark-HappyTreeFriends-FamilyGuy-kinda cynicism, because it always works the same way and has become too predictable to be able to shock or amuse you anymore.
I guess it's this game's personal color and the fact that one person put all his s**t into it, so the graphical style, the music and the story harmonize perfectly. And I mean, just take a look at this Austin Jorgensen's Facebook profile. That guy is just delightfully... strange. Looks like someone dug him out of a part of America where there has been no internet until recently and only TV shows and films from up to 1993. I hope they consider him for the new season of Twin Peaks.

Also, what I really liked about this game is the uncompromising consequences you have to live with. This game should have an iron man mode with only one save which is automatically updated after each decision. I have to admit at one point I just didn't want to take the brutal consequence of my decision, loaded my save and decided otherwise. Yeah, I know, I'm weak! But it's not my fault - the game shouldn't have let me do it ;)
Still, there's so many mean f**ks you have to take in this game (some literally) that you WILL BE SORE.
I was also a lot into the story. Unfortunately, the end was a little disappointing and 'thin'. The setting and plot had a lot more potential.

Still, this is one of those games that are so quaint it'll stick with you. The soundtrack, too. I'm still waking up every day to the tune of that trumpet player in my head O_O

I've heard the guy is already working on his next game (between Kung-Fu lessons, acting, making music and greasing his hair) and I'm reeeeally looking forward to it :)

reviewText:
LISA is a fantastic visual and emotional experience that will have you questioning your morals throughout the entire game.

Are you willing to make personal sacrifices to save those who you've become attached to? Are you willing to do questionable things in the pursuit of personal gain? You will find yourself answering both of these questions over and over again, leaving you in a position to question yourself if you've done the right thing...or if there really was a right" all along.

I personally recommend this to anyone who is a fan of dark humor

reviewText:
The story of Lisa is the story of rescuing your Buddy. The feels this game gives ya rivals the multi-million dollar platform games made today.

It's a true mysterious, difficult, and exciting journey that I haven't seen in a long time that is far different from the easy, hand holding, and completely stale games that are here today.

And yes... I just rescued a fat man from a hair club from being molested by creepy men. He now runs over bad guys with his truck.

The game is violent, it is perverted, it is foul, it is awkward, and I love everything about it.

reviewText: Be warned: This game is extremely experimental (and this isn't just another way to say it's pretentious indie crap
date:
I swear).
The game goes out of its way to frustrate you. You are forced to make hard decisions. You will lose, again, and again, and again. There are dozens of companions in this game, and each and every single one of them can die permanently. Or they might just decide to abandon you. Your main character can lose all he has, including his limbs.
This game is absolutely nuts.
It's not quite rocks fall
hoursPlayed:
but at one point, it gets very, very close to that.
Absolutely loving the game just for that aspect alone already.

The story is gripping, dark, and you always know that anything can happen. I absolutely couldn't let go off this game, because I wanted to know how it was going to end.
But all in all, I've got to say the story's actually what I like the least about this game. A few times in the game, your player character will do terrible things to others. He'll just do what he wants, basically. It always takes you out of the game a little bit, but it's mostly forgivable. However, at one point in particular, towards the very end of the game, it just completely took me out of the game. I'd been there, captivated by the plot, longing to know what happens next--but then, I ceased to feel with my player character. Simple as that.
About one hour before completing the game, I was actually concerned that I wasn't going to be able to sleep easy, no matter how the game would end. But now, I just don't really care.
And when you look at it, the story is just bleak and depressing. Things don't really get resolved at all, and there's a bunch of open questions.
Apart from the last thirty minutes of the game, the story is perfect, though. Absolutely phenomenal, especially coupled with the permadeath mechanics. I can't emphasize this enough: Hard decisions have to be made in this game.

I've actually had to wrestle with myself whether to hit that thumbs up or thumbs down button at the bottom of this review. Ultimately, I went with a recommendation, because this game is just so unbelievably imaginative, daring, and provocative. Does the game go too far? Definitely. But too far is better than too little.

reviewText: Imagine for me this: You take the post-apocalyptic setting of Fallout but instead of guns you use fists and farts to deal damage, then stir in the perversion of Mad Max and Escape from New York, finally bake to a tender juicy finish with the melodramatic insanity of A Boy and His Dog. That's LISA. LISA is the type of game that doesn't come along often, especially from an indie developer. Having just scratched the surface of this game with only 8 hours of gameplay, I am confident to say that it holds its own amongst indie superstars Braid and LIMBO. The introduction alone is worth the price of admission, as it weaves a convincing story in the first five minutes of (near silent) game play than all of Twilight does throughout three films. As the player follows LISA's protagonist through a heartbreaking adventure full of perverts, drugs, and combat, he or she will find it hard to pull away from both the narrative and the gameplay.\n\nIf I had anything remiss to say about LISA it would be that sometimes the combat can seem repetitive, or the side scrolling back and forth to make sure you have explored every possible route can become tedious for the neurotic gamer, but LISA manages to mix up the perfect concoction of humor and unique combat to spin a dark and twisted post-apocalyptic tale unlike many modern games have ever done.

reviewText:
I picked this game up during the Summer Sale with the leftovers of my Steam wallet. I had read an article about this game some time ago and I thought the premise was interesting enough. I'll be honest, I actually wasn't expecting too much from this game. Indie hasn't really been my thing. It came out and I never really heard anything about it afterwards. Not sure why though. The game is ridiculously good. The developer created a world that is really interesting and its populated whacky characters that had me continuously moving forward. I wanted to see what insane thing was on the next screen and I wasn't disappointed.

Despite all the craziness, the world ties together really nicely. You might meet an npc that gives an offhand comment that you don't get the full implication of until later in the game when you get more context. This kind of attention to detail makes the game great. The world is a blast to traverse through. Maybe a few too many caves but they're short and normally used for transition. They often contain some event that prevents them from being too bad anyways. The mood of all the areas is lended a hand by the music. The music is great and really helps to establish sense of an area. Also that workout song? Beautiful.

This game isn't all whacky though. There are some genuinely creepy elements to the game and a sense of unease is cultivated that often has a rather horrifying pay off. You also are forced into tough choices. I didn't really struggle on the first couple but the later choices are rough and will leave you wondering if you should of done that. I can harp on about the world the game created for a while but how is the gameplay? Its pretty good. A bit standard if I really want to nitpick about it. You pick your attacks/skills and the turn plays out based on who has priority. The combat is helped along by the allies you pick up during your journey. The variety of characters really kept me from getting bored.

They all have their own skill sets that are fun to experiment with. You can find some pretty fun combinations of allies in the game. I will say that the joy addiction system wasn't my favorite thing in the world. It pretty much makes some characters completely worthless due to withdrawals. I ended up avoiding them because, while they CAN be strong, I felt that the withdrawals was a bit too annoying to deal with. Especially considering that the non-addict teammates seemed just as strong to me. I also didn't find much joy in my playthrough but that could of been on me. I really wanted to use Bucket after what I went through to get him, but alas...

In the end, I really enjoyed this game. I would recommend it regardless of price. The ten dollar price tag is more than worth it. If you're a bit leery then do like I did and pick it up during a sale. I managed to beat it after ~11 hours and I can say it was a blast to playthrough. I'm even considering going through it again on the hard difficulty.

TLDR: Great world
Great soundtrack
Good combat
Great story
Great game

reviewText: This is the first piece of media in a huge while that made me feel something.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
A wasteland of Joy, mutants and desperate fiends. A tale of love, abuse and loyalty.

You play the part of Brad, a broken man known as an accomplished martial arts instructor, deeply tormented by grief and abuse.
Your life changes the day one of your drugged up afternoons are interrupted by a baby girl lying on the ground in front of you - a seemingly impossible event in a ruined world inhabited solely freaks and deranged men. The future of humanity is now literally in your hands and you will be forced to go to great length and make crushing choices to protect it.
Who will you be at the end of all of this?

The story, writing and soundtrack are the absolute highlights of this tale. Many of the tracks from the soundtrack stand on their own, even outside of the context of the game. The dialogue is impressive, moving from pitch black darkness to absolute hilarity with ease. The disturbing visuals adds greatly to the experience. The aesthetic looks like something Ralph Steadman would conjure up if he was less talented and into pixel art.

It is not without flaws, however. The game has some mechanical issues of major proportions and the limitations of the game engine are often apparent. It's not bad enough to detract from an incredible experience but one can't help but wonder what the game would play like with a bigger budget and a custom engine.

LISA is definitely not for everyone. If it is for you however - and if you read this far it quite possibly is - you will laugh, be disgusted, get angry and maybe even shed a tear or two when you experience this piece of art. It will make you feel something and that's a rare thing in gaming.

Seriously recommended.

reviewText:
So, before I begin, I would like to thank Dingaling for providing a fresh and fun entry into the indie genre, one that has affected me and many others greatly, and hopefully will endure the test of time.

I feel that the first thing I should do is address the drawing of parallels between Undertale and LISA. These games may share quite a bit, but it is absolutely NOT worth comparing the two, as they share completely different themes and gameplay focuses. Undertale's focus is more on gathering friendships and the value of those friendships. Undertale likes to be fair(so long as you are going pacifist), and will reward you for playing along. LISA is a take on how everything can be taken away from us in the blink of an eye, even if you DO play along. Choices you make will be difficult, they will have an effect on you in the moment, and will make your journey significantly more difficult, as you cannot avoid these decisions.

It's unfair.

Life is unfair.

I will now break down LISA into pros/cons like the good little reviewer I was born to be.

Pros:
-Great soundtrack, I still listen to a few of the songs on my own time, and each area has it's own little (widdly2)diddly as you walk about and absorb the atmosphere.

-Incredible atmosphere, LISA is hopeless, you will feel hopeless, but that's part of the enjoyment, the comedy given to you in the form of characters and wacky situations help raise your spirits to give you the motivation to continue on regardless.

-Story(?), LISA easily has one of the most dark and inhuman storylines of any game I've ever had the pleasure of playing, it will destroy your sense of being and bring you back to the light only to send you back to hell. It makes you feel things. It's good.

-Combat(?), Although many would say combat was the shortcoming of LISA, I actually found it a bit fun, it works on a basic WASD dial combo system to dial in skills for extra damage. If you were too lazy to learn the combos yourself, you could simply circumvent the dial combos and go straight to the skill menu. This feature was a blessing and a curse, the latter I will explain later.

-Art, The art was nothing special to be honest, but it was definitely really good and the earthy tones really helped convey the tone Dingaling was going for.

Now, onto our cons.

-Difficulty Curve, LISA's main selling point may just be it's downfall. It's hard. This game was incredibly hard in it's beginning stages, albeit it becomes easier as the game goes on, it almost turned me off and has actually turned off many other players from continuing the game. Anyone who buys this needs to understand that you'll need to push past that first crossroads before the game picks up and you can actually fight things.

-Combat(?), LISA's combat is a real crapshoot, you either like it or hate it, or who knows, you might be fine with it, but it definitely wasn't anything revolutionary and ESPECIALLY in the beginning stages it's tedious as hell and can really get frustrating to fight anything. It gets better later on, but as I said, the steep curve of this game turns players off right from the beginning without showing them a light at the end of the tunnel

-Story(?), LISA's story is ♥♥♥♥ed up, and for the most people, hardly relateable. It's really dark and depending on your life experiences you will either become enthralled in it's world or be completely turned off by it's harshness. Really a matter of preference.

-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ING CLIFFS, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T

Overall, I rate LISA:The Painful RPG a 8/10, could have been better on the mechanics side of thing, but overall an amazing title and a great addition to anyone's library.

reviewText:
I want to write a review mostly because the game was on sales so many people bought it. First off, if you have no idea what this game is about and want to find out more watch the trailer. Don't go to the negative reviews. People with 30 minutes of gameplay say some random ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t for no reason without reasonable arguements.

Anyways, like everyone has said the game is inspired by Earthbound. If you're familiar with Earthbound then you'll quickly grasp the combat system. The game is kinda difficult, I struggled at some certain parts but in my first run I did way better than I expected. The story is amazing and really emotional. Austin (the developer) has done an amazing job with the plot and apart from all the emotion the humor in this game is just ... amazing.
The game isn't gonna go easy on you. I realised that in the first hour. You're gonna need to make choices, important choices. You need to think of the correct choices that benefit your main character and that was harsh for someone like me who likes to have many companions.
Up so far, Lisa is for me the best game I've played in 2015 (We will see if Lisa the Joyful can top this game). You should buy this game and you should go through the emotional rollercoaster I went through. 10/10

reviewText:
The best way to describe this game would be 'Dad who loses everything simulator'. You play as Brad Armstrong, a sad, broken man looking for his missing daughter in a post-apocalyptic world where he hates everything and everything hates him. Touches on some very dark themes such as child abuse, drug addiction, prostitution, and professional wrestling.

Gameplay: Heavily Earthbound inspired and is pretty much typical JRPG combat. However, even as someone who normally dislikes that sort of thing, I found the combat rather enjoyable. Certain characters have very different playstyles, such as one who can only inflict status effects, and another who attacks through button combinations to do combos. Status effects have actual meaning, as opposed to other games in which it's better to go for straight up damage. In LISA, the status effects will work on every enemy, even the bosses, so there is variance in combat as opposed to just spam one move. Additionally, there are a bunch of party members spread around the game who play very differently, allowing for very varied playthroughs.

Writing: A very good blend of both drama and humor. Powerful and sad story with bits of dark (VERY dark) humor spread throughout. I don't laugh at a lot of games but this got me laughing out loud a couple of times. Lots of very likeable characters. Lots of very tough decisions must be made throughout the game. I believe the developer said at one point that he wanted the choices to be difficult instead of just an obvious THIS IS THE GOOD PATH CHOICE AND THIS IS THE BAD ONE, and it really shows.

Sound: The soundtrack is very well made, conveying emotion very well during the serious parts, and being rather silly during the funny parts. Some of the tunes are really catchy as well.

Overall, one my favorite games I've played. I'd say it's my 2nd favorite of all time, right behind Dwarf Fortress which will forever be the best. At only $10, I'd recommend picking it up, it's great. By the end, this game will have you saying, Did I do the right thing?""

reviewText:
This is probably one of the few game's I've played that was able to handle mature and serious subjects (Child Abuse, Drug Abuse, ♥♥♥♥, Mass Murdering Fathers) and deal them with a great amount of tact. Additionally the game was a blast to play, and made me laugh quite a bit.

The combat may be sort of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ vanilla RPG Maker battle system that some here may at first find stale, but the gameplay actually becomes rather entertaining with the sheer amount of Party Members and the teams you can build with them. Just exploring the odd world and soaking in the craziness, and the odd 2-D platforming. Some teams are obviously better than others and some might be even a bit OP, but it's always tempting to put on a talking Fish with legs on your team over your OG Terry. The punishing aspect of the game is in full force as well. Don't choose Pain Mode for a first run unless you are some sort of masocist like me. Even then don't do it because one of the best bosses in the game loses all his dialogue and character so I'm thinking of replaying simply to experience that again.

The story is also well crafted and told. The actual plot may seem to be rather conventional. It's like The Last of Us mixed with Children of Men + Fist of the North star and crazy wrestling references. But almost all the characters speak, act, and feel like real people. Real flawed, selfish, awful, but ultimately sympathizable people (except a certain 2). And the ending is absolutely perfect.

If I played this game back in 2014 it surely would be my GOTY. Now I feel sort of bad that I played it too late, because nothing this year has really topped it for me IMO.

reviewText:
This is probably one of the few game's I've played that was able to handle mature and serious subjects (Child Abuse, Drug Abuse, ♥♥♥♥, Mass Murdering Fathers) and deal them with a great amount of tact. Additionally the game was a blast to play, and made me laugh quite a bit.

The combat may be sort of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ vanilla RPG Maker battle system that some here may at first find stale, but the gameplay actually becomes rather entertaining with the sheer amount of Party Members and the teams you can build with them. Just exploring the odd world and soaking in the craziness, and the odd 2-D platforming. Some teams are obviously better than others and some might be even a bit OP, but it's always tempting to put on a talking Fish with legs on your team over your OG Terry. The punishing aspect of the game is in full force as well. Don't choose Pain Mode for a first run unless you are some sort of masocist like me. Even then don't do it because one of the best bosses in the game loses all his dialogue and character so I'm thinking of replaying simply to experience that again.

The story is also well crafted and told. The actual plot may seem to be rather conventional. It's like The Last of Us mixed with Children of Men + Fist of the North star and crazy wrestling references. But almost all the characters speak, act, and feel like real people. Real flawed, selfish, awful, but ultimately sympathizable people (except a certain 2). And the ending is absolutely perfect.

If I played this game back in 2014 it surely would be my GOTY. Now I feel sort of bad that I played it too late, because nothing this year has really topped it for me IMO.
