reviewText:
I normally don't make any reviews of games on Steam, but in this case I feel that it's only proper to make an exception, so bear with me.

Lisa is a sidescrolling RPG which tells the story of Brad, a down-on-his-luck former martial artist with a very unfortunate past. Brad sets out on a dangerous journey to find a girl who may prove to be crucial to the survival of the species.

Plot, in my opinion, is the strongest point of the game. It makes one think and consider various options, as well as theories. One could say that it provides some serious food for thought, and this wouldn't be an exaggeration. Choices that one makes on the way affect the gameplay and the game world in a few different ways. After all, this is a post-apocalyptic wasteland, you never know what lurks around the corner. The story is very dark, but there are also plenty of wacky, downright comical moments in the game.

What is more, this game has a pretty unique art style. It is very charming in its own way. Pretty much every character looks different and has personality. It reminds me of Earthbound (and rightfully so - supposedly, Earthbound was one of the dev's biggest inspirations). The soundtrack is also excellent - it features both quirky and serene pieces, and so everyone will find some appealing songs in it.

All things considered, I think that this is one of the strongest indie titles from 2014. A sequel/DLC is due in 10 days, so hopefully it will wrap-up certain characters arcs. I can sincerely recommend this game, it is definitely worth the asking price.

So, what are you waiting for? Step into the world of Olathe and have fun. :)

reviewText:
Pros:
- Mother/Earthbound inspired game (and let's face it, Mother is one of the best JRPGs known to mankind)
- 30+ recruitable companions, all with unique, different playstyles and personalities
- Brillant yet bizzare soundtrack, setting the tone of the game perfectly. I think it even rivals the Hotline Miami 2 soundtrack...
- Has many funny easter eggs and references
- Solid RPG gameplay; you'll get to level up characters, buy them gear, etc.
- The dialog the characters have is often super funny yet kinda ♥♥♥♥ed up
- Painful Mode is PAINFUL (don't play it on your first run like I attempted to do...)
- The combat is quick but flashy enough to make it fun. It seems complex at first, but it's really not
- The artstyle ranges from quirky and cute to creepy and disgusting
- Forced to make choices that matter while simultaneously make you feel like a worthless subhuman
- The main character, Brad, is someone you'll hate and love throughout the story
- The story is probably one of the best stories I have ever encountered in a video game. It's weird, dark, depressing and touches on subjects that not many games have attempted to approach. Now, that would make it seem pretentious... but it's not. The story is presented in such a blunt way that it makes you empathize with the characters instead of rolling your eyes at them.
- Be prepared to be punched in the feels ALOT
- This game made me depressed

Neutral:
- In a way, this game is a sequel to LISA: The First. Many people say you don't need to play LISA: The First, but I honestly feel like you do in order to understand the depth of the story.
- ♥♥♥♥ Buzzo... this actually has nothing to do with the review, but I just wanted to get that off my chest: ♥♥♥♥ that piece of mother♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥.
- The controls are confusing at first, but that's mostly due to this game being made in RPG maker. However, you can view the controls by pressing F12 and rebind them in anyway you please.

Cons:
- Cliffs ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off at times because if you fall off a cliff (which is likely to happen sooner or later) it's game over. Now, this isn't too much of a big deal in normal mode, since there are save points everywhere. However, in Painful mode, you can only save at a save point once, then it blows up and you can't use it again. Therefore, save points are precious and rare... and you're gonna lose a ton of progress by falling off a cliff.
- The intro is important and sets the tone of the game, but I feel like it dragged on for too long.
- Satan, an optional boss (and the hardest in the game), is disappointingly easy.

Get this game if you like video games.

reviewText:
A tragedy from start to finish that somehow manages to couple gigantic frustration and loss with qwirky humor.

One minute I'm laughing and the next I'm horrified and partially confused at what I'm seeing, which is a lot to say with the limited graphics chosen for the art style. The music follows this same trend - often so cheesy and low budget that you can't tell if it's intentional or... well, that low budget. However, the music (as well as other sound effects) come into play so appropriately to stear the mood or setup an upcoming scene that in the end it's all very appreciated and respected.

I've played through once, but there is so many secretes to unlock in this game that it will definitely draw a large crowd of players to come back searching for more... if you can stomach all the loss.

Truly unlike any game I've ever played before and in a good way... er, and a bad one : |

reviewText:
It's so good. Just. Really.

The soundtrack is absolutely amazing and will definitely evoke a little nostalgia for those who were fans of the Mother series. My personal favorite was Dandy Boy, which honestly made me jive a bit in my seat. There isn't a song that I didn't like in all honesty, and each one is used effectively, especially towards the end game.

The game's story was very enthralling and kept me coming back for more and more, ending up in long, long sessions where I'd just plow through areas in hopes to find even more quirky allies for my party. Don't grow too attached however, because this game has perma death. If you're like me then you'll retry the Russian Roulette section over and over until everyone in your party survives. And of course the game is very twisted in some aspects, but there are chunks of dark humor spread about like sprinkles on a scoop of blood flavored ice-cream.

It's good. Really good. I got it on sale for $5 and played it for 13 and a half hours, so I'd say I got my money's worth on this one.

If you like RPGs, dark humor, and an overall crushing atmosphere of despair and misery, then this is the game for you.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: On its surface, LISA is a pretty basic RPG with little technical innovation. You form a party, you travel around various areas, you take turns beating enemies. There are bosses and semi-secret areas. There are branching paths. You've played games like this before.\n\nWhat makes LISA special is not gameplay but narrative. It is unrelentingly dark. If Cormac McCarthy and Quentin Tarantino got together to write a video game, LISA would be it. You have to make choices that will genuinely upset you. Bad things will happen, sometimes randomly, sometimes because of something you did earlier, and all you can do is face the music. Humor shines like an oil slick on the ceaseless tide of suffering that the game presents. LISA is a study in misery, redemption, sacrifice, and betrayal, and yet it is deeply engaging and worthwhile in a way that few games today manage. It's the game everybody who grew up playing the same JRPG over and over again as a kid realizes that they deserved to be playing all along.

reviewText:
Not the masterpiece it was hyped to be, but still an insanely excellent game.

The story is great and came close to making me cry a couple of times.  The humor is a bit inconsistent in how it meshes with the story though.  Sometimes it can make an emotional/serious moment come across as a little odd, other times it blends really well with those moments and makes them stronger.  It's easy to get attached to any character you meet really and all of the characters are portrayed in a grey/neutral light which I really like in a post-apocalyptic setting personally.

The combat is good and the party members you meet all feel unique in their abilities.  The animation for combos and skills are all really nice and fun to look at (especially Rage Ironhead's LUCHA combos).  The game isn't too challenging, but it's hard enough to put some pressure on the player in key moments.  Mutants are designed really well and are actually pretty intimidating to fight.

What really surprises me about LISA though is the music.  In all the talk of LISA I've witnessed, nobody ever mentioned the music.  This ♥♥♥♥ is ♥♥♥♥ing excellent and really creates a sort of unique atmosphere during fights and during exploration.  it gets you pumped up in different ways or it creates a sort of wary, uncomfortable feeling that you probably won't like (see all the mutant fights).

Overall I'd highly recommend this game to just about anyone.  I really don't know who wouldn't like this game, it's just all around a fun and emotional ride.

reviewText:
This game...is rough. Not in a diffuculty sense, unless you play Pain Mode, but in an emotional sense.

In a story standard, better have a box of tissues nearby. This game will not hold back on the feels, because this deals with some heavy stuff. It would be best if you would play LISA: The First before any of this to understand the storyline. Then play this game, then Pain Mode, then the Joyful DLC. Or you could just...watch it on YouTube.

In a gameplay standard, it's amazing! Even though it's just an RPG, it's one of the most original ones I've encountered. Instead of an open world, you're limited to a 2D platformer, such as ones like Mario or Megaman. And with that 2D feature, there's different depths, adding to that platforming aspect. This world is very large; and if you don't know what you're doing, you're bound to get lost. With that open world comes a wacky cast of helpers, some serious, other just...weird. The fighting system is just like any other RPG, except, sometimes, your basic attack can input combos, which can lead to special moves!

The music is fantastic, too! It helps set the mood for whatever is happening in the game, and does it really well!

This game also requires patience. There's a lot of ways to die. And I mean A LOT. Brad moves kinda slow, but you'll get some faster way of transportation pretty early on.

Overall, buy this game, the soundtrack, the artbook, and the DLC. It is worth it.

reviewText:
Best Game I've played in years. Manages to pull so many emotions, making a very sad and disgusting story with interesting characters while also pulling off very clever and humourous writing.  Over 30 Unique party members that each offer something different with strategy-heavy gameplay (There is no OP or broken party memebers). Most of the choices that are made throughout the game are not for some excuse for showing one of many endings; but rather alter the gameplay, by taking away combos and decreasing the main characters attack or permanently killing off a crucial party member with no prior warning. There is no right or wrong in this game when it comes to choices. To summarise, LISA is a game with a very impressive atmosphere; It'll tell you a joke, make you laugh, then kick you in the balls. It'll force you to make choices that'll leave your stomach trembling and never goes easy on you. This game is incredible, and the fact that it was made in RPG Maker really goes to show that it doesn't matter how limitting the software or engine is, there are people that are creative, bold and willing to create something unique and near flawless.

Art Style - Amazing
Music - Amazing
Story - Amazing
Gameplay - Amazing
Writing - Amazing

If you haven't bought this game yet, do yourself a favour and pick it up, if you are even remotely interested in RPG's than it will not dissapoint.

reviewText:
My name is Brad. I am a Joy addict.

I lived a life with my abusive father, and my sister killed herself.

The women have gone. All of them. We do not know why or where.

I live with my three friends, and we would drink and take Joy and try to wait out the end. However, one day, I found a child. A young girl. With black hair. My little buddy. We agreed between the four of us that we would raise her alone, away from the men who would take her and hurt her and destroy her for their own selfish reasons.

We were happy, I think. One day I went to go and take drugs and Buddy was gone. Someone had found out. My friends were either gone or dead. I will not let anyone hurt her, I will not let anyone take her from me.

I begin to find friends in this world; a man obsessed with his chickens, a tiger man looking for a better master, a man who missed his wife, a magician who joined me for a deck of cards and a man who drank to forget the world, and others.

I would later met the Devil and kill him. My innocent actions would murder many. I would have to choose between my flesh and my needs. I weighed each pill I took in my misery. I would become a wrestling champion. I would meet the Red Skull. I would find my daughter, and I will kill anyone who hurts her.

I am so obsessed with this goal I don't stop to look at the river of blood behind me.

reviewText:
I would just like to say in advance that I've never reveiwed a game, so I am sorry for anything wrong with this.

I'm a guy. I'm 20. I'm in college. I've seen abuse first hand, I've been tormented by myself, and I've expirienced depression for as long as I can remember. I say all of this because it gives me credability to say that this game is, by far, the most saddening game I have ever played. There were several points in where I personally had to put the game down for a week or two just to think about everything that had happened. The story is so incredablity delicate in the way it makes a veiwer feel emotion that it is terrifying. I've been a writer for years, but I have never even come close to this level of artistry. I can't promise amazing graphics (it's pixel based), I can't promise an amazing combat system (it's basic), but what I could promise anyone that reads this is that if you play this game, you will never regret it.

To the developer: There are several points in the add-on that you thank us for supporting you. It's not you that should say that to us, we understand your appreciation in the quality that you've given us. You deserve much more notability than you will be given. Thank you.

reviewText: It's hard for me to explain exactly why I love this game, but I am gonna try.  This isn't a game for everyone.  It has unchangeable resolution, arrow key controls, very basic controller support, an overall depressing story, an archaic combat system, easily exploitable save systems, some strange glitches, and is very unforgiving with some of its mechanics.  But it's perfect.  I have never been this engrossed in a video game before.  Seiously.  Never.  The writting is fantastic, the story is enthralling, the characters are all intersting, the music is perfect, the combat is satistfying, and despite the old school influences, the mechanics are surprisingly very intuitive even by today's RPG standards.  During my origninal 10+ hour playthrough I felt sad, happy, depressed, scared, paranoid, angry, heartwarmed, confused, morally conflicted, and thouroughly entertained.\n\nAlso has butt humor.  10/10 DyBond's GOTY 2014

reviewText:
I'm not finished with the game. but I've just entered the 3rd section which I can guess will be the final part. Even though it's on sale right now I would buy this game for the full price with no question. This RPG is like nothing you have played before. It's a dark, yet hilariously written story with so much charm and attention to detail that I can't wait for anything this developer puts out in the future. To be honest I was just curious because of some of the reviews I read, but I thought it was just going to be a lazy side scroling game I'd try and stop within a couple hours. It seemed like my prediction was coming true for the first hour or two of the game, but man was I plesantly surprised to keep on playing.

I'll start with my only cons: It's short, it can be difficult to learn or play if you're not paying good attention, and the inventory system and lack of any kind of map can make you feel lost at times.

The Pros HIGHLY over shadow its cons: Dark gritty humor, incredible soundtrack, brilliant writing, deep emontial connections with child abuse, addiction, loss, and many topics I have not seen in video games to this date. If your a gamer like me, this really is a must play. You will make difficult decisions with outcomes you probably won't expect.

This is now one of my favorite RPG's I've played and that's saying something. Especially for being a 2D side scroller.
DO NOT give up because of the pace of the game until you get the bike! And by then you'll be hooked.

10/10. Just Brilliant, I need more!

reviewText:
To put it simply; An old school style RPG with a few tricks up it's sleeve.  Don't expect the game to hold your hand in terms of story telling or level progression as grinding feels required for certain segments.  Combat is not always straightforward as every character you recruit does not seem to be immediately useful without understanding what the heck their niche role is.

That's probably the worst I could say about the game.  I still highly recommend it but don't let the copious amounts of dark humor fool you, there will be a few parts where the tone suddenly becomes serious with the writing bringing home some surprisingly strong emotional impact especially towards the end.

All that being said playing or at least having a bit of knowledge of the free prequel LISA The First will probably help make sense of a lot of what's going on in Brad's head.

This is probably one of the best games I've ever played.  There's comedy,confusion, and a general creepiness.  This story does stupid, dark humor sometimes with unexpected turns.  I honestly can't explain it, it's just so strange in an amazing way.

Its plot is relatively straightforward.  Find the girl.  After the almost starwars-esqe introduction, you fight perverts, mutants, and your own inner demons.  All the while leaving the most memorable story from all the very strange people and places you end up visiting.

The characters lack a bit of plot, but add to the rediculousness of the whole game.  Many additions to the team are like, oh hi I'm going to join you" or need to be hired by using the in game currency of porno mags.  Some of the characters are so cool I'd glady give my left arm to keep them (maybe my right as well).

By the way this game has some extremly intersting lore.  Dont take joy."

reviewText:
Normally I'd be tempted to just make a really short and dumb review, but Lisa is an exception. The art, crazy music, and combat system is a throwback to earthbound days and it manages to also grab your heart and throw it in a pit, stomp on it repeatedly, then make you laugh again with a dark joke or two just after.

As great as the game is, it does have it's shortcomings, combat can be extremely repetitive, you can beat the entire game with just Brad if you want, but where is the fun in that? This game encourages you to explore all of your options and to really dig for the details, just be wary of the repetitive combat.

And the developer, Austin, props to you for managing to come up with a wide array of memorable characters and that unique as hell soundtrack. Thanks for the wild ride and screw you for making me want to die.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
A marvelous RPG with Earthbound elements.
The art style and narrative is definitely unique and quirky.

You go through a miserable journey as Brad.
You meet all sorts of people: perverted, funny, depressed, compulsive.
You can form a team of 4 to fight with you throughout your journey -- from a selection of up to 30 people.
You make some life-threatening decisions that may affect the difficulty of the gameplay.
You encounter various towns and cultures.
You get to see lots of blood and deformities.
You bask in its crude, dark humour.

Also, don't do drugs kids, 'cause withdrawal sucks.

reviewText:
It's so good. Just. Really.

The soundtrack is absolutely amazing and will definitely evoke a little nostalgia for those who were fans of the Mother series. My personal favorite was Dandy Boy, which honestly made me jive a bit in my seat. There isn't a song that I didn't like in all honesty, and each one is used effectively, especially towards the end game.

The game's story was very enthralling and kept me coming back for more and more, ending up in long, long sessions where I'd just plow through areas in hopes to find even more quirky allies for my party. Don't grow too attached however, because this game has perma death. If you're like me then you'll retry the Russian Roulette section over and over until everyone in your party survives. And of course the game is very twisted in some aspects, but there are chunks of dark humor spread about like sprinkles on a scoop of blood flavored ice-cream.

It's good. Really good. I got it on sale for $5 and played it for 13 and a half hours, so I'd say I got my money's worth on this one.

If you like RPGs, dark humor, and an overall crushing atmosphere of despair and misery, then this is the game for you.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
A tragedy from start to finish that somehow manages to couple gigantic frustration and loss with qwirky humor.

One minute I'm laughing and the next I'm horrified and partially confused at what I'm seeing, which is a lot to say with the limited graphics chosen for the art style. The music follows this same trend - often so cheesy and low budget that you can't tell if it's intentional or... well, that low budget. However, the music (as well as other sound effects) come into play so appropriately to stear the mood or setup an upcoming scene that in the end it's all very appreciated and respected.

I've played through once, but there is so many secretes to unlock in this game that it will definitely draw a large crowd of players to come back searching for more... if you can stomach all the loss.

Truly unlike any game I've ever played before and in a good way... er, and a bad one : |

reviewText:
If you like games that make you feel, then look no further. LISA will ♥♥♥♥ you up.

LISA is the most emotionally and morally challenging game I have ever played. It will confuse you, make you laugh and make you cry like a ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥. I like playing games that force you to take moral decisions, but while in other games all you often get is a finger wag and the game telling you you're a bad person, LISA actually makes you feel the consequences of your decisions throughout the whole game.

The story of Brad, the protagonist in LISA, is the saddest story I've ever played, read or seen. Never have I felt so much pity for a fictional character.
The developer, Dingaling as he calls himself, proved that he is very talented when it comes to story writing and I am already eagerly awaiting his next project. The same goes for the OST, the music is among the best I've heard in a game, it fits the situations you find yourself in perfectly. It pumps you up in one moment and brutally throws you into existential dread or pure nostalgia the next.

Honestly, I cannot recommend this game enough. The more I think about it, the more it's becoming one of my all-time favorites.

PS: I would also advise everyone that wants to know more about the story to play the free game LISA: The First, it's not available on Steam, but it can be downloaded on the game's website. It´s very short but it gives you a lot of important information about the story that is only implied in the LISA: The Painful.

reviewText:
Best Game I've played in years. Manages to pull so many emotions, making a very sad and disgusting story with interesting characters while also pulling off very clever and humourous writing.  Over 30 Unique party members that each offer something different with strategy-heavy gameplay (There is no OP or broken party memebers). Most of the choices that are made throughout the game are not for some excuse for showing one of many endings; but rather alter the gameplay, by taking away combos and decreasing the main characters attack or permanently killing off a crucial party member with no prior warning. There is no right or wrong in this game when it comes to choices. To summarise, LISA is a game with a very impressive atmosphere; It'll tell you a joke, make you laugh, then kick you in the balls. It'll force you to make choices that'll leave your stomach trembling and never goes easy on you. This game is incredible, and the fact that it was made in RPG Maker really goes to show that it doesn't matter how limitting the software or engine is, there are people that are creative, bold and willing to create something unique and near flawless.

Art Style - Amazing
Music - Amazing
Story - Amazing
Gameplay - Amazing
Writing - Amazing

If you haven't bought this game yet, do yourself a favour and pick it up, if you are even remotely interested in RPG's than it will not dissapoint.

reviewText:
Probably the most affecting game I've ever played, I sometimes had to take week-long breaks from it due to the sheer brutality in what it asks you to do by your own choice.
I don't normally play turn-based RPGs but the combat was decent enough to carry it, but the star of the show is the context in which you are in these combat situations, accompanied by an awesome soundtrack and arstyle with clever writing.

All of my issues are with the buggy nature of making this style of game in RPG Maker, frequently I would encounter bugs such as my screen going black after resting, which was fixable by using fast travel but then you have to rest again to fix the player animations; you learn early on that doing that can carry consequences.

Absolutely solid all-round game and provides an experience that you won't find anywhere else. Do yourself a favour and play without knowing anything about it and prepare to feel some pain.

reviewText:
This game is so manly it made my sister grow testicles and chest hair.

Its combat system is very similar to mother/earth bound, and its world design is some what reminiscent of the 2D Mario platformers, though only in appearance. the story is immersive and gives you choices during key moments in the game, even leaving the resolution in your hands. there are many different areas and many different characters, each with their own story. there is a thick layer of mystery wrapped around this game, and the ending is some what of a cliff hanger. but there is a sequel in the works.

PROS
-very repalyable
-fun and simple combat system
-large amount of party members to recruit
-many different secret areas which can easily be passed up and require a very perceptive player to find
-a fairly large world  which is evenly passed and by no means streamlined
-many different weapons and armor which you can equip to your party members
-a large arsenal of items which each have a unique effect and different degrees of rarity
-the game creates a feeling that prevails through the lower quality graphics and sticks with the player
-very good story telling

NEUTRAL
-Retro design
-goofy at times
-many tonal shifts
-can make you feel bad (not kidding)

CONS
-leaves many elements unexplained, thus requiring that the player buys the sequel in order to get the whole story
-minimal bugs found through out the game wich only detract from the atmosphere rather than ruining the game.

over all this is a very good game that is deserving of its price. though it may not be as big or fancy as something like fallout, it doesn't have nearly as many downsides to it.

reviewText:
Obscenity is hard. Obscenity can get bogged down in being too stupid, too shocking, too crass. In order to make obscenity into something meaningful, it needs coherence. Enough coherence to counterbalance the revulsion of the content. LISA, remarkably, navigates this balance beam.

It offers plenty of strange, dirty, cruel content, but all with context. The comedy's juxtaposition with the tragedy isn't just for contrast, it's works thematically as well. The lighthearted fantasy alongside cutthroat survival, both in world building and in gameplay, mesh entirely with the narrative's ultimate goals.

But this isn't a visual novel or something, it's a game too. And it's a fun, surprisingly balanced game, especially considering the single-man production. There are a ton of party members, and most of them feel distinct in theme as well as in gameplay. You can set up a team with lots of fun, powerful combinations, and there aren't too many ways to go wrong. Equipment upgrades are infrequent and expensive enough to feel meaningful. Resources both feel tight because of scarcity, and loose because of anticipated demise. Other than the occasional dark cave or grassy field, all battles are satisfyingly non-random. This kind of gameplay balance is tough for bigger games to manage, so it's a bit wondrous how well it works in LISA.

I waited to buy LISA on sale, because we all have a backlog of games now. But I put it at the top of my que, and it was worth the favoritism. LISA was well developed enough, meaningful enough, and satisfying enough that I'd freely recommend it at the full $10 price tag. I have spent $10 more poorly many, many times.

reviewText: This is a pretty short game - Steam clocked about 17 hours for my first playthrough - but it is one hell of a ride from start to finish. It is hilarious, sad, uncomfortable, and terrifying, but always great and rarely goes too far with its subject matter (though be warned, it still goes far). Battles are simple, but satisfying with a combo system that allows some additional flexibility with battle strategy, a varied cast of party members to play with, the occasional looming threat of instant and unavoidable permadeath for your companions (don't worry, there's not *too* much shame in save-scumming), and an absolutely killer soundtrack to accompany it. The soundtrack is stellar all around, really; if you get this game, be sure to grab the Deluxe edition if only for that.\n\nIf you're looking for a light-hearted game, you might want to skip this one; even the humor is often firmly on the dark side (though it will give you a good fart joke or two). If an R-rated, incredibly messed up Earthbound sounds like your cup of tea? You probably want this game.

reviewText:
*WARNING* THIS GAME IS A SEQUEL TO A GAME CALLED 'LISA: THE FIRST', A MAJOR PLOTPOINT WILL BE CONFUSING AND MAKE NO SENCE, SO GO PLAY THAT.

LISA is on the same par as classics like MOTHER 3 and FFVII, and this game is sure to go down in history as one of the greatest RPGs ever made. This game is brutal in every sense of the word, the game can be soul-crushingly challenging, gut-bustingly hilarious, and unfathomably depressing and somber. The game's strongest aspect is the fantastic story that  takes you on a grand quest to save your adopted daughter and shelter her from the cruel and unforgiving world that seeks to use her for its own gain. The game will constantly be throwing very heavy descisions at you, and unlike games like Mass Effect or The Walking Dead, your actions have very serous immediate and long term effects that change gameplay, the story, and the world as a whole. There are over 30 different followers for you to recruit on your journey, and it is incredibly easy to miss out on meeting new allies, and it's also incredibly easy to permanently loose them. Combat in this game is your somewhat standard turn-based RPG affair, but there are plenty of clever twists that make fighting more fun and memorable, like characters that input combos, build up a special meter, and characters who buff and heal the party. This game is somewhat bipolar, and the constant switching between (incredibly funnycomedy and tragedy makes the game a very surreal experience, and the mood whiplash can leave you completley flabbergasted. If i had any real problems with the game it would be the lack of a map, although you gain the ability to warp to and from specific zones, which somewhat help the issue. People who are easily lost or have no navigational abilities what-so-ever will have trouble navigating the world, and will end up very frustrated.

Prepare your feel hole for complete and udder destruction. this is the single saddest experience i have ever felt, and ihave spent long sleepless nights staring into my ceiling, lost in thought. If you are emotionally unstable, this game WILL break you.

TL;DR, I would give this game a 10/10, it is a masterpiece, and nearly every sprite has tiny cute nipples.

TERRY HINTLORD IS BEST CHARACTER, CONFIRMED BY DEV

reviewText:
I don't like this type of games,I don't like long dialogues,I don't like mechanics like this,I don't like dark humour,but listen.

This game is awesome.

I never thought game like this will catch me that much that I want to play it my every single free moment.Spoiler of first 5 minutes of game.You are victim of a bullies from school,your's father is alcoholic who hates you,and then you are the men who find a baby on a desert and want to protect it. You are addicted to drugs but you love your baby and want to cover it from the world because there are no womens left on the world.You think this story is solid?Of course it is,and it's even more solid when you go further.I want to knowledge whole story of this game,I always care more about mechanics then about story because I like crafting,free world and stuff that are not included in this game but I love this game even if it don't have what I love.Why?

Here are the Pros:
+++very very very solid story
+++humour is dark but in that way you will love it
+++world is kinda open.It's not closed,you can back to certain locaction even very back or even back to beginning.World is huge,sometimes you will lost in this huge world.
+++nice animations how you attack with characters in battles
+++great,awesome soundtrack.You will not get tired of music because it's always changing,only in two or three locations the music is the same but every location have like own music.It's great,you not get tired because you listen to one dump song,you enjoy music because it's always changing and music fits the atmosphere of apocalypse-trash world.
++if you jump from too high you will take a damage with is nice because it's realistic
+nice platforming jumping system from higher to lower location.

So here are minor cons of this game:
-sometimes you will fall down because you go too fast on a vehicle and need to repeat something because you don't save.
-you need to back to certain location like 2-3 times.
-you will lose like 6 companions after 7 hours of playing but you will have like 8 so it will be little pain.


I rate this game 20/10 because I don't like this type of games but this game changed my point of view on this type of games.

Edit:
Ok,so I end this game after 12 hours and must say it......For the first time I cried because of a history in a game.I hate games what makes me cries but w/e,I can cry if history is that good.

reviewText: LISA is a great example of why the future of gaming lies in Indie titles, and not AAA releases.  To keep this brief, LISA is a relatively short and brutal game that manages to surpass some of the greatest video game stories out there.  The faint of heart and easily offended need not apply.  Many, many risks were taken in the creation of the world portrayed in LISA, and in my opinion, those risks paid off bigtime.  I will support any future titles by Austin in the future, and would be overjoyed to see any new content in the LISA universe, even if it may not pick up where Brad's or Buddy's stories left off.  Absolutely 100% recommend this game to anybody who is looking for a deep and interesting story, a challenging game, or anyone who is looking to enjoy a game which captures the SNES-esque 16-bit pixel aesthetic perfectly.  If there were ever a perfect game, this comes pretty close to it.  9/10!

reviewText:
So, before I begin, I would like to thank Dingaling for providing a fresh and fun entry into the indie genre, one that has affected me and many others greatly, and hopefully will endure the test of time.

I feel that the first thing I should do is address the drawing of parallels between Undertale and LISA. These games may share quite a bit, but it is absolutely NOT worth comparing the two, as they share completely different themes and gameplay focuses. Undertale's focus is more on gathering friendships and the value of those friendships. Undertale likes to be fair(so long as you are going pacifist), and will reward you for playing along. LISA is a take on how everything can be taken away from us in the blink of an eye, even if you DO play along. Choices you make will be difficult, they will have an effect on you in the moment, and will make your journey significantly more difficult, as you cannot avoid these decisions.

It's unfair.

Life is unfair.

I will now break down LISA into pros/cons like the good little reviewer I was born to be.

Pros:
-Great soundtrack, I still listen to a few of the songs on my own time, and each area has it's own little (widdly2)diddly as you walk about and absorb the atmosphere.

-Incredible atmosphere, LISA is hopeless, you will feel hopeless, but that's part of the enjoyment, the comedy given to you in the form of characters and wacky situations help raise your spirits to give you the motivation to continue on regardless.

-Story(?), LISA easily has one of the most dark and inhuman storylines of any game I've ever had the pleasure of playing, it will destroy your sense of being and bring you back to the light only to send you back to hell. It makes you feel things. It's good.

-Combat(?), Although many would say combat was the shortcoming of LISA, I actually found it a bit fun, it works on a basic WASD dial combo system to dial in skills for extra damage. If you were too lazy to learn the combos yourself, you could simply circumvent the dial combos and go straight to the skill menu. This feature was a blessing and a curse, the latter I will explain later.

-Art, The art was nothing special to be honest, but it was definitely really good and the earthy tones really helped convey the tone Dingaling was going for.

Now, onto our cons.

-Difficulty Curve, LISA's main selling point may just be it's downfall. It's hard. This game was incredibly hard in it's beginning stages, albeit it becomes easier as the game goes on, it almost turned me off and has actually turned off many other players from continuing the game. Anyone who buys this needs to understand that you'll need to push past that first crossroads before the game picks up and you can actually fight things.

-Combat(?), LISA's combat is a real crapshoot, you either like it or hate it, or who knows, you might be fine with it, but it definitely wasn't anything revolutionary and ESPECIALLY in the beginning stages it's tedious as hell and can really get frustrating to fight anything. It gets better later on, but as I said, the steep curve of this game turns players off right from the beginning without showing them a light at the end of the tunnel

-Story(?), LISA's story is ♥♥♥♥ed up, and for the most people, hardly relateable. It's really dark and depending on your life experiences you will either become enthralled in it's world or be completely turned off by it's harshness. Really a matter of preference.

-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ING CLIFFS, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T

Overall, I rate LISA:The Painful RPG a 8/10, could have been better on the mechanics side of thing, but overall an amazing title and a great addition to anyone's library.

reviewText:
Right, let's take it from the top.
Lisa: The Painful is crazy. It sets the player in the shoes of one Brad Armstrong in his morbid, fairly depressing voyage through a world of men. It's dark, but there are still plenty of moments of light to be found; little moments of humor, life, and hope that keep you from throwing your computer and yourself out the window. The atmosphere is desolate but rich with strange and interesting character and more possible gang members than you can count on one hand. It's a tragedy where the only ending is sorrow, and one can't help but find themselves caught up in the strangeness of the land of Olathe.
Lisa: The Joyful, on the other hand, takes place as a sequel; it comes off as a bit more emotionally mature throughout and darker in tone, but still managed to keep me invested throughout. You play as Buddy, the young girl Brad searches for throughout the previous game, on her quest for... freedom, I suppose, would be the best word. Freedom from anyone daring to control her, freedom from anyone trying to shelter her, freedom from a vicious cycle passed down through a thoroughly messed up family. In the end it helped deepen my understanding of the characters and the world while still leaving me with questions, both for in the game and out.
Overall, I'd recommend getting LISA if you're a fan of well-made RPG Maker style RPGs, deep moral thoughts and issues, dark storylines, and a fascinating world after an unusual apocalypse.

I backed LISA on Kickstarter a year ago and never regretted it.

Post apocalyptic setting, a combination of black humour and gritty atmosphere, funky soundtrack and engrossing gameplay. Beware, choices in-game will have impact on you and your crew (ransom, decapitation, dismemberment etc).

reviewText:
If you like games that make you feel, then look no further. LISA will ♥♥♥♥ you up.

LISA is the most emotionally and morally challenging game I have ever played. It will confuse you, make you laugh and make you cry like a ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥. I like playing games that force you to take moral decisions, but while in other games all you often get is a finger wag and the game telling you you're a bad person, LISA actually makes you feel the consequences of your decisions throughout the whole game.

The story of Brad, the protagonist in LISA, is the saddest story I've ever played, read or seen. Never have I felt so much pity for a fictional character.
The developer, Dingaling as he calls himself, proved that he is very talented when it comes to story writing and I am already eagerly awaiting his next project. The same goes for the OST, the music is among the best I've heard in a game, it fits the situations you find yourself in perfectly. It pumps you up in one moment and brutally throws you into existential dread or pure nostalgia the next.

Honestly, I cannot recommend this game enough. The more I think about it, the more it's becoming one of my all-time favorites.

PS: I would also advise everyone that wants to know more about the story to play the free game LISA: The First, it's not available on Steam, but it can be downloaded on the game's website. It´s very short but it gives you a lot of important information about the story that is only implied in the LISA: The Painful.

reviewText:
Obscenity is hard. Obscenity can get bogged down in being too stupid, too shocking, too crass. In order to make obscenity into something meaningful, it needs coherence. Enough coherence to counterbalance the revulsion of the content. LISA, remarkably, navigates this balance beam.

It offers plenty of strange, dirty, cruel content, but all with context. The comedy's juxtaposition with the tragedy isn't just for contrast, it's works thematically as well. The lighthearted fantasy alongside cutthroat survival, both in world building and in gameplay, mesh entirely with the narrative's ultimate goals.

But this isn't a visual novel or something, it's a game too. And it's a fun, surprisingly balanced game, especially considering the single-man production. There are a ton of party members, and most of them feel distinct in theme as well as in gameplay. You can set up a team with lots of fun, powerful combinations, and there aren't too many ways to go wrong. Equipment upgrades are infrequent and expensive enough to feel meaningful. Resources both feel tight because of scarcity, and loose because of anticipated demise. Other than the occasional dark cave or grassy field, all battles are satisfyingly non-random. This kind of gameplay balance is tough for bigger games to manage, so it's a bit wondrous how well it works in LISA.

I waited to buy LISA on sale, because we all have a backlog of games now. But I put it at the top of my que, and it was worth the favoritism. LISA was well developed enough, meaningful enough, and satisfying enough that I'd freely recommend it at the full $10 price tag. I have spent $10 more poorly many, many times.

reviewText:
Easily one of the best games I've ever played. It has an unique style, and it sure delivers. It can be really sad, terrifying or downright hilarious, but it's always deep. Even in funny moments, dark humor, satire or grotesque situations make you laugh and think at the same time, nothing pass unnoticed. It really touches some REALLY (and I mean REALLY) complicated issues, like child abuse, abusive parents, heavy drug use and how it affects relationships, and even some really twisted stuff. If you like this kind of game and are up for a rather odd yet amazing journey, this is most definitely your game.

If you care about it, I can point the pros and cons:

PROS
>Superb story
>Nice level design, really original sometimes. Even landscapes makes you laugh sometimes!
>Amazing humor, seriously if you love dark humor this is a most buy
>Great soundtrack, similar to Hotline Miami (just not as good)
>Complex moral issues, touched in a really humane and sensitive way. Everything happens seen through the messed up eyes of the diferent people in this world, everyone with some really intense lifes, to say the least.
>A lot of companions and diversity in general
>The art style was odd at the beginning to be honest, but its so well made that I love it now.

CONS
>Edges are completely non forgiving, and ropes are near edges sometimes. There is no quicksave nor autosave so it can end bad. And it will of course, but I reckon it was made on purpose just to mess with you just a little more. It's really rage inducing tho.
>Just as a warning: yes, it can be really hard, unforgiving and tedious sometimes. All I can say is: get good. Don't be defeated by a game you pleb, you are better than that.



Now, it IS true that the ending is kind of cut into a DLC. But I personaly don't agree with that because this game in particular is Brad's journey with his problems, completely diferent to The Joyful story plot. So, its more like the global ending is a DLC but this game alone isn't focused on nothing more than Brad.

reviewText:
LISA, or to give it its full name, LISA The Painful RPG. Painful is right, as you adventure with Brad to save his adopted daughter you'll struggle with addiction, meet characters who have been through hell, maybe even watch some of your favorite ones die before you. Worst of all you'll feel like a lot of it will be your fault as LISA forces you to make tough decisions with no right answer; dismemberment or death? Sacrifice all your items or sacrifice your only friend? The story is a simple and personal one. There's no world to save, just a very important girl. It hits hard and it's wonderfully engaging. You'll always want to know what happens next. Having said that, it isn't always so downtrodden in tone. LISA also manages to work a lot of humour into its setting and characters. A bunch of middle aged men doing bad Power Rangers impressions, the Mexican guy whose main attributes are crying and hitting enemies with a truck and so much more.

The story is complimented by a soundtrack that is often sombre and occasional lighthearted, thus it fits the mood of the environments and the events perfectly.

Of course there's more to the game than the story. The gameplay is great for those who like turn based RPGS, especially Earthbound as this game is heavily inspired by it. Though there is more to the combat than just choose enemy
recommended: and there are a lot of different characters
hoursPlayed: have different combat styles. For Brad's attacks you have to input button combinations for example. Outside of combat the gameplay is very simple. You mostly just move left and right without any platforming. Moreoever the story and combat are meshed together very well. Certain choices you make will affect how characters behave in combat. It's difficult to say without spoiling it. One example is that  you may chose to save a friend or have on of Brad's arms removed. After the amputation Brad loses a lot of his powerful combos
voteText: since he now only has one arm.\n\nTo summarise
helpfulPercent: LISA is a tough experience that'll make you laugh and maybe cry. It'll make you feel like ♥♥♥♥ at times but you'll always want to come back for more because of the endearing characters that yuo'll no doubt want to see succeed."

reviewText:
So, before I begin, I would like to thank Dingaling for providing a fresh and fun entry into the indie genre, one that has affected me and many others greatly, and hopefully will endure the test of time.

I feel that the first thing I should do is address the drawing of parallels between Undertale and LISA. These games may share quite a bit, but it is absolutely NOT worth comparing the two, as they share completely different themes and gameplay focuses. Undertale's focus is more on gathering friendships and the value of those friendships. Undertale likes to be fair(so long as you are going pacifist), and will reward you for playing along. LISA is a take on how everything can be taken away from us in the blink of an eye, even if you DO play along. Choices you make will be difficult, they will have an effect on you in the moment, and will make your journey significantly more difficult, as you cannot avoid these decisions.

It's unfair.

Life is unfair.

I will now break down LISA into pros/cons like the good little reviewer I was born to be.

Pros:
-Great soundtrack, I still listen to a few of the songs on my own time, and each area has it's own little (widdly2)diddly as you walk about and absorb the atmosphere.

-Incredible atmosphere, LISA is hopeless, you will feel hopeless, but that's part of the enjoyment, the comedy given to you in the form of characters and wacky situations help raise your spirits to give you the motivation to continue on regardless.

-Story(?), LISA easily has one of the most dark and inhuman storylines of any game I've ever had the pleasure of playing, it will destroy your sense of being and bring you back to the light only to send you back to hell. It makes you feel things. It's good.

-Combat(?), Although many would say combat was the shortcoming of LISA, I actually found it a bit fun, it works on a basic WASD dial combo system to dial in skills for extra damage. If you were too lazy to learn the combos yourself, you could simply circumvent the dial combos and go straight to the skill menu. This feature was a blessing and a curse, the latter I will explain later.

-Art, The art was nothing special to be honest, but it was definitely really good and the earthy tones really helped convey the tone Dingaling was going for.

Now, onto our cons.

-Difficulty Curve, LISA's main selling point may just be it's downfall. It's hard. This game was incredibly hard in it's beginning stages, albeit it becomes easier as the game goes on, it almost turned me off and has actually turned off many other players from continuing the game. Anyone who buys this needs to understand that you'll need to push past that first crossroads before the game picks up and you can actually fight things.

-Combat(?), LISA's combat is a real crapshoot, you either like it or hate it, or who knows, you might be fine with it, but it definitely wasn't anything revolutionary and ESPECIALLY in the beginning stages it's tedious as hell and can really get frustrating to fight anything. It gets better later on, but as I said, the steep curve of this game turns players off right from the beginning without showing them a light at the end of the tunnel

-Story(?), LISA's story is ♥♥♥♥ed up, and for the most people, hardly relateable. It's really dark and depending on your life experiences you will either become enthralled in it's world or be completely turned off by it's harshness. Really a matter of preference.

-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ING CLIFFS, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T

Overall, I rate LISA:The Painful RPG a 8/10, could have been better on the mechanics side of thing, but overall an amazing title and a great addition to anyone's library.

reviewText: I've played through this game several times now, and I can say it's easily one of my favorite games of all time. To be fair, LISA isn't for the faint of heart. The subject matters are really unnerving, but that's part of what makes it amazing. Everything within the game makes sense in the context of the game, the characters, the music, the writing, the difficulty, everything. I haven't been this passionate about a game in a long time, and i've played through it 4 times. I suggest this game highly.

reviewText: I don't think I've felt this many different types of emotions from any other form of media. This is definitely a game that is not only a work of art, but a masterpiece at that.  The amount of work put into this title is astronomical, and being that I purchase this title for $5, I feel like I owe the developer even more than the original $10. Just a marvelous gem of a title. Brad Armstrong is one of the greatest protagonists in video game history simply due to his raw emotion. Brad is a human, and isn't just some macho space marine, or an action hero. He is the epitome of a broken man. Lisa the Painful, if I had to give it any rating is a perfect 10 out 10. I one day hope this gets ported to consoles so even more people can experience this journey of misery, addiction, pain, loss, dark humor, hatred of Dale Spooner, and passion.

reviewText:
To put it simply; An old school style RPG with a few tricks up it's sleeve.  Don't expect the game to hold your hand in terms of story telling or level progression as grinding feels required for certain segments.  Combat is not always straightforward as every character you recruit does not seem to be immediately useful without understanding what the heck their niche role is.

That's probably the worst I could say about the game.  I still highly recommend it but don't let the copious amounts of dark humor fool you, there will be a few parts where the tone suddenly becomes serious with the writing bringing home some surprisingly strong emotional impact especially towards the end.

All that being said playing or at least having a bit of knowledge of the free prequel LISA The First will probably help make sense of a lot of what's going on in Brad's head.

reviewText:
I want to write a review mostly because the game was on sales so many people bought it. First off, if you have no idea what this game is about and want to find out more watch the trailer. Don't go to the negative reviews. People with 30 minutes of gameplay say some random ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t for no reason without reasonable arguements.

Anyways, like everyone has said the game is inspired by Earthbound. If you're familiar with Earthbound then you'll quickly grasp the combat system. The game is kinda difficult, I struggled at some certain parts but in my first run I did way better than I expected. The story is amazing and really emotional. Austin (the developer) has done an amazing job with the plot and apart from all the emotion the humor in this game is just ... amazing.
The game isn't gonna go easy on you. I realised that in the first hour. You're gonna need to make choices, important choices. You need to think of the correct choices that benefit your main character and that was harsh for someone like me who likes to have many companions.
Up so far, Lisa is for me the best game I've played in 2015 (We will see if Lisa the Joyful can top this game). You should buy this game and you should go through the emotional rollercoaster I went through. 10/10

reviewText: This is a pretty short game - Steam clocked about 17 hours for my first playthrough - but it is one hell of a ride from start to finish. It is hilarious, sad, uncomfortable, and terrifying, but always great and rarely goes too far with its subject matter (though be warned, it still goes far). Battles are simple, but satisfying with a combo system that allows some additional flexibility with battle strategy, a varied cast of party members to play with, the occasional looming threat of instant and unavoidable permadeath for your companions (don't worry, there's not *too* much shame in save-scumming), and an absolutely killer soundtrack to accompany it. The soundtrack is stellar all around, really; if you get this game, be sure to grab the Deluxe edition if only for that.\n\nIf you're looking for a light-hearted game, you might want to skip this one; even the humor is often firmly on the dark side (though it will give you a good fart joke or two). If an R-rated, incredibly messed up Earthbound sounds like your cup of tea? You probably want this game.

reviewText: LISA is a great example of why the future of gaming lies in Indie titles, and not AAA releases.  To keep this brief, LISA is a relatively short and brutal game that manages to surpass some of the greatest video game stories out there.  The faint of heart and easily offended need not apply.  Many, many risks were taken in the creation of the world portrayed in LISA, and in my opinion, those risks paid off bigtime.  I will support any future titles by Austin in the future, and would be overjoyed to see any new content in the LISA universe, even if it may not pick up where Brad's or Buddy's stories left off.  Absolutely 100% recommend this game to anybody who is looking for a deep and interesting story, a challenging game, or anyone who is looking to enjoy a game which captures the SNES-esque 16-bit pixel aesthetic perfectly.  If there were ever a perfect game, this comes pretty close to it.  9/10!

reviewText: LISA is a strange game. On the surface, it seems like yet another RPG but the story is incredibly disturbing. This game does not pull punches; talking freely about tough subjects like cross dressing, ♥♥♥♥, suicide and other dark topics. When one of the minigames is Russian Roulette where you must sacrifice a party member for potential money, you can't help but feel like an enabler. The game revolves around an apocalpyse with no women around and no way to humanity to survive. The sudden mention of a girl being alive sparks a war where brothers are willing to kill one another for a chance of their genes being passed on. If you want to know what depression feels like, give this game a try.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Imagine Undertale, but everyone had depression and you had to kill your friends to continue playing. There are no good endings, and no bad endings, only this; would you sacrifice everything to continue looking for someone you love?

While it may not be as brutal as this, LISA tells the story of a broken man with a broken childhood, surviving solely on medication to forget his troubles. All women have gone extinct, leaving humanity to rot as the world slowly crumbles. All women, except the baby that fell into your hands. Once she goes missing, you vow to do whatever it takes to get her back, even if it means your life. And then, the game starts.

One of the only times in a video game where I laughed with utter amusement and choked up a little within 20 minutes of each other, it is truly an experience that can't be missed. From funny dialogue to memorable characters, this is the closest thing to a future cult classic I can think of.

Have fun, ya no-armed freak! :)

reviewText: LISA! The RPG game where you have to destroy everyone.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
LISA can be compared to another other RPGs, but that isn't terribly fair to it. LISA is a game about sacrifice in an insane world filled with less than pleasant things. Nobody's really the good guy or the bad guy, death is everywhere and the only real constant, and things may not be getting any better no matter what you do.

So just ride with it, do what you think should be done, try to stay true to something and have it be your choice. Even if it's a terribly sucky choice that you have absolutely no control over and will end badly. Because that's what LISA's all about. Choices, but often forced by those who really should have made better ones earlier.

Gameplay-wise, LISA is a turn-based quirky game filled with humor both surreal and pitch black. Lots of replay value in the many many party members you have allowing you to take different folks through the game where necessary to make different choices from your last run. If you choose to experience every possible route. Though that said there aren't many huge differences from each route, and despite the ethical feelings these choices can lead to, ultimately they're just different kinds of sacrifices that don't lead to some kind of end all golden ending. It plays well and is super challenging, forcing you to adapt quickly and not focus on just grinding things out but instead exploring as much as you can while confronting the insane denizens around you and probably killing them all horribly in the process.

Strongly recommended unless you have a weak stomach, this is a game that will stomp all over you even if you're ready for it. The title screen is of the titual character Lisa already dead and hanging, it's just going to get worse from there. Much much worse.

reviewText:
Set in a world where women have been brought into extinction, only men with broken dreams, minds and ambitions remain.

A very popular drug called Joy runs rampant  warping people into disgusting mutants after extended use. You are one of these Joy takers, a man named Brad. Brad finds a baby, the baby is a girl. This is where the story and obscenely
difficult choices to protect her innocence begin.

Sounds depressing? It is, this games ending broke me. It was beautiful and left me with many emotions days after playing. Why do I recommend this game? Mostly the fantastic dialogue melded into the story using both dark humour, and weighty choices.

The gameplay is very simplistic but organic enough to encourage multiple playthroughs, sporting a challenge mode and many recruitable followers. The overworld gameplay is platforming, both walking and riding a suprisingly durable bike will help you traverse the terrain, the battle mechanics are the simplistic turn-based battles seen in the Earthbound series. The combat never got old in the 9-14 hours of gameplay mostly due to the imput of certain keys to create powerful combos with certain characters.

The music, while somewhat repetitious in a few places is fantasic, yet it almost feels ill fitting of the game you are playing due to the strangeness of the world; yet at the same time it somehow comes together to create something absurdly beautiful.

The game is stylised in a matter very familar to Earthbound players, yet I would say it works a lot better here. Brad is a warped individual and this is often shown in flashbacks and hallucinations leaving you not knowing for sure if the many characters are always what they seem to be. Colourful, creative and often frightening, they do their job very well.

The game does however have a few minor flaws. The options and key binding menu is a little ugly and unintuitive, some of the bosses can feel luck based at times leading to some frustratiton.

Thank you for reading this review, I really hope it convinces you to buy this fantastic game!

reviewText: You WILL feel ashamed of your words and deeds.

reviewText:
My name is Brad. I am a Joy addict.

I lived a life with my abusive father, and my sister killed herself.

The women have gone. All of them. We do not know why or where.

I live with my three friends, and we would drink and take Joy and try to wait out the end. However, one day, I found a child. A young girl. With black hair. My little buddy. We agreed between the four of us that we would raise her alone, away from the men who would take her and hurt her and destroy her for their own selfish reasons.

We were happy, I think. One day I went to go and take drugs and Buddy was gone. Someone had found out. My friends were either gone or dead. I will not let anyone hurt her, I will not let anyone take her from me.

I begin to find friends in this world; a man obsessed with his chickens, a tiger man looking for a better master, a man who missed his wife, a magician who joined me for a deck of cards and a man who drank to forget the world, and others.

I would later met the Devil and kill him. My innocent actions would murder many. I would have to choose between my flesh and my needs. I weighed each pill I took in my misery. I would become a wrestling champion. I would meet the Red Skull. I would find my daughter, and I will kill anyone who hurts her.

I am so obsessed with this goal I don't stop to look at the river of blood behind me.

I really liked this game. It's your standard turn-based RPG, but with the feature of dial combos with other characters. Lots of companions to have on your side, story that gets pretty deep and dark, and very well-made soundtrack. All of this for 10$... I would honestly say it's not worth it. If it were to go down to 5$-7$ instead, then it is totally worth it. Expect 8-15 hours of gameplay

THINGS TO NOT FREAK OUT ABOUT:

reviewText:
This is a type of game that is hard to come by nowadays. Hell, any media like this is impossible to find it seems. It is what it is, it's very plain about that. It refuses to tell you what to feel. It does not coddle your feelings. It will ♥♥♥♥ you up, and you will enjoy every bit of it.

For me at least, where other story-rich games fall short is their utter dishonesty about humanity. This game tells a story that, with an adjustment of setting and situation of course, could be found in the real world. A story of perversion, of addiction, of violence, of insanity. It is relatable because of that. Undertale displays humanity through the mind of an immature 13-year-old: it is always good in the end, there is good in everyone, etc. And that is a blatant lie.

The atmosphere of the game is something I have never encountered before, the utter insanity of it was comforting, in a weird way. It did so well with so little that you can't help but smirk when finding a few select areas. The artstyle of the game contributed to this immensely, being uneasily cheery given the situation.

The story of the game is barebones, but impeccably done. Brad is, as stated by the game, a broken man. A childhood of abuse lay behind him, and the haunting visions of his past consume him. He looks for redemption, gives his body and life for it, and still he gets nothing. There is something to be learned in that.

The music was pretty damn good. It is something of a drug-laced version of rave music and just works so well with the overall direction of the game.

The gameplay is this games shortcoming, however, as it is an RPG-Maker game. If you have decent experience with computer gaming however those aren't that much of problems. The game itself is a bit clunky, the controls can really ♥♥♥♥ you off, especially in Pain mode. Nothing like spending an hour in game then losing it all after walking off of a cliff.

Overall, this is an EXCELLENT sophomore production from Dingaling, and even more impressive considering that this was made by one person. I give it a solid 9/10, and worth anyone's time if they have it to be spared.

Oh, and joy is never what it seems.

reviewText:
Lisa definitely isn't a game for everyone. It has some dark and deep subjects matters. But for those who can enjoy a thought provoking game with dark humor, this is a must buy. Lisa the Painful is a game about a man named brad. He's a recovering drug addict  who lives in a post apocalyptic world that lacks women. One day while out on a daily stroll brad comes across a baby. After checking the baby's gender brad realizes he's come across the last girl in existence. One of his friends recommends that he give the baby up, but he decides to keep it and raise it as his own. One day after a walk brad finds that his adopted daughter  had been captured by a group that plan on repopulating the earth.
Game play wise, battling is your average RPG affair, but what Lisa changes is your party member's, there's a lot of them, and they're all really expendable, when you start to feel an emotional attachment to a character, there's nothing more sad than seeing them die.
This game also has a lot of eater eggs, like a lot of them. I mean after 3 or 4 play throughs there's still a lot to see.
I'll have to give Lisa a 10/10. It was one of the best games of 2015. (Even though it was released in 2014.)

reviewText:
LISA can be compared to another other RPGs, but that isn't terribly fair to it. LISA is a game about sacrifice in an insane world filled with less than pleasant things. Nobody's really the good guy or the bad guy, death is everywhere and the only real constant, and things may not be getting any better no matter what you do.

So just ride with it, do what you think should be done, try to stay true to something and have it be your choice. Even if it's a terribly sucky choice that you have absolutely no control over and will end badly. Because that's what LISA's all about. Choices, but often forced by those who really should have made better ones earlier.

Gameplay-wise, LISA is a turn-based quirky game filled with humor both surreal and pitch black. Lots of replay value in the many many party members you have allowing you to take different folks through the game where necessary to make different choices from your last run. If you choose to experience every possible route. Though that said there aren't many huge differences from each route, and despite the ethical feelings these choices can lead to, ultimately they're just different kinds of sacrifices that don't lead to some kind of end all golden ending. It plays well and is super challenging, forcing you to adapt quickly and not focus on just grinding things out but instead exploring as much as you can while confronting the insane denizens around you and probably killing them all horribly in the process.

Strongly recommended unless you have a weak stomach, this is a game that will stomp all over you even if you're ready for it. The title screen is of the titual character Lisa already dead and hanging, it's just going to get worse from there. Much much worse.

reviewText:
I'm not finished with the game. but I've just entered the 3rd section which I can guess will be the final part. Even though it's on sale right now I would buy this game for the full price with no question. This RPG is like nothing you have played before. It's a dark, yet hilariously written story with so much charm and attention to detail that I can't wait for anything this developer puts out in the future. To be honest I was just curious because of some of the reviews I read, but I thought it was just going to be a lazy side scroling game I'd try and stop within a couple hours. It seemed like my prediction was coming true for the first hour or two of the game, but man was I plesantly surprised to keep on playing.

I'll start with my only cons: It's short, it can be difficult to learn or play if you're not paying good attention, and the inventory system and lack of any kind of map can make you feel lost at times.

The Pros HIGHLY over shadow its cons: Dark gritty humor, incredible soundtrack, brilliant writing, deep emontial connections with child abuse, addiction, loss, and many topics I have not seen in video games to this date. If your a gamer like me, this really is a must play. You will make difficult decisions with outcomes you probably won't expect.

This is now one of my favorite RPG's I've played and that's saying something. Especially for being a 2D side scroller.
DO NOT give up because of the pace of the game until you get the bike! And by then you'll be hooked.

10/10. Just Brilliant, I need more!

reviewText:
Normally I'd be tempted to just make a really short and dumb review, but Lisa is an exception. The art, crazy music, and combat system is a throwback to earthbound days and it manages to also grab your heart and throw it in a pit, stomp on it repeatedly, then make you laugh again with a dark joke or two just after.

As great as the game is, it does have it's shortcomings, combat can be extremely repetitive, you can beat the entire game with just Brad if you want, but where is the fun in that? This game encourages you to explore all of your options and to really dig for the details, just be wary of the repetitive combat.

And the developer, Austin, props to you for managing to come up with a wide array of memorable characters and that unique as hell soundtrack. Thanks for the wild ride and screw you for making me want to die.

reviewText:
A marvelous RPG with Earthbound elements.
The art style and narrative is definitely unique and quirky.

You go through a miserable journey as Brad.
You meet all sorts of people: perverted, funny, depressed, compulsive.
You can form a team of 4 to fight with you throughout your journey -- from a selection of up to 30 people.
You make some life-threatening decisions that may affect the difficulty of the gameplay.
You encounter various towns and cultures.
You get to see lots of blood and deformities.
You bask in its crude, dark humour.

Also, don't do drugs kids, 'cause withdrawal sucks.

reviewText:
LISA, or to give it its full name, LISA The Painful RPG. Painful is right, as you adventure with Brad to save his adopted daughter you'll struggle with addiction, meet characters who have been through hell, maybe even watch some of your favorite ones die before you. Worst of all you'll feel like a lot of it will be your fault as LISA forces you to make tough decisions with no right answer; dismemberment or death? Sacrifice all your items or sacrifice your only friend? The story is a simple and personal one. There's no world to save, just a very important girl. It hits hard and it's wonderfully engaging. You'll always want to know what happens next. Having said that, it isn't always so downtrodden in tone. LISA also manages to work a lot of humour into its setting and characters. A bunch of middle aged men doing bad Power Rangers impressions, the Mexican guy whose main attributes are crying and hitting enemies with a truck and so much more.

The story is complimented by a soundtrack that is often sombre and occasional lighthearted, thus it fits the mood of the environments and the events perfectly.

Of course there's more to the game than the story. The gameplay is great for those who like turn based RPGS, especially Earthbound as this game is heavily inspired by it. Though there is more to the combat than just choose enemy
recommended: and there are a lot of different characters
hoursPlayed: have different combat styles. For Brad's attacks you have to input button combinations for example. Outside of combat the gameplay is very simple. You mostly just move left and right without any platforming. Moreoever the story and combat are meshed together very well. Certain choices you make will affect how characters behave in combat. It's difficult to say without spoiling it. One example is that  you may chose to save a friend or have on of Brad's arms removed. After the amputation Brad loses a lot of his powerful combos
voteText: since he now only has one arm.\n\nTo summarise
helpfulPercent: LISA is a tough experience that'll make you laugh and maybe cry. It'll make you feel like ♥♥♥♥ at times but you'll always want to come back for more because of the endearing characters that yuo'll no doubt want to see succeed."

reviewText:
Oh boy... whew! Lemme tell ya... oh man..w ooOOwww... oh boy!

I never usually play rpgs outside of Pokemon because I don't like all the grinding and rng. I do, however like the charm and humor of games such as Earthbound despite never having played it. LISA has definitely caught my attention and makes me want to play more games like it. This game is an emotional trip. You will laugh, you will cry (or come very close to crying). The topics explored are dark and sometimes disturbing and the game is not subtle about it. But if you're willing to bear it the message is sure to leave a lasting impression. That and the amazing soundtrack makes this one of the most memorable games I have played recently. I'm looking forward to Dingaling's next project.

I am ashamed to say I bought the complete edition on sale... if you're interested in LISA, don't give it a second thought, this game is well worth every penny.

reviewText:
Lisa is a truly amazing game!
I got it and expected smth completely different but what I found was even better.
The story is enaging, sad and merciless while the gameplay is a great mixture of fun and frustration.
Even the soundtrack is great and original (if so smts super trippy n smts just tear enducing).
To get the whole depth of the story, I recommend to play all 3 titles of this series (Lisa the first, The Painful and the Joyful).

Lisa was an amazing exprience to play through n now I feel left behind and want more of this sorta game. (best way to end a playthrough, really)
Can't recommend it more!!

reviewText:
LISA is a powerhouse of ♥♥♥♥ing emotion and disaster"


Ok to start I want to say
date: I have been gaming since I was 6. Among the many different games I played
recommended: Rpg's were always around since the beginning of time. This game reminds me alot of dragon quest combat with other mixed features. The gameplay is good
hoursPlayed: the combat plays out like it should
voteText: but it is the type of game that punishes the user severely for making bad decisions. The boss fights are hard and I would not reccomend it to anyone who has no experience with old school Rpg formats. SAVE FREQUENTLY\n\nSecondly this game really shines for me with the writing. Dude-man-guy who wrote the story for this game
helpfulPercent: you are a legend. Its funny

commentsCount: LISA is a powerhouse of ♥♥♥♥ing emotion and disaster. The game has many easter eggs and hidden quests/ things to find and do. The further I got into it the more I got sucked into the characters. The game has a really wide array of party members you can recruit. I have to start over 5 more times just to try all the party combinations I considered.\n\nFor the love of LISA try this game
